   <h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en">Philippines</h1> 
   <div id="bodyContent" class="mw-body-content"> 
    <div id="siteSub" class="noprint">
     From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
    </div> 
    <div id="contentSub"></div> 
    <div id="contentSub2"></div> 
    <div id="jump-to-nav"></div> <a class="mw-jump-link" href="#mw-head">Jump to navigation</a> <a class="mw-jump-link" href="#searchInput">Jump to search</a> 
    <div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr">
     <div class="mw-parser-output">
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       "Philippine" redirects here. For the town in the Netherlands, see <a href="/wiki/Philippine,_Netherlands" title="Philippine, Netherlands">Philippine, Netherlands</a>.
      </div> 
      <div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">
       Country in Southeast Asia
      </div> 
      <p> <span style="font-size: small;"><span id="coordinates"><a href="/wiki/Geographic_coordinate_system" title="Geographic coordinate system">Coordinates</a>: <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r994658806">.mw-parser-output .geo-default,.mw-parser-output .geo-dms,.mw-parser-output .geo-dec{display:inline}.mw-parser-output .geo-nondefault,.mw-parser-output .geo-multi-punct{display:none}.mw-parser-output .longitude,.mw-parser-output .latitude{white-space:nowrap}</style><span class="plainlinks nourlexpansion"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//geohack.toolforge.org/geohack.php?pagename=Philippines&amp;params=13_N_122_E_type:country_region:PH"><span class="geo-default"><span class="geo-dms" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location"><span class="latitude">13°N</span> <span class="longitude">122°E</span></span></span><span class="geo-multi-punct">﻿ / ﻿</span><span class="geo-nondefault"><span class="geo-dec" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location">13°N 122°E</span><span style="display:none">﻿ / <span class="geo">13; 122</span></span></span></a></span></span></span> </p>

           <b>Motto:&nbsp;</b>
           <br>"<i lang="fil" title="Filipino-language text"><a href="/wiki/Maka-Diyos,_Maka-Tao,_Makakalikasan_at_Makabansa" class="mw-redirect" title="Maka-Diyos, Maka-Tao, Makakalikasan at Makabansa">Maka-Diyos, Maka-Tao, Makakalikasan at Makabansa</a></i>"<sup id="cite_ref-ra8491_1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ra8491-1">[1]</a></sup>
           <br><span style="font-size:85%;">"For God, People, Nature and Country"</span>

            <a href="/wiki/File:PHL_orthographic.svg" class="image"><img alt="PHL orthographic.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/PHL_orthographic.svg/220px-PHL_orthographic.svg.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="220" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/PHL_orthographic.svg/330px-PHL_orthographic.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/PHL_orthographic.svg/440px-PHL_orthographic.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="550" data-file-height="550"></a><span class="switcher-label" style="display:none" data-switcher-default="">Show globe</span>

           •&nbsp;Per capita
          </div></th>
         <td><img alt="Increase" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/11px-Increase2.svg.png" decoding="async" title="Increase" width="11" height="11" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/17px-Increase2.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/22px-Increase2.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="300" data-file-height="300"> $3,484<sup id="cite_ref-auto_11-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto-11">[11]</a></sup> (<a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)_per_capita" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal) per capita">119th</a>)</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <th scope="row"><a href="/wiki/Gini_coefficient" title="Gini coefficient">Gini</a>&nbsp;<span style="font-weight:normal;">(2015)</span></th>
         <td><img alt="Positive decrease" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Decrease_Positive.svg/11px-Decrease_Positive.svg.png" decoding="async" title="Positive decrease" width="11" height="11" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Decrease_Positive.svg/17px-Decrease_Positive.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Decrease_Positive.svg/22px-Decrease_Positive.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="300" data-file-height="300">&nbsp;44.4<sup id="cite_ref-wb-gini_12-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wb-gini-12">[12]</a></sup><br><span style="white-space:nowrap;"><span style="color:orange">medium</span></span>&nbsp;·&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_income_equality" title="List of countries by income equality">44th</a></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <th scope="row"><a href="/wiki/Human_Development_Index" title="Human Development Index">HDI</a>&nbsp;<span style="font-weight:normal;">(2019)</span></th>
         <td><img alt="Increase" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/11px-Increase2.svg.png" decoding="async" title="Increase" width="11" height="11" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/17px-Increase2.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/22px-Increase2.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="300" data-file-height="300">&nbsp;0.718<sup id="cite_ref-UNHDR_13-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UNHDR-13">[13]</a></sup><br><span style="white-space:nowrap;"><span style="color:forestgreen">high</span></span>&nbsp;·&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_Human_Development_Index" title="List of countries by Human Development Index">107th</a></td>
        </tr>

        <tr>
         <td colspan="2" style="text-align:center">
          <div style="text-align:left;margin-left:auto; margin-right:auto;">
           <ol style="list-style-type: lower-alpha; margin-left: 1em;"> 
            <li value="1"><span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote_a"><b><a href="#ref_a">^</a></b></span> While <a href="/wiki/Manila" title="Manila">Manila</a> is designated as the nation's capital, the <a href="/wiki/Seat_of_government" title="Seat of government">seat of government</a> is the <i>National Capital Region</i>, popularly known as "<a href="/wiki/Metro_Manila" title="Metro Manila">Metro Manila</a>", of which the city of Manila is a part.<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">[15]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">[16]</a></sup> Many national government institutions aside from <a href="/wiki/Malaca%C3%B1ang" class="mw-redirect" title="Malacañang">Malacañang</a> Palace and some agencies/institutions are located within the NCR.</li> 
           </ol>
          </div></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <p>The <b>Philippines</b> (<span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">ˈ</span><span title="'f' in 'find'">f</span><span title="/ɪ/: 'i' in 'kit'">ɪ</span><span title="'l' in 'lie'">l</span><span title="/ɪ/: 'i' in 'kit'">ɪ</span><span title="'p' in 'pie'">p</span><span title="/iː/: 'ee' in 'fleece'">iː</span><span title="'n' in 'nigh'">n</span><span title="'z' in 'zoom'">z</span></span>/</a></span> <span class="nowrap" style="font-size:85%">(<span class="unicode haudio"><span class="fn"><span style="white-space:nowrap;margin-right:.25em;"><a href="/wiki/File:En-us-Philippines.ogg" title="About this sound"><img alt="About this sound" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" decoding="async" width="11" height="11" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="20" data-file-height="20"></a></span><a href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/b/bf/En-us-Philippines.ogg" class="internal" title="En-us-Philippines.ogg">listen</a></span></span>)</span></span>; <a href="/wiki/Filipino_language" title="Filipino language">Filipino</a>: <i lang="fil">Pilipinas</i> <small></small><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Tagalog" title="Help:IPA/Tagalog">[ˌpɪlɪˈpinɐs]</a></span> or <i>Filipinas</i> <small></small><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Tagalog" title="Help:IPA/Tagalog">[fɪlɪˈpinɐs]</a></span>), officially the <b>Republic of the Philippines</b> (<a href="/wiki/Filipino_language" title="Filipino language">Filipino</a>: <i lang="fil">Republika ng Pilipinas</i>),<sup id="cite_ref-a_17-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-a-17">[a]</a></sup> is an <a href="/wiki/Archipelagic_state" title="Archipelagic state">archipelagic country</a> in <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Asia" title="Southeast Asia">Southeast Asia</a>. Situated in the western <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Ocean" title="Pacific Ocean">Pacific Ocean</a>, it consists of about 7,641 islands that are broadly categorized under three main geographical divisions from north to south: <a href="/wiki/Luzon" title="Luzon">Luzon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Visayas" title="Visayas">Visayas</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Mindanao" title="Mindanao">Mindanao</a>. The capital city of the Philippines is <a href="/wiki/Manila" title="Manila">Manila</a> and the most populous city is <a href="/wiki/Quezon_City" title="Quezon City">Quezon City</a>, both within the single urban area of <a href="/wiki/Metro_Manila" title="Metro Manila">Metro Manila</a>. Bounded by the <a href="/wiki/South_China_Sea" title="South China Sea">South China Sea</a> to the west, the <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Sea" title="Philippine Sea">Philippine Sea</a> to the east, and the <a href="/wiki/Celebes_Sea" title="Celebes Sea">Celebes Sea</a> to the southwest, the Philippines shares maritime borders with <a href="/wiki/Taiwan" title="Taiwan">Taiwan</a> to the north, <a href="/wiki/Japan" title="Japan">Japan</a> to the northeast, <a href="/wiki/Palau" title="Palau">Palau</a> to the east, <a href="/wiki/Indonesia" title="Indonesia">Indonesia</a> to the south, <a href="/wiki/Malaysia" title="Malaysia">Malaysia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Brunei" title="Brunei">Brunei</a> to the southwest, <a href="/wiki/Vietnam" title="Vietnam">Vietnam</a> to the west, and <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a> to the northwest. </p>
      <p>The Philippines' position as an <a href="/wiki/List_of_island_countries" title="List of island countries">island country</a> on the Pacific <a href="/wiki/Ring_of_Fire" title="Ring of Fire">Ring of Fire</a> and close to the equator makes the country prone to <a href="/wiki/Earthquakes_in_the_Philippines" class="mw-redirect" title="Earthquakes in the Philippines">earthquakes</a> and <a href="/wiki/Typhoons_in_the_Philippines" title="Typhoons in the Philippines">typhoons</a>. The country has a variety of <a href="/wiki/Natural_resource" title="Natural resource">natural resources</a> and a globally significant <a href="/wiki/Megadiverse_countries" title="Megadiverse countries">level of biodiversity</a>. The Philippines has an area of around 300,000&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> (120,000&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi) with a population of around 109&nbsp;million people. As of 2020<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Philippines&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, it is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_Asian_countries_by_population" title="List of Asian countries by population">8th-most populated country in Asia</a> and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_dependencies_by_population" title="List of countries and dependencies by population">13th-most populated country</a> in the world. Multiple <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_groups_in_the_Philippines" title="Ethnic groups in the Philippines">ethnicities</a> and cultures are found throughout the islands. </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Negrito" title="Negrito">Negritos</a>, some of the archipelago's earliest inhabitants, were followed by <a href="/wiki/Models_of_migration_to_the_Philippines" title="Models of migration to the Philippines">successive waves</a> of <a href="/wiki/Austronesian_peoples" title="Austronesian peoples">Austronesian peoples</a>. The arrival of <a href="/wiki/Ferdinand_Magellan" title="Ferdinand Magellan">Ferdinand Magellan</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Empire" title="Portuguese Empire">Portuguese</a> explorer leading a fleet for Spain, marked the beginning of Spanish colonization. In 1543, Spanish explorer <a href="/wiki/Ruy_L%C3%B3pez_de_Villalobos" title="Ruy López de Villalobos">Ruy López de Villalobos</a> named the archipelago <i><i lang="es" title="Spanish-language text"><a href="https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Filipinas" class="extiw" title="es:Filipinas">Las Islas Filipinas</a></i></i> in honor of <a href="/wiki/Philip_II_of_Spain" title="Philip II of Spain">Philip II of Spain</a>. Spanish settlement, beginning in 1565, led to the Philippines becoming part of the <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Empire" title="Spanish Empire">Spanish Empire</a> for more than 300 years. During this time, <a href="/wiki/Catholicism" class="mw-redirect" title="Catholicism">Catholicism</a> became the dominant religion, and Manila became the western hub of <a href="/wiki/Spanish_treasure_fleet" title="Spanish treasure fleet">trans-Pacific trade</a>. In 1896, the <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Revolution" title="Philippine Revolution">Philippine Revolution</a> began, which then became entwined with the 1898 <a href="/wiki/Spanish%E2%80%93American_War" title="Spanish–American War">Spanish–American War</a>. Spain ceded the territory to the United States, while <a href="/wiki/Hong_Kong_Junta" title="Hong Kong Junta">Filipino rebels</a> declared the <a href="/wiki/First_Philippine_Republic" title="First Philippine Republic">First Philippine Republic</a>. The ensuing <a href="/wiki/Philippine%E2%80%93American_War" title="Philippine–American War">Philippine–American War</a> ended with the United States establishing control over the territory, which they maintained until the <a href="/wiki/Philippines_campaign_(1941%E2%80%931942)" title="Philippines campaign (1941–1942)">Japanese invasion</a> of the islands during <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>. Following <a href="/wiki/Philippines_campaign_(1944%E2%80%931945)" title="Philippines campaign (1944–1945)">liberation</a>, the Philippines became independent in 1946. Since then, the <a href="/wiki/Unitary_state" title="Unitary state">unitary</a> <a href="/wiki/Sovereign_state" title="Sovereign state">sovereign state</a> has often had a tumultuous experience with democracy, which included the overthrow of a <a href="/wiki/Dictatorship" title="Dictatorship">dictatorship</a> by the <a href="/wiki/People_Power_Revolution" title="People Power Revolution">People Power Revolution</a>. </p>
      <p>The Philippines is a founding member of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a>, <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">World Trade Organization</a>, <a href="/wiki/Association_of_Southeast_Asian_Nations" class="mw-redirect" title="Association of Southeast Asian Nations">Association of Southeast Asian Nations</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Asia-Pacific_Economic_Cooperation" title="Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation">Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation</a> forum, and the <a href="/wiki/East_Asia_Summit" title="East Asia Summit">East Asia Summit</a>. The Philippines is considered to be an <a href="/wiki/Emerging_market" title="Emerging market">emerging market</a> and a <a href="/wiki/Newly_industrialized_country" title="Newly industrialized country">newly industrialized country</a>, which has an economy transitioning from being based on agriculture to being based more on services and manufacturing. </p> 
      <div id="toc" class="toc" role="navigation" aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading">

      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Name_of_the_Philippines" class="mw-redirect" title="Name of the Philippines">Name of the Philippines</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Philip_II_portrait_by_Titian.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Philip_II_portrait_by_Titian.jpg/170px-Philip_II_portrait_by_Titian.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="216" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Philip_II_portrait_by_Titian.jpg/255px-Philip_II_portrait_by_Titian.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Philip_II_portrait_by_Titian.jpg/340px-Philip_II_portrait_by_Titian.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1512" data-file-height="1920"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Philip_II_portrait_by_Titian.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Philip_II_of_Spain" title="Philip II of Spain">Philip II of Spain</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Spanish explorer <a href="/wiki/Ruy_L%C3%B3pez_de_Villalobos" title="Ruy López de Villalobos">Ruy López de Villalobos</a>, during his expedition in 1542, named the islands of <a href="/wiki/Leyte" title="Leyte">Leyte</a> and <a href="/wiki/Samar" title="Samar">Samar</a> "<i><i lang="es" title="Spanish-language text">Felipinas</i></i>" after <a href="/wiki/Philip_II_of_Spain" title="Philip II of Spain">Philip&nbsp;II of Spain</a>, then the <a href="/wiki/Prince_of_Asturias" title="Prince of Asturias">Prince of Asturias</a>. Eventually the name "<i><i lang="es" title="Spanish-language text">Las Islas Filipinas</i></i>" would be used to cover the archipelago's Spanish possessions.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEScott1994[httpsbooksgooglecombooksid15KZU-yMuisCpgPA6_6]_18-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEScott1994[httpsbooksgooglecombooksid15KZU-yMuisCpgPA6_6]-18">[17]</a></sup> Before Spanish rule was established, other names such as <i><i lang="es" title="Spanish-language text">Islas del Poniente</i></i> (Islands of the West) and Magellan's name for the islands, <i><i lang="es" title="Spanish-language text">San Lázaro</i></i>, were also used by the Spanish to refer to islands in the region.<sup id="cite_ref-Spate_19-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Spate-19">[18]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Friis_20-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Friis-20">[19]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Galang_21-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Galang-21">[20]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Cambridge1_22-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Cambridge1-22">[21]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>During the <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Revolution" title="Philippine Revolution">Philippine Revolution</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Revolutionary_Government_of_the_Philippines" class="mw-redirect" title="Revolutionary Government of the Philippines">Malolos Congress</a> proclaimed the establishment of the <i><i lang="es" title="Spanish-language text">República Filipina</i></i> or the <i><a href="/wiki/First_Philippine_Republic" title="First Philippine Republic">Philippine Republic</a></i>. From the period of the <a href="/wiki/Spanish%E2%80%93American_War" title="Spanish–American War">Spanish–American War</a> (1898) and the <a href="/wiki/Philippine%E2%80%93American_War" title="Philippine–American War">Philippine–American War</a> (1899–1902) until the <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_of_the_Philippines" title="Commonwealth of the Philippines">Commonwealth</a> period (1935–1946), American colonial authorities referred to the country as the <i>Philippine Islands</i>, a translation of the Spanish name.<sup id="cite_ref-Constantino1975_23-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Constantino1975-23">[22]</a></sup> The full title of the <i>Republic of the Philippines</i> was included in the 1935 constitution as the name of the future independent state.<sup id="cite_ref-PhilIs_24-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PhilIs-24">[23]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Philippines" title="History of the Philippines">History of the Philippines</a>
      </div> 
      <h3><span id="Prehistory_.28pre.E2.80.93900.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Prehistory_(pre–900)">Prehistory (pre–900)</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Prehistory_of_the_Philippines" title="Prehistory of the Philippines">Prehistory of the Philippines</a>
      </div> 
      <p>There is evidence of early <a href="/wiki/Hominins" class="mw-redirect" title="Hominins">hominins</a> living in what is now the Philippines as early as 709,000 years ago.<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">[24]</a></sup> A small number of bones from <a href="/wiki/Callao_Cave" title="Callao Cave">Callao Cave</a> potentially represent an otherwise unknown species, <i><a href="/wiki/Homo_luzonensis" title="Homo luzonensis">Homo luzonensis</a></i>, that lived around 50,000 to 67,000 years ago.<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">[25]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">[26]</a></sup> The oldest <a href="/wiki/Modern_human" class="mw-redirect" title="Modern human">modern human</a> remains found on the islands are from the <a href="/wiki/Tabon_Caves" title="Tabon Caves">Tabon Caves</a> of <a href="/wiki/Palawan" title="Palawan">Palawan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Uranium%E2%80%93thorium_dating" title="Uranium–thorium dating">U/Th-dated</a> to 47,000 ± 11–10,000 years ago.<sup id="cite_ref-Detroit2004_28-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Detroit2004-28">[27]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Tabon_Man" title="Tabon Man">Tabon Man</a> is presumably a <a href="/wiki/Negrito" title="Negrito">Negrito</a>, who were among the archipelago's earliest inhabitants, descendants of the first human migrations out of <a href="/wiki/Africa" title="Africa">Africa</a> via the coastal route along southern Asia to the now sunken landmasses of <a href="/wiki/Sundaland" title="Sundaland">Sundaland</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sahul_(continent)" class="mw-redirect" title="Sahul (continent)">Sahul</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Jett2017_29-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Jett2017-29">[28]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The first Austronesians reached the Philippines at around 2200 BC, settling the <a href="/wiki/Batanes_Islands" class="mw-redirect" title="Batanes Islands">Batanes Islands</a> and <a href="/wiki/Northern_Luzon" class="mw-redirect" title="Northern Luzon">northern Luzon</a> from <a href="/wiki/Taiwan" title="Taiwan">Taiwan</a>. From there, they rapidly spread downwards to the rest of the islands of the Philippines and <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Asia" title="Southeast Asia">Southeast Asia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Chambers2013_30-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Chambers2013-30">[29]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-mijares2006_31-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mijares2006-31">[30]</a></sup> This population assimilated with the existing Negritos resulting in the modern <a href="/wiki/Filipino_ethnic_groups" class="mw-redirect" title="Filipino ethnic groups">Filipino ethnic groups</a> which display various ratios of <a href="/wiki/Genetic_admixture" title="Genetic admixture">genetic admixture</a> between Austronesian and Negrito groups.<sup id="cite_ref-Lipson2014_32-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lipson2014-32">[31]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Philippine_jade_artifacts" class="mw-redirect" title="Philippine jade artifacts">Jade artifacts</a> have been found dated to 2000&nbsp;BC,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEScott198417_33-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEScott198417-33">[32]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34">[33]</a></sup> with the <a href="/wiki/Lingling-o" title="Lingling-o">lingling-o</a> jade items crafted in Luzon made using raw materials originating from Taiwan.<sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35">[34]</a></sup> By 1000&nbsp;BC, the inhabitants of the archipelago had developed into four kinds of social groups: hunter-gatherer tribes, warrior societies, highland <a href="/wiki/Plutocracy" title="Plutocracy">plutocracies</a>, and port principalities.<sup id="cite_ref-Legarda,_Benito,_Jr._2001_40_36-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Legarda,_Benito,_Jr._2001_40-36">[35]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span id="Early_states_.28900.E2.80.931565.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_states_(900–1565)">Early states (900–1565)</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Philippines_(900%E2%80%931565)" title="History of the Philippines (900–1565)">History of the Philippines (900–1565)</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Extract_from_Inskripsyon_sa_Binatbat_na_Tanso_ng_Laguna.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Extract_from_Inskripsyon_sa_Binatbat_na_Tanso_ng_Laguna.jpg/220px-Extract_from_Inskripsyon_sa_Binatbat_na_Tanso_ng_Laguna.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="133" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Extract_from_Inskripsyon_sa_Binatbat_na_Tanso_ng_Laguna.jpg/330px-Extract_from_Inskripsyon_sa_Binatbat_na_Tanso_ng_Laguna.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Extract_from_Inskripsyon_sa_Binatbat_na_Tanso_ng_Laguna.jpg/440px-Extract_from_Inskripsyon_sa_Binatbat_na_Tanso_ng_Laguna.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2920" data-file-height="1768"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Extract_from_Inskripsyon_sa_Binatbat_na_Tanso_ng_Laguna.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Laguna_Copperplate_Inscription" title="Laguna Copperplate Inscription">Laguna Copperplate Inscription</a>, the oldest known writing found in the Philippines
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The earliest known surviving written record found in the Philippines is the <a href="/wiki/Laguna_Copperplate_Inscription" title="Laguna Copperplate Inscription">Laguna Copperplate Inscription</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Postma1992_37-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Postma1992-37">[36]</a></sup> By the 1300s, a number of the large coastal settlements had emerged as trading centers, and became the focal point of societal changes.<sup id="cite_ref-Jocano2001_38-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Jocano2001-38">[37]</a></sup> Some polities had exchanges with other states across Asia.<sup id="cite_ref-Junker1999_39-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Junker1999-39">[38]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Miksic2009_40-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Miksic2009-40">[39]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Sals2005_41-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sals2005-41">[40]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-JocanoJr2012_42-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-JocanoJr2012-42">[41]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated3_43-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated3-43">[42]</a></sup> Trade with China is believed to have begun during the <a href="/wiki/Tang_dynasty" title="Tang dynasty">Tang dynasty</a>, but grew more extensive during the <a href="/wiki/Song_dynasty" title="Song dynasty">Song dynasty</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">[43]</a></sup> By the 2nd millennium CE, some Philippine polities were known to have sent trade delegations which participated in the Tributary system enforced by the Chinese imperial court, trading but without direct political or military control.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEScott1994_45-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEScott1994-45">[44]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources" title="Wikipedia:Citing sources"><span title="This citation requires a reference to the specific page or range of pages in which the material appears. (July 2020)">page&nbsp;needed</span></a></i>]</sup><sup id="cite_ref-Junker1999_39-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Junker1999-39">[38]</a></sup> Indian cultural traits, such as linguistic terms and religious practices, began to spread within the Philippines during the 10th century, likely via the Hindu <a href="/wiki/Majapahit" title="Majapahit">Majapahit</a> empire.<sup id="cite_ref-JocanoJr2012_42-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-JocanoJr2012-42">[41]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Jocano2001_38-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Jocano2001-38">[37]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Osborne2004_46-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Osborne2004-46">[45]</a></sup> By the 15th&nbsp;century, Islam was established in the <a href="/wiki/Sulu_Archipelago" title="Sulu Archipelago">Sulu Archipelago</a> and spread from there.<sup id="cite_ref-McAmis_47-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-McAmis-47">[46]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Polities founded in the Philippines from the 10th–16th centuries include <a href="/wiki/Rajahnate_of_Maynila" class="mw-redirect" title="Rajahnate of Maynila">Maynila</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Ring_48-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ring-48">[47]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Tondo_(historical_polity)" title="Tondo (historical polity)">Tondo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Namayan" title="Namayan">Namayan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Caboloan" title="Caboloan">Pangasinan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rajahnate_of_Cebu" class="mw-redirect" title="Rajahnate of Cebu">Cebu</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rajahnate_of_Butuan" class="mw-redirect" title="Rajahnate of Butuan">Butuan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sultanate_of_Maguindanao" title="Sultanate of Maguindanao">Maguindanao</a>, <a href="/wiki/Confederation_of_sultanates_in_Lanao" title="Confederation of sultanates in Lanao">Lanao</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sultanate_of_Sulu" title="Sultanate of Sulu">Sulu</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Ma-i" title="Ma-i">Ma-i</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">[48]</a></sup> The early polities were typically made up of three-tier social structure: a nobility class, a class of "freemen", and a class of dependent debtor-bondsmen.<sup id="cite_ref-Jocano2001_38-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Jocano2001-38">[37]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Junker1999_39-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Junker1999-39">[38]</a></sup> Among the nobility were leaders called "<a href="/wiki/Datu" title="Datu">Datus</a>," responsible for ruling autonomous groups called "<a href="/wiki/Barangay_(pre-colonial)" class="mw-redirect" title="Barangay (pre-colonial)">barangay</a>" or "dulohan".<sup id="cite_ref-Jocano2001_38-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Jocano2001-38">[37]</a></sup> When these barangays banded together, either to form a larger settlement<sup id="cite_ref-Jocano2001_38-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Jocano2001-38">[37]</a></sup> or a geographically looser alliance group,<sup id="cite_ref-Junker1999_39-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Junker1999-39">[38]</a></sup> the more esteemed among them would be recognized as a "paramount datu",<sup id="cite_ref-Jocano2001_38-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Jocano2001-38">[37]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Legarda,_Benito,_Jr._2001_40_36-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Legarda,_Benito,_Jr._2001_40-36">[35]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Rajah" class="mw-redirect" title="Rajah">rajah</a>, or <a href="/wiki/Sultan" title="Sultan">sultan</a><sup id="cite_ref-Carley2013_50-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Carley2013-50">[49]</a></sup> which headed the community state.<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51">[50]</a></sup> There is little evidence of large-scale violence in the archipelago prior to the 2nd millennium AD,<sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52">[51]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template noprint noexcerpt Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:NOTRS" class="mw-redirect" title="Wikipedia:NOTRS"><span title="This claim needs references to better sources. (October 2020)">better&nbsp;source&nbsp;needed</span></a></i>]</sup> and throughout these periods population density is thought to have been low.<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53">[52]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 1521, Portuguese explorer <a href="/wiki/Ferdinand_Magellan" title="Ferdinand Magellan">Ferdinand Magellan</a> arrived in the area, claimed the islands for Spain, and was then killed at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Mactan" title="Battle of Mactan">Battle of Mactan</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-etymology_54-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-etymology-54">[53]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span id="Colonial_rule_.281565.E2.80.931946.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Colonial_rule_(1565–1946)">Colonial rule (1565–1946)</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Philippines_(1565%E2%80%931898)" title="History of the Philippines (1565–1898)">History of the Philippines (1565–1898)</a> and <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Philippines_(1898%E2%80%931946)" title="History of the Philippines (1898–1946)">History of the Philippines (1898–1946)</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Colonization began when Spanish explorer <a href="/wiki/Miguel_L%C3%B3pez_de_Legazpi" title="Miguel López de Legazpi">Miguel López de Legazpi</a> arrived from Mexico in 1565.<sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55">[54]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Basques_56-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Basques-56">[55]</a></sup><sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">:<span>20–23</span></sup> In 1571, <a href="/wiki/Intramuros" title="Intramuros">Spanish Manila</a> became the capital of the <a href="/wiki/Spanish_East_Indies" title="Spanish East Indies">Spanish East Indies</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57">[56]</a></sup> which also encompassed Spanish territories in Asia and the Pacific.<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58">[57]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Andrade_59-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Andrade-59">[58]</a></sup> The Spanish considered their war with the Muslims in Southeast Asia an extension of the <a href="/wiki/Reconquista" title="Reconquista">Reconquista</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60">[59]</a></sup> The Spanish successfully invaded the different local states by employing the principle of <a href="/wiki/Divide_and_rule" title="Divide and rule">divide and conquer</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61">[60]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Spanish rule brought most of what is now the Philippines into a single unified administration.<sup id="cite_ref-auto5_62-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto5-62">[61]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63">[62]</a></sup> From 1565 to 1821, the Philippines was governed as part of the Mexico-based <a href="/wiki/New_Spain" title="New Spain">Viceroyalty of New Spain</a>, later administered from <a href="/wiki/Madrid" title="Madrid">Madrid</a> following the <a href="/wiki/Mexican_War_of_Independence" title="Mexican War of Independence">Mexican War of Independence</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">[63]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Manila_galleons" class="mw-redirect" title="Manila galleons">Manila galleons</a> were constructed in <a href="/wiki/Bicol_Region" title="Bicol Region">Bicol</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cavite" title="Cavite">Cavite</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65">[64]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66">[65]</a></sup> Manila was the western hub of the <a href="/wiki/Spanish_treasure_fleet" title="Spanish treasure fleet">trans-Pacific trade</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Kane_67-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kane-67">[66]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Intramuros_cannon.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Intramuros_cannon.JPG/220px-Intramuros_cannon.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="152" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Intramuros_cannon.JPG/330px-Intramuros_cannon.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Intramuros_cannon.JPG/440px-Intramuros_cannon.JPG 2x" data-file-width="2021" data-file-height="1395"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Intramuros_cannon.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Spanish artillery along the walls of <a href="/wiki/Intramuros" title="Intramuros">Intramuros</a> to protect the city from local revolts and foreign invaders.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Under Spanish rule, disparate barangays were deliberately <a href="/wiki/Reductions" title="Reductions">consolidated into towns</a>, where <a href="/wiki/Friars_in_Spanish_Philippines" title="Friars in Spanish Philippines">Catholic missionaries</a> were more easily able to convert the inhabitants to <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christianity</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Abinales_68-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Abinales-68">[67]</a></sup><sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">:<span>53, 68</span></sup><sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69">[68]</a></sup> A national <a href="/wiki/Education_in_the_Philippines_during_Spanish_rule" title="Education in the Philippines during Spanish rule">public school system</a> was introduced in 1863.<sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70">[69]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71">[70]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>During its rule, Spain quelled <a href="/wiki/Philippine_revolts_against_Spain" title="Philippine revolts against Spain">various indigenous revolts</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Halili_72-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Halili-72">[71]</a></sup> as well as defending against external military challenges.<sup id="cite_ref-Ooi2004_73-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ooi2004-73">[72]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74">[73]</a></sup> The Philippines was expensive. <a href="/wiki/Battles_of_La_Naval_de_Manila" title="Battles of La Naval de Manila">War against the Dutch</a> from the West, in the 17th century, together with conflict with the Muslims in the South nearly bankrupted the colonial treasury.<sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75">[74]</a></sup> Spanish forces included soldiers from elsewhere in New Spain, many of whom deserted and intermingled with the wider population.<sup id="cite_ref-76" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-76">[75]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77">[76]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78">[77]</a></sup> Immigration blurred the racial caste system<sup id="cite_ref-ReferenceC_79-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceC-79">[78]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80">[79]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Abinales_68-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Abinales-68">[67]</a></sup><sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">:<span>98</span></sup> Spain maintained in towns and cities.<sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81">[80]</a></sup> Administration of the Philippine islands were considered a drain on the economy of Spain,<sup id="cite_ref-Ooi2004_73-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ooi2004-73">[72]</a></sup> and there were debates about abandoning it or trading it for some other territory. However, this was opposed for a number of reasons, including economic potential, security, and the desire to continue religious conversion in the islands and the surrounding region.<sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82">[81]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83">[82]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The Philippines survived on an annual subsidy provided by the Spanish Crown,<sup id="cite_ref-Ooi2004_73-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ooi2004-73">[72]</a></sup> which averaged 250,000 pesos<sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84">[83]</a></sup> and was usually paid through the provision of 75 tons of silver bullion being sent from the Americas.<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85">[84]</a></sup> Financial constraints meant the 200-year-old fortifications in Manila did not see significant change after being first built by the early Spanish colonizers.<sup id="cite_ref-tracy1995p12p55_86-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-tracy1995p12p55-86">[85]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/British_occupation_of_Manila" title="British occupation of Manila">British forces occupied Manila</a> from 1762 to 1764 during the <a href="/wiki/Seven_Years%27_War" title="Seven Years' War">Seven Years' War</a>, however they were unable to extend their conquest outside of Manila as the Filipinos stayed loyal to the remaining Spanish community outside Manila. Spanish rule was restored through the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Paris_(1763)" title="Treaty of Paris (1763)">1763 Treaty of Paris</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Basques_56-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Basques-56">[55]</a></sup><sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">:<span>81–83</span></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Spanish%E2%80%93Moro_conflict" title="Spanish–Moro conflict">Spanish–Moro conflict</a> lasted for several hundred years. In the last quarter of the 19th century, Spain conquered portions of <a href="/wiki/Mindanao" title="Mindanao">Mindanao</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jolo,_Sulu" title="Jolo, Sulu">Jolo</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87">[86]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Moro_people" title="Moro people">Moro</a> Muslims in the <a href="/wiki/Sultanate_of_Sulu" title="Sultanate of Sulu">Sultanate of Sulu</a> formally recognized Spanish sovereignty.<sup id="cite_ref-88" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-88">[87]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-89" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89">[88]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Ilustrados_1890.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Ilustrados_1890.jpg/250px-Ilustrados_1890.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="129" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Ilustrados_1890.jpg/375px-Ilustrados_1890.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Ilustrados_1890.jpg/500px-Ilustrados_1890.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2000" data-file-height="1029"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Ilustrados_1890.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Filipino <i><a href="/wiki/Ilustrado" title="Ilustrado">Ilustrados</a></i> in Spain formed the <a href="/wiki/Propaganda_Movement" title="Propaganda Movement">Propaganda Movement</a>. Photographed in 1890.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In the 19th century, Philippine ports opened to world trade and shifts started occurring within Filipino society.<sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90">[89]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-91" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-91">[90]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Latin_American_wars_of_independence" class="mw-redirect" title="Latin American wars of independence">Latin American wars of independence</a> and renewed immigration led to shifts in social identity, with the term <i>Filipino</i> shifting from referring to <a href="/wiki/Peninsulares" title="Peninsulares">Spaniards born in the Iberian Peninsula</a> and <a href="/wiki/Criollo_people" title="Criollo people">in the Philippines</a> to a term encompassing all people in the archipelago. This identity shift was driven by wealthy <a href="/wiki/Mestizos" class="mw-redirect" title="Mestizos">families of mixed ancestry</a>, for which it developed into a national identity.<sup id="cite_ref-92" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-92">[91]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-93" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-93">[92]</a></sup> This was compounded by a Mexican of Filipino descent, <a href="/wiki/Isidoro_Montes_de_Oca" title="Isidoro Montes de Oca">Isidoro Montes de Oca</a>, becoming captain-general to the revolutionary leader <a href="/wiki/Vicente_Guerrero" title="Vicente Guerrero">Vicente Guerrero</a> during the <a href="/wiki/Mexican_War_of_Independence" title="Mexican War of Independence">Mexican War of Independence</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94">[93]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-95" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-95">[94]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-96" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-96">[95]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Katipuneros.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Katipuneros.jpg/220px-Katipuneros.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="161" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Katipuneros.jpg/330px-Katipuneros.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Katipuneros.jpg/440px-Katipuneros.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1163" data-file-height="853"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Katipuneros.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Photograph of armed Filipino revolutionaries known as <i><a href="/wiki/Katipunan" title="Katipunan">Katipuneros</a></i>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Revolutionary sentiments were stoked in 1872 after <a href="/wiki/Gomburza" title="Gomburza">three activist Catholic priests</a> were executed on weak pretences.<sup id="cite_ref-97" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-97">[96]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98">[97]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Cavite_Mutiny_99-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Cavite_Mutiny-99">[98]</a></sup> This would inspire a <a href="/wiki/Propaganda_movement" class="mw-redirect" title="Propaganda movement">propaganda movement</a> in Spain, organized by <a href="/wiki/Marcelo_H._del_Pilar" title="Marcelo H. del Pilar">Marcelo H. del Pilar</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Rizal" title="José Rizal">José Rizal</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Mariano_Ponce" title="Mariano Ponce">Mariano Ponce</a>, lobbying for political reforms in the Philippines. Rizal was eventually executed on December 30, 1896, on charges of rebellion. This radicalized many who had previously been loyal to Spain.<sup id="cite_ref-ReferenceA1_100-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA1-100">[99]</a></sup> As attempts at reform met with resistance, <a href="/wiki/Andr%C3%A9s_Bonifacio" title="Andrés Bonifacio">Andrés Bonifacio</a> in 1892 established the militant secret society called the <a href="/wiki/Katipunan" title="Katipunan">Katipunan</a>, who sought independence from Spain through armed revolt.<sup id="cite_ref-101" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-101">[100]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The Katipunan <a href="/wiki/Cry_of_Pugad_Lawin" title="Cry of Pugad Lawin">started</a> the <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Revolution" title="Philippine Revolution">Philippine Revolution</a> in 1896.<sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102">[101]</a></sup> Katipunan chapters in Cavite Province, primarily the <a href="/wiki/Magdiwang_(Katipunan_faction)" title="Magdiwang (Katipunan faction)">Magdiwang</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Magdalo_(Katipunan_faction)" class="mw-redirect" title="Magdalo (Katipunan faction)">Magdalo</a> had an internal dispute that led to the <a href="/wiki/Tejeros_Convention" title="Tejeros Convention">Tejeros Convention</a> and an election in which Bonifacio lost his position and <a href="/wiki/Emilio_Aguinaldo" title="Emilio Aguinaldo">Emilio Aguinaldo</a> was elected as the new leader of the revolution.<sup id="cite_ref-Duka_103-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Duka-103">[102]</a></sup><sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">:<span>145–147</span></sup> In 1897, the <a href="/wiki/Pact_of_Biak-na-Bato" title="Pact of Biak-na-Bato">Pact of Biak-na-Bato</a> brought about the <a href="/wiki/Hong_Kong_Junta" title="Hong Kong Junta">exile of the revolutionary leadership to Hong Kong</a>. In 1898, the <a href="/wiki/Spanish%E2%80%93American_War" title="Spanish–American War">Spanish–American War</a> began and reached Philippines. Aguinaldo returned, resumed the revolution, and <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Declaration_of_Independence" title="Philippine Declaration of Independence">declared independence</a> from Spain on June 12, 1898.<sup id="cite_ref-Abinales_68-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Abinales-68">[67]</a></sup><sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">:<span>112–113</span></sup> The <a href="/wiki/First_Philippine_Republic" title="First Philippine Republic">First Philippine Republic</a> was established on January 21, 1899.<sup id="cite_ref-104" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-104">[103]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Douglas_MacArthur_lands_Leyte1.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Douglas_MacArthur_lands_Leyte1.jpg/220px-Douglas_MacArthur_lands_Leyte1.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Douglas_MacArthur_lands_Leyte1.jpg/330px-Douglas_MacArthur_lands_Leyte1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Douglas_MacArthur_lands_Leyte1.jpg/440px-Douglas_MacArthur_lands_Leyte1.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1600" data-file-height="1199"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Douglas_MacArthur_lands_Leyte1.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/General_Douglas_MacArthur" class="mw-redirect" title="General Douglas MacArthur">General Douglas MacArthur</a> landing ashore during the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Leyte" title="Battle of Leyte">Battle of Leyte</a> on October 20, 1944.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The islands had been <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Paris_(1898)" title="Treaty of Paris (1898)">ceded</a> by Spain to the United States alongside <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Rico" title="Puerto Rico">Puerto Rico</a> and <a href="/wiki/Guam" title="Guam">Guam</a> as a result of the latter's victory in the Spanish–American War.<sup id="cite_ref-105" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-105">[104]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106">[105]</a></sup> As it became increasingly clear the United States would not recognize the First Philippine Republic, the <a href="/wiki/Philippine%E2%80%93American_War" title="Philippine–American War">Philippine–American War</a> broke out.<sup id="cite_ref-107" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-107">[106]</a></sup> War resulted in the deaths of 250,000 to 1&nbsp;million civilians, mostly due to famine and disease.<sup id="cite_ref-108" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-108">[107]</a></sup> After the defeat of the First Philippine Republic, an <a href="/wiki/Insular_Government_of_the_Philippine_Islands" title="Insular Government of the Philippine Islands">American civilian government</a> was <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Organic_Act_(1902)" title="Philippine Organic Act (1902)">established</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Gates_109-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Gates-109">[108]</a></sup> American forces continued to secure and extend their control over the islands, suppressing an attempted <a href="/wiki/Tagalog_Republic#Sakay" title="Tagalog Republic">extension of the Philippine Republic</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Duka_103-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Duka-103">[102]</a></sup><sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">:<span>200–202</span></sup><sup id="cite_ref-antonio_abad_110-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-antonio_abad-110">[109]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Kiram-Bates_Treaty" title="Kiram-Bates Treaty">securing the Sultanate of Sulu</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Bates_111-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bates-111">[110]</a></sup> and establishing control over interior mountainous areas that had resisted Spanish conquest.<sup id="cite_ref-112" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-112">[111]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Cultural developments strengthened the continuing development of a national identity,<sup id="cite_ref-books.google.com_113-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-books.google.com-113">[112]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-114" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-114">[113]</a></sup> and Tagalog began to take precedence over other local languages.<sup id="cite_ref-Abinales_68-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Abinales-68">[67]</a></sup><sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">:<span>121</span></sup> In 1935, the Philippines was granted <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_of_the_Philippines" title="Commonwealth of the Philippines">Commonwealth</a> status with <a href="/wiki/Manuel_Quezon" class="mw-redirect" title="Manuel Quezon">Manuel Quezon</a> as president and <a href="/wiki/Sergio_Osme%C3%B1a" title="Sergio Osmeña">Sergio Osmeña</a> as vice president.<sup id="cite_ref-115" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-115">[114]</a></sup> Quezon's priorities were defence, social justice, inequality and economic diversification, and national character.<sup id="cite_ref-116" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-116">[115]</a></sup> Tagalog was designated the <a href="/wiki/Filipino_language" title="Filipino language">national language</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-117" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-117">[116]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/1937_Philippine_women%27s_suffrage_plebiscite" title="1937 Philippine women's suffrage plebiscite">women's suffrage was introduced</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-118" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-118">[117]</a></sup> and land reform mooted.<sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119">[118]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Manapat,_Carlos_2010_120-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Manapat,_Carlos_2010-120">[119]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Philippine_Independence,_July_4_1946.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Philippine_Independence%2C_July_4_1946.jpg/170px-Philippine_Independence%2C_July_4_1946.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="235" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Philippine_Independence%2C_July_4_1946.jpg/255px-Philippine_Independence%2C_July_4_1946.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Philippine_Independence%2C_July_4_1946.jpg/340px-Philippine_Independence%2C_July_4_1946.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1280" data-file-height="1770"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Philippine_Independence,_July_4_1946.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Independence ceremonies following signing of the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Manila_(1946)" title="Treaty of Manila (1946)">Treaty of Manila</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Tydings%E2%80%93McDuffie_Act" title="Tydings–McDuffie Act">Plans for independence</a> over the next decade were interrupted by World War II when the <a href="/wiki/Empire_of_Japan" title="Empire of Japan">Japanese Empire</a> <a href="/wiki/Philippines_campaign_(1941%E2%80%931942)" title="Philippines campaign (1941–1942)">invaded</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Second_Philippine_Republic" title="Second Philippine Republic">Second Philippine Republic</a>, under <a href="/wiki/Jose_P._Laurel" title="Jose P. Laurel">Jose P. Laurel</a>, was established as a puppet state.<sup id="cite_ref-121" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-121">[120]</a></sup> From mid-1942 through mid-1944, the Japanese occupation of the Philippines was <a href="/wiki/Philippine_resistance_against_Japan" title="Philippine resistance against Japan">opposed</a> by large-scale <a href="/wiki/Japanese_occupation_of_the_Philippines#Resistance" title="Japanese occupation of the Philippines">underground guerrilla activity</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-McAAE_122-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-McAAE-122">[121]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-123" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-123">[122]</a></sup> The largest naval battle in history, according to gross tonnage sunk, the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Leyte_Gulf" title="Battle of Leyte Gulf">Battle of Leyte Gulf</a>, occurred when Allied forces began liberating the Philippines from the Japanese Empire.<sup id="cite_ref-Woodward1947_124-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Woodward1947-124">[123]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-125" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-125">[124]</a></sup> Atrocities and <a href="/wiki/Japanese_war_crimes" title="Japanese war crimes">war crimes</a> were committed during the war, including the <a href="/wiki/Bataan_Death_March" title="Bataan Death March">Bataan Death March</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Manila_massacre" title="Manila massacre">Manila massacre</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-126" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-126">[125]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-127" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-127">[126]</a></sup> Allied troops <a href="/wiki/Philippines_Campaign_(1944%E2%80%9345)" class="mw-redirect" title="Philippines Campaign (1944–45)">defeated the Japanese</a> in 1945. By the end of the war it is estimated that over a million Filipinos had died.<sup id="cite_ref-Rottman_128-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rottman-128">[127]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-129" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-129">[128]</a></sup> On October 11, 1945, the Philippines became one of the <a href="/wiki/Member_states_of_the_United_Nations" title="Member states of the United Nations">founding members</a> of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-130" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-130">[129]</a></sup> On July 4, 1946, the Philippines was officially recognized by the United States as an independent nation through the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Manila_(1946)" title="Treaty of Manila (1946)">Treaty of Manila</a>, during the presidency of <a href="/wiki/Manuel_Roxas" title="Manuel Roxas">Manuel Roxas</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Treaty_of_Manila_131-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Treaty_of_Manila-131">[130]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span id="Postcolonial_period_.281946.E2.80.93present.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Postcolonial_period_(1946–present)">Postcolonial period (1946–present)</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Philippines_(1946%E2%80%9365)" class="mw-redirect" title="History of the Philippines (1946–65)">History of the Philippines (1946–65)</a>, <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Philippines_(1965%E2%80%9386)" class="mw-redirect" title="History of the Philippines (1965–86)">History of the Philippines (1965–86)</a>, and <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Philippines_(1986%E2%80%93present)" title="History of the Philippines (1986–present)">History of the Philippines (1986–present)</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Efforts to end the <a href="/wiki/Hukbalahap_Rebellion" title="Hukbalahap Rebellion">Hukbalahap Rebellion</a> began during <a href="/wiki/Elpidio_Quirino" title="Elpidio Quirino">Elpidio Quirino</a>'s term,<sup id="cite_ref-132" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-132">[131]</a></sup> however, it was only during <a href="/wiki/Ramon_Magsaysay" title="Ramon Magsaysay">Ramon Magsaysay</a>'s presidency was the movement suppressed.<sup id="cite_ref-133" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-133">[132]</a></sup> Magsaysay's successor, <a href="/wiki/Carlos_P._Garcia" title="Carlos P. Garcia">Carlos P. Garcia</a>, initiated the <a href="/wiki/Filipino_First_policy" title="Filipino First policy">Filipino First Policy</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-134" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-134">[133]</a></sup> which was continued by <a href="/wiki/Diosdado_Macapagal" title="Diosdado Macapagal">Diosdado Macapagal</a>, with celebration of Independence Day moved from July 4 to June 12, the date of Emilio Aguinaldo's declaration,<sup id="cite_ref-bibingka-jun12_135-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bibingka-jun12-135">[134]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-136" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-136">[135]</a></sup> and pursuit of <a href="/wiki/North_Borneo_dispute" title="North Borneo dispute">a claim</a> on the eastern part of <a href="/wiki/North_Borneo" title="North Borneo">North Borneo</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-137" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-137">[136]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-138" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-138">[137]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 1965, Macapagal lost the presidential election to <a href="/wiki/Ferdinand_Marcos" title="Ferdinand Marcos">Ferdinand Marcos</a>. Early in his presidency, Marcos initiated numerous infrastructure projects<sup id="cite_ref-139" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-139">[138]</a></sup> but, together with his wife <a href="/wiki/Imelda_Marcos" title="Imelda Marcos">Imelda</a>, was accused of corruption and embezzling billions of dollars in public funds.<sup id="cite_ref-140" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-140">[139]</a></sup> Nearing the end of his term, Marcos declared <a href="/wiki/Martial_law_in_the_Philippines" title="Martial law in the Philippines">martial law</a> on September 21, 1972.<sup id="cite_ref-141" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-141">[140]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-142" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-142">[141]</a></sup> This period of his rule was characterized by political repression, censorship, and human rights violations.<sup id="cite_ref-143" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-143">[142]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>On August 21, 1983, Marcos' chief rival, opposition leader <a href="/wiki/Benigno_Aquino_Jr." title="Benigno Aquino Jr.">Benigno Aquino Jr.</a>, was <a href="/wiki/Assassination_of_Benigno_Aquino_Jr." title="Assassination of Benigno Aquino Jr.">assassinated</a> on the tarmac at <a href="/wiki/Manila_International_Airport" class="mw-redirect" title="Manila International Airport">Manila International Airport</a>. Marcos called a snap <a href="/wiki/1986_Philippine_presidential_election" title="1986 Philippine presidential election">presidential election in 1986</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Chandler_144-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Chandler-144">[143]</a></sup> Marcos was proclaimed the winner, but the results were widely regarded as fraudulent.<sup id="cite_ref-:7_145-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:7-145">[144]</a></sup> The resulting protests led to the <a href="/wiki/People_Power_Revolution" title="People Power Revolution">People Power Revolution</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Gandhi_146-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Gandhi-146">[145]</a></sup> which forced Marcos and his allies to flee to <a href="/wiki/Hawaii" title="Hawaii">Hawaii</a>, and Aquino's widow, <a href="/wiki/Corazon_Aquino" title="Corazon Aquino">Corazon Aquino</a>, was installed as president.<sup id="cite_ref-Chandler_144-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Chandler-144">[143]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-147" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-147">[146]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Pinatubo91eruption_plume.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Pinatubo91eruption_plume.jpg/220px-Pinatubo91eruption_plume.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Pinatubo91eruption_plume.jpg/330px-Pinatubo91eruption_plume.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Pinatubo91eruption_plume.jpg/440px-Pinatubo91eruption_plume.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2875" data-file-height="1923"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Pinatubo91eruption_plume.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/1991_eruption_of_Mount_Pinatubo" title="1991 eruption of Mount Pinatubo">1991 eruption of Mount Pinatubo</a> was the second largest volcanic eruption of the 20th century.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The return of democracy and government reforms beginning in 1986 were hampered by national debt, government corruption, <a href="/wiki/1986%E2%80%9390_Philippine_coup_attempts" class="mw-redirect" title="1986–90 Philippine coup attempts">coup attempts</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-148" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-148">[147]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-149" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-149">[148]</a></sup> a persistent <a href="/wiki/CPP-NPA-NDF_rebellion" class="mw-redirect" title="CPP-NPA-NDF rebellion">communist insurgency</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-150" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-150">[149]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-151" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-151">[150]</a></sup> and a military conflict with <a href="/wiki/Moro_conflict" title="Moro conflict">Moro separatists</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-152" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-152">[151]</a></sup> The administration also faced a series of disasters, including the sinking of the <i><a href="/wiki/MV_Do%C3%B1a_Paz" title="MV Doña Paz">MV Doña Paz</a></i> in December 1987<sup id="cite_ref-nyt1_153-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nyt1-153">[152]</a></sup> and the eruption of <a href="/wiki/Mount_Pinatubo" title="Mount Pinatubo">Mount Pinatubo</a> in June 1991.<sup id="cite_ref-154" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-154">[153]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-155" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-155">[154]</a></sup> Aquino was succeeded by <a href="/wiki/Fidel_V._Ramos" title="Fidel V. Ramos">Fidel V. Ramos</a>, whose economic performance, at 3.6% growth rate,<sup id="cite_ref-lastlaugh_156-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lastlaugh-156">[155]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-157" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-157">[156]</a></sup> was overshadowed by the onset of the <a href="/wiki/1997_Asian_financial_crisis" title="1997 Asian financial crisis">1997 Asian financial crisis</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-AFC-NA-13_158-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AFC-NA-13-158">[157]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-AFC-NA-14_159-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AFC-NA-14-159">[158]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Ramos' successor, <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Estrada" title="Joseph Estrada">Joseph Estrada</a>, was overthrown by the <a href="/wiki/2001_EDSA_Revolution" class="mw-redirect" title="2001 EDSA Revolution">2001 EDSA Revolution</a> and succeeded by his <a href="/wiki/Vice_President_of_the_Philippines" title="Vice President of the Philippines">Vice President</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gloria_Macapagal-Arroyo" class="mw-redirect" title="Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo">Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo</a>, on January 20, 2001.<sup id="cite_ref-160" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-160">[159]</a></sup> Arroyo's 9-year administration was marked by economic growth,<sup id="cite_ref-161" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-161">[160]</a></sup> but was tainted by graft and political scandals.<sup id="cite_ref-162" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-162">[161]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-163" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-163">[162]</a></sup> On November 23, 2009, 34 journalists and several civilians were <a href="/wiki/Maguindanao_massacre" title="Maguindanao massacre">killed in Maguindanao</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-164" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-164">[163]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-maptimeline_165-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-maptimeline-165">[164]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Economic growth continued during <a href="/wiki/Benigno_Aquino_III" title="Benigno Aquino III">Benigno Aquino III</a>'s administration, which pushed for good governance and transparency.<sup id="cite_ref-166" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-166">[165]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-167" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-167">[166]</a></sup> In 2015, a <a href="/wiki/Mamasapano_clash" title="Mamasapano clash">clash</a> which took place in Mamasapano, Maguindanao killed 44 members of the <a href="/wiki/Philippine_National_Police" title="Philippine National Police">Philippine National Police</a>-<a href="/wiki/Special_Action_Force" title="Special Action Force">Special Action Force</a>, resulting in efforts to pass the <a href="/wiki/Bangsamoro_Basic_Law" class="mw-redirect" title="Bangsamoro Basic Law">Bangsamoro Basic Law</a> reaching an impasse.<sup id="cite_ref-168" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-168">[167]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-169" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-169">[168]</a></sup> Former <a href="/wiki/Davao_City" title="Davao City">Davao City</a> mayor <a href="/wiki/Rodrigo_Duterte" title="Rodrigo Duterte">Rodrigo Duterte</a> won the <a href="/wiki/2016_Philippine_presidential_election" title="2016 Philippine presidential election">2016 presidential election</a>, becoming the first president from Mindanao.<sup id="cite_ref-2016_election_170-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2016_election-170">[169]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-171" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-171">[170]</a></sup> Duterte launched <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Drug_War" class="mw-redirect" title="Philippine Drug War">an anti-drug campaign</a><sup id="cite_ref-172" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-172">[171]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-173" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-173">[172]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Build!_Build!_Build!_Infrastructure_Plan" class="mw-redirect" title="Build! Build! Build! Infrastructure Plan">an infrastructure plan</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-174" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-174">[173]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-175" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-175">[174]</a></sup> The implementation of the <a href="/wiki/Bangsamoro_Organic_Law" title="Bangsamoro Organic Law">Bangsamoro Organic Law</a> led to the creation of the autonomous <a href="/wiki/Bangsamoro" title="Bangsamoro">Bangsamoro</a> region in Mindanao.<sup id="cite_ref-willitlast_176-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-willitlast-176">[175]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-CarolynArguillas20190126_177-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CarolynArguillas20190126-177">[176]</a></sup> In early 2020, the <a href="/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_the_Philippines" title="COVID-19 pandemic in the Philippines">COVID-19 pandemic</a> reached the country<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_178-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-178">[177]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-phconfirms_179-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-phconfirms-179">[178]</a></sup> causing the economy to contract by 9.5% in terms of gross domestic product since records began in 1947.<sup id="cite_ref-180" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-180">[179]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 2021, it was revealed the United States would defend the Philippines including the <a href="/wiki/South_China_Sea" title="South China Sea">South China sea</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-181" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-181">[180]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography_and_environment">Geography and environment</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_the_Philippines" title="Geography of the Philippines">Geography of the Philippines</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Relief_Map_Of_The_Philippines.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/Relief_Map_Of_The_Philippines.png/170px-Relief_Map_Of_The_Philippines.png" decoding="async" width="170" height="249" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/Relief_Map_Of_The_Philippines.png/255px-Relief_Map_Of_The_Philippines.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/Relief_Map_Of_The_Philippines.png/340px-Relief_Map_Of_The_Philippines.png 2x" data-file-width="2134" data-file-height="3120"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Relief_Map_Of_The_Philippines.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Topography of the Philippines
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The Philippines is an <a href="/wiki/Archipelago" title="Archipelago">archipelago</a> composed of about 7,641 <a href="/wiki/List_of_islands_of_the_Philippines" title="List of islands of the Philippines">islands</a><sup id="cite_ref-182" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-182">[181]</a></sup> with a total land area, including inland bodies of water, of around 300,000 square kilometers (115,831&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi),<sup id="cite_ref-183" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-183">[182]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Boquet_184-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Boquet-184">[183]</a></sup> with cadastral survey data suggesting it may be larger.<sup id="cite_ref-185" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-185">[184]</a></sup> The 36,289 kilometers (22,549&nbsp;mi) of coastline makes it the country with the fifth <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_length_of_coastline" title="List of countries by length of coastline">longest coastline</a> in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-CIAfields_186-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIAfields-186">[185]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Exclusive_economic_zone_of_the_Philippines" title="Exclusive economic zone of the Philippines">exclusive economic zone of the Philippines</a> covers 2,263,816&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> (874,064&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi).<sup id="cite_ref-187" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-187">[186]</a></sup> It is located between 116°&nbsp;40', and 126°&nbsp;34' E longitude and 4°&nbsp;40' and 21°&nbsp;10' N latitude and is bordered by the <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Sea" title="Philippine Sea">Philippine Sea</a><sup id="cite_ref-188" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-188">[187]</a></sup> to the east, the <a href="/wiki/South_China_Sea" title="South China Sea">South China Sea</a><sup id="cite_ref-189" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-189">[188]</a></sup> to the west, and the <a href="/wiki/Celebes_Sea" title="Celebes Sea">Celebes Sea</a> to the south.<sup id="cite_ref-190" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-190">[189]</a></sup> The island of <a href="/wiki/Borneo" title="Borneo">Borneo</a> is located a few hundred kilometers southwest<sup id="cite_ref-191" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-191">[190]</a></sup> and Taiwan is located directly to the north. The <a href="/wiki/Maluku_Islands" title="Maluku Islands">Moluccas</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sulawesi" title="Sulawesi">Sulawesi</a> are located to the south-southwest and <a href="/wiki/Palau" title="Palau">Palau</a> is located to the east of the islands.<sup id="cite_ref-About_192-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-About-192">[191]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The highest <a href="/wiki/List_of_mountains_in_the_Philippines" title="List of mountains in the Philippines">mountain</a> is <a href="/wiki/Mount_Apo" title="Mount Apo">Mount Apo</a>. It measures up to 2,954 meters (9,692&nbsp;ft) above sea level and is located on the island of <a href="/wiki/Mindanao" title="Mindanao">Mindanao</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-193" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-193">[192]</a></sup> The Galathea Depth in the <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Trench" title="Philippine Trench">Philippine Trench</a> is the deepest point in the country and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_submarine_topographical_features#List_of_oceanic_trenches" title="List of submarine topographical features">third deepest in the world</a>. The trench is located in the Philippine Sea.<sup id="cite_ref-194" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-194">[193]</a></sup> The longest <a href="/wiki/List_of_rivers_of_the_Philippines" title="List of rivers of the Philippines">river</a> is the <a href="/wiki/Cagayan_River" title="Cagayan River">Cagayan River</a> in northern <a href="/wiki/Luzon" title="Luzon">Luzon</a>, measuring about 520 kilometers (320&nbsp;mi).<sup id="cite_ref-195" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-195">[194]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Manila_Bay" title="Manila Bay">Manila Bay</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Jacinto_et_al_(A)_196-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Jacinto_et_al_(A)-196">[195]</a></sup> upon the shore of which the capital city of Manila lies, is connected to <a href="/wiki/Laguna_de_Bay" title="Laguna de Bay">Laguna de Bay</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-197" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-197">[196]</a></sup> the largest <a href="/wiki/List_of_lakes_of_the_Philippines" title="List of lakes of the Philippines">lake</a> in the Philippines, by the <a href="/wiki/Pasig_River" title="Pasig River">Pasig River</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-rehabinfo_198-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rehabinfo-198">[197]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Princesa_Subterranean_River" class="mw-redirect" title="Puerto Princesa Subterranean River">Puerto Princesa Subterranean River</a>, which runs 8.2 kilometers (5.1&nbsp;mi) underground through a <a href="/wiki/Karst" title="Karst">karst</a> landscape before reaching the ocean, is a <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO</a> <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Site" title="World Heritage Site">World Heritage Site</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-199" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-199">[198]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
