        <a href="/wiki/File:Mt.Mayon_tam3rd.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Mt.Mayon_tam3rd.jpg/220px-Mt.Mayon_tam3rd.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="140" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Mt.Mayon_tam3rd.jpg/330px-Mt.Mayon_tam3rd.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Mt.Mayon_tam3rd.jpg/440px-Mt.Mayon_tam3rd.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="765"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Mt.Mayon_tam3rd.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Mayon" title="Mayon">Mayon</a> is the Philippines' most active volcano.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Situated on the western fringes of the Pacific <a href="/wiki/Ring_of_Fire" title="Ring of Fire">Ring of Fire</a>, the Philippines experiences frequent seismic and volcanic activity.<sup id="cite_ref-200" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-200">[199]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Benham_Plateau" class="mw-redirect" title="Benham Plateau">Benham Plateau</a> to the east in the Philippine Sea is an undersea region active in <a href="/wiki/Plate_tectonics" title="Plate tectonics">tectonic</a> <a href="/wiki/Subduction" title="Subduction">subduction</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-CLCS_submissions_201-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CLCS_submissions-201">[200]</a></sup> Around 20 <a href="/wiki/List_of_earthquakes_in_the_Philippines" title="List of earthquakes in the Philippines">earthquakes</a> are registered daily, though most are too weak to be felt. The last major earthquake was the <a href="/wiki/1990_Luzon_earthquake" title="1990 Luzon earthquake">1990 Luzon earthquake</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-202" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-202">[201]</a></sup> There are <a href="/wiki/List_of_active_volcanoes_in_the_Philippines" title="List of active volcanoes in the Philippines">many active volcanoes</a> such as the <a href="/wiki/Mayon_Volcano" class="mw-redirect" title="Mayon Volcano">Mayon Volcano</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mount_Pinatubo" title="Mount Pinatubo">Mount Pinatubo</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Taal_Volcano" title="Taal Volcano">Taal Volcano</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-PHIVOLCS-Volcanoes_203-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PHIVOLCS-Volcanoes-203">[202]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/1991_eruption_of_Mount_Pinatubo" title="1991 eruption of Mount Pinatubo">eruption of Mount Pinatubo in June 1991</a> produced the <a href="/wiki/List_of_large_volcanic_eruptions_of_the_20th_century" title="List of large volcanic eruptions of the 20th century">second largest terrestrial eruption</a> of the 20th&nbsp;century.<sup id="cite_ref-Pinatubo1991_204-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pinatubo1991-204">[203]</a></sup> The Philippines is the world's second-biggest <a href="/wiki/Geothermal_power_in_the_Philippines" title="Geothermal power in the Philippines">geothermal energy</a> producer behind the United States, with 18% of <a href="/wiki/Energy_in_the_Philippines" title="Energy in the Philippines">the country's electricity</a> needs being met by geothermal power.<sup id="cite_ref-205" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-205">[204]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Significant mineral deposits exist as a result of the country's complex geologic structure and high level of seismic activity.<sup id="cite_ref-206" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-206">[205]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-207" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-207">[206]</a></sup> These deposites are considered highly valuable.<sup id="cite_ref-Inquirer-PhilippinesSits_208-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Inquirer-PhilippinesSits-208">[207]</a></sup> The country is thought to have the second-largest gold deposits after South Africa, along with a large amount of copper deposits.<sup id="cite_ref-NYTimesMiners_209-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYTimesMiners-209">[208]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Palladium" title="Palladium">Palladium</a>, originally discovered in <a href="/wiki/South_America" title="South America">South America</a>, was found to have the world's largest deposits in the Philippines too.<sup id="cite_ref-Inquirer-FirmSeesMetal_210-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Inquirer-FirmSeesMetal-210">[209]</a></sup> Other minerals include chromite, nickel, and zinc. Despite this, a lack of law enforcement, poor management, opposition due to the presence of indigenous communities, and past instances of environmental damages and disasters, have resulted in these mineral resources remaining largely untapped.<sup id="cite_ref-NYTimesMiners_209-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYTimesMiners-209">[208]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-211" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-211">[210]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Biodiversity">Biodiversity</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Wildlife_of_the_Philippines" title="Wildlife of the Philippines">Wildlife of the Philippines</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_threatened_species_of_the_Philippines" title="List of threatened species of the Philippines">List of threatened species of the Philippines</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Pithecophaga_jefferyi_front.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/Pithecophaga_jefferyi_front.jpg/220px-Pithecophaga_jefferyi_front.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="264" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/Pithecophaga_jefferyi_front.jpg/330px-Pithecophaga_jefferyi_front.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/Pithecophaga_jefferyi_front.jpg/440px-Pithecophaga_jefferyi_front.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1000" data-file-height="1200"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Pithecophaga_jefferyi_front.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Eagle" class="mw-redirect" title="Philippine Eagle">Philippine Eagle</a> is endemic to the forests of the country.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The Philippines is a <a href="/wiki/Megadiverse_countries" title="Megadiverse countries">megadiverse country</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Chanco_212-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Chanco-212">[211]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-AUSGOP_213-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AUSGOP-213">[212]</a></sup> Eight major types of forests are distributed throughout the Philippines; <a href="/wiki/Dipterocarp" class="mw-redirect" title="Dipterocarp">dipterocarp</a>, beach forest, <a href="/wiki/Pine" title="Pine">pine</a> forest, <a href="/wiki/Vitex_parviflora" title="Vitex parviflora">molave</a> forest, <a href="/wiki/Montane_ecosystems" title="Montane ecosystems">lower montane forest</a>, upper montane or <a href="/wiki/Mossy_forest" class="mw-redirect" title="Mossy forest">mossy forest</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mangrove" title="Mangrove">mangroves</a>, and ultrabasic forest.<sup id="cite_ref-214" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-214">[213]</a></sup> Around 1,100 land vertebrate species can be found in the Philippines including over 100 mammal species and 170 bird species not thought to exist elsewhere.<sup id="cite_ref-lonelyplanet_215-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lonelyplanet-215">[214]</a></sup> The Philippines has among the highest rates of discovery in the world with sixteen new species of <a href="/wiki/Mammals" class="mw-redirect" title="Mammals">mammals</a> discovered in the last ten years. Because of this, the rate of <a href="/wiki/List_of_ecoregions_with_high_endemism" title="List of ecoregions with high endemism">endemism</a> for the Philippines has risen and likely will continue to rise.<sup id="cite_ref-216" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-216">[215]</a></sup> Parts of its marine waters contain the highest diversity of shorefish species in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-Carpenter_217-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Carpenter-217">[216]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Large <a href="/wiki/Reptiles" class="mw-redirect" title="Reptiles">reptiles</a> include the <a href="/wiki/Philippine_crocodile" title="Philippine crocodile">Philippine crocodile</a><sup id="cite_ref-218" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-218">[217]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Saltwater_crocodile" title="Saltwater crocodile">saltwater crocodile</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-219" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-219">[218]</a></sup> The largest crocodile in captivity, known locally as <a href="/wiki/Lolong" title="Lolong">Lolong</a>, was captured in the southern island of Mindanao,<sup id="cite_ref-220" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-220">[219]</a></sup> and died on February 10, 2013 from <a href="/wiki/Pneumonia" title="Pneumonia">pneumonia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cardiac_arrest" title="Cardiac arrest">cardiac arrest</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-221" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-221">[220]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/National_bird" class="mw-redirect" title="National bird">national bird</a>, known as the <a href="/wiki/Philippine_eagle" title="Philippine eagle">Philippine eagle</a>, has the longest body of any <a href="/wiki/Eagle" title="Eagle">eagle</a>; it generally measures 86 to 102&nbsp;cm (2.82 to 3.35&nbsp;ft) in length and weighs 4.7 to 8.0&nbsp;kg (10.4 to 17.6&nbsp;lb).<sup id="cite_ref-RaptorsWorld_222-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RaptorsWorld-222">[221]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-223" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-223">[222]</a></sup> The Philippine eagle is part of the family <a href="/wiki/Accipitridae" title="Accipitridae">Accipitridae</a> and is endemic to the rainforests of Luzon, Samar, Leyte and Mindanao.<sup id="cite_ref-224" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-224">[223]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Philippine <a href="/wiki/Territorial_waters" title="Territorial waters">maritime waters</a> encompass as much as 2,200,000 square kilometers (849,425&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi) producing unique and diverse marine life,<sup id="cite_ref-FAOOrg_225-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FAOOrg-225">[224]</a></sup> an important part of the <a href="/wiki/Coral_Triangle" title="Coral Triangle">Coral Triangle</a>, a territory shared with other countries.<sup id="cite_ref-LiveScience-CoralTriangle_226-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LiveScience-CoralTriangle-226">[225]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-PNAGovPH-PHSeeks_227-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PNAGovPH-PHSeeks-227">[226]</a></sup> The total number of corals and marine fish species was estimated at 500 and 2,400 respectively.<sup id="cite_ref-lonelyplanet_215-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lonelyplanet-215">[214]</a></sup> New records<sup id="cite_ref-228" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-228">[227]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-229" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-229">[228]</a></sup> and species discoveries continue.<sup id="cite_ref-230" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-230">[229]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-231" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-231">[230]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-232" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-232">[231]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Tubbataha_Reef" title="Tubbataha Reef">Tubbataha Reef</a> in the Sulu Sea was declared a World Heritage Site in 1993.<sup id="cite_ref-233" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-233">[232]</a></sup> Philippine waters also sustain the cultivation of fish, crustaceans, oysters, and seaweeds.<sup id="cite_ref-234" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-234">[233]</a></sup> One species of oyster, <a href="/wiki/Pinctada_maxima" title="Pinctada maxima">Pinctada maxima</a>, produces pearls that are naturally golden in color.<sup id="cite_ref-235" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-235">[234]</a></sup> Pearls have been declared a "National Gem".<sup id="cite_ref-gem_236-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gem-236">[235]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>With an estimated 13,500 plant species in the country, 3,200 of which are unique to the islands,<sup id="cite_ref-lonelyplanet_215-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lonelyplanet-215">[214]</a></sup> Philippine <a href="/wiki/Rainforests" class="mw-redirect" title="Rainforests">rainforests</a> boast an array of flora,<sup id="cite_ref-biodiverse_237-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-biodiverse-237">[236]</a></sup> including many rare types of <a href="/wiki/List_of_the_orchids_of_the_Philippines" title="List of the orchids of the Philippines">orchids</a><sup id="cite_ref-238" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-238">[237]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Rafflesia" title="Rafflesia">rafflesia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-239" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-239">[238]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Deforestation" title="Deforestation">Deforestation</a>, often the result of <a href="/wiki/Illegal_logging" title="Illegal logging">illegal logging</a>, is <a href="/wiki/Deforestation_in_the_Philippines" title="Deforestation in the Philippines">an acute problem in the Philippines</a>. Forest cover declined from 70% of the Philippines's total land area in 1900 to about 18.3% in 1999.<sup id="cite_ref-240" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-240">[239]</a></sup> Many species are endangered and scientists say that Southeast Asia, which the Philippines is part of, faces a catastrophic extinction rate of 20% by the end of the 21st century.<sup id="cite_ref-241" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-241">[240]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">Climate</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Climate_of_the_Philippines" title="Climate of the Philippines">Climate of the Philippines</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Koppen-Geiger_Map_PHL_present.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Koppen-Geiger_Map_PHL_present.svg/220px-Koppen-Geiger_Map_PHL_present.svg.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="155" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Koppen-Geiger_Map_PHL_present.svg/330px-Koppen-Geiger_Map_PHL_present.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Koppen-Geiger_Map_PHL_present.svg/440px-Koppen-Geiger_Map_PHL_present.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1203" data-file-height="850"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Koppen-Geiger_Map_PHL_present.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification" title="Köppen climate classification">Köppen climate classification</a> of the Philippines
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The Philippines has a tropical maritime climate that is usually hot and humid. There are three seasons: a hot dry season or summer from March to May; a rainy season from June to November; and a cool dry season from December to February. The southwest <a href="/wiki/Monsoon" title="Monsoon">monsoon</a> lasts from from May to October, and the northeast monsoon from November to April. Temperatures usually range from 21&nbsp;°C (70&nbsp;°F) to 32&nbsp;°C (90&nbsp;°F). The coolest month is January; the warmest is May.<sup id="cite_ref-PAGASA-Climate_242-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PAGASA-Climate-242">[241]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The average yearly temperature is around 26.6&nbsp;°C (79.9&nbsp;°F). In considering temperature, location in terms of latitude and longitude is not a significant factor, and temperatures at sea level tend to be in the same range. Altitude usually has more of an impact. The average annual temperature of <a href="/wiki/Baguio" title="Baguio">Baguio</a> at an elevation of 1,500 meters (4,900&nbsp;ft) above sea level is 18.3&nbsp;°C (64.9&nbsp;°F), making it a popular destination during hot summers.<sup id="cite_ref-PAGASA-Climate_242-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PAGASA-Climate-242">[241]</a></sup> Annual rainfall measures as much as 5,000 millimeters (200&nbsp;in) in the mountainous east coast section but less than 1,000 millimeters (39&nbsp;in) in some of the sheltered valleys.<sup id="cite_ref-cp_243-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cp-243">[242]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Sitting astride the <a href="/wiki/Typhoons_in_the_Philippines" title="Typhoons in the Philippines">typhoon belt</a>, the islands experience 15–20 typhoons annually from July to October,<sup id="cite_ref-cp_243-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cp-243">[242]</a></sup> with around nineteen typhoons<sup id="cite_ref-244" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-244">[243]</a></sup> entering the <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Area_of_Responsibility" title="Philippine Area of Responsibility">Philippine area of responsibility</a> in a typical year and eight or nine making landfall.<sup id="cite_ref-PagasaWMO_245-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PagasaWMO-245">[244]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-digitaltyphoon_246-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-digitaltyphoon-246">[245]</a></sup> Historically typhoons were sometimes referred to as <i>baguios</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-247" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-247">[246]</a></sup> The wettest recorded typhoon to hit the Philippines dropped 2,210 millimeters (87&nbsp;in) in Baguio from July 14 to 18, 1911.<sup id="cite_ref-248" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-248">[247]</a></sup> The Philippines is highly <a href="/wiki/Climate_change_in_the_Philippines" class="mw-redirect" title="Climate change in the Philippines">exposed to climate change</a> and is among the world's ten countries that are most <a href="/wiki/Climate_change_vulnerability" title="Climate change vulnerability">vulnerable to climate change</a> risks.<sup id="cite_ref-249" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-249">[248]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_the_Philippines" title="Demographics of the Philippines">Demographics of the Philippines</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:BGC.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/BGC.jpg/220px-BGC.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="79" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/BGC.jpg/330px-BGC.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/BGC.jpg/440px-BGC.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1080" data-file-height="390"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:BGC.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Skyline of <a href="/wiki/Taguig" title="Taguig">Taguig</a>, the 7th most populous city in the Philippines.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The Commission on Population estimated the country's population to be 107,190,081 as of December 31, 2018, based on the latest population census of 2015 conducted by the Philippine Statistics Authority.<sup id="cite_ref-Philippines_Estimated_2018_Population_250-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Philippines_Estimated_2018_Population-250">[249]</a></sup> The population increased from 1990 to 2008 by approximately 28&nbsp;million, a 45% growth in that time frame.<sup id="cite_ref-IEApop2011_251-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IEApop2011-251">[250]</a></sup> The first <a href="/wiki/Philippines_census" class="mw-redirect" title="Philippines census">official census</a> in the Philippines was carried out in 1877 and recorded a population of 5,567,685.<sup id="cite_ref-252" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-252">[251]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>A third of the population resides in <a href="/wiki/Metro_Manila" title="Metro Manila">Metro Manila</a> and its immediately neighboring regions.<sup id="cite_ref-Officialpop_253-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Officialpop-253">[252]</a></sup> The 2.34% average annual population growth rate between 1990 and 2000 decreased to an estimated 1.90% for the 2000–2010 period.<sup id="cite_ref-254" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-254">[253]</a></sup> Government attempts to reduce population growth have been a <a href="/wiki/Reproductive_Health_Bill_(Philippines)" class="mw-redirect" title="Reproductive Health Bill (Philippines)">contentious issue</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-gma_255-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gma-255">[254]</a></sup> The population's median age is 22.7 years with 60.9% aged from 15 to 64 years old.<sup id="cite_ref-CIAfactbook_6-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIAfactbook-6">[6]</a></sup> Life expectancy at birth is 69.4 years, 73.1 years for females and 65.9 years for males.<sup id="cite_ref-worldfactbook1_256-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-worldfactbook1-256">[255]</a></sup> Poverty incidence dropped to 21.6% in 2015 from 25.2% in 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-phpovertyincidence_257-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-phpovertyincidence-257">[256]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Metro Manila is the most populous of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_metropolitan_areas_in_the_Philippines" title="List of metropolitan areas in the Philippines">3 defined metropolitan areas</a> in the Philippines<sup id="cite_ref-258" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-258">[257]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_metropolitan_areas_by_population" class="mw-redirect" title="List of metropolitan areas by population">5th most populous</a> in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-demographia_259-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-demographia-259">[258]</a></sup> Census data from 2015 showed it had a population of 12,877,253 constituting almost 13% of the national population.<sup id="cite_ref-phcensus_260-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-phcensus-260">[259]</a></sup> Including suburbs in the adjacent provinces (<a href="/wiki/Bulacan" title="Bulacan">Bulacan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cavite" title="Cavite">Cavite</a>, <a href="/wiki/Laguna_(province)" title="Laguna (province)">Laguna</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Rizal" title="Rizal">Rizal</a>) of <a href="/wiki/Greater_Manila_Area" title="Greater Manila Area">Greater Manila</a>, the population is around 23,088,000.<sup id="cite_ref-demographia_259-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-demographia-259">[258]</a></sup> Across the country, the Philippines has a total urbanization rate of 51.2 percent.<sup id="cite_ref-phcensus_260-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-phcensus-260">[259]</a></sup> Metro Manila's <a href="/wiki/Gross_regional_product" title="Gross regional product">gross regional product</a> was estimated as of 2009<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Philippines&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> to be <a href="/wiki/Philippine_peso" title="Philippine peso">₱</a>468.4&nbsp;billion (at constant 1985 prices) and accounts for 33% of the nation's GDP.<sup id="cite_ref-NSCB_261-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NSCB-261">[260]</a></sup> In 2011 Manila ranked as the <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_by_GDP" title="List of cities by GDP">28th wealthiest urban agglomeration</a> in the world and the 2nd in Southeast Asia.<sup id="cite_ref-pwc_262-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pwc-262">[261]</a></sup> </p> 
      <table class="navbox"> 
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <th colspan="10" class="navbox-title">
          <div style="float:right; width:6em; height:2.6em">
           &nbsp;

          <div class="navbar plainlinks hlist navbar-mini" style="float: left;height:2.6em;">

           </ul>
          </div> 
          <div style="height:2.6em;line-height:1.3em;">
           <span style="font-size:110%;">Largest <a href="/wiki/Cities_of_the_Philippines#Classification" title="Cities of the Philippines">cities</a> in the Philippines</span>
           <br>
           <div style="display:inline;font-weight:normal;">
            <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.psa.gov.ph/sites/default/files/attachments/hsd/pressrelease/2015%20population%20counts%20Summary_0.xlsx">PSA Census August 2015</a>
           </div>
          </div> </th>
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <th></th> 
         <th><a href="/wiki/List_of_Philippine_cities_and_municipalities_by_population" class="mw-redirect" title="List of Philippine cities and municipalities by population">Rank</a> </th> 
         <th><a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_in_the_Philippines" title="List of cities in the Philippines">Name</a> </th> 
         <th><a href="/wiki/Regions_of_the_Philippines" title="Regions of the Philippines">Region</a> </th> 
         <th><a href="/wiki/List_of_Philippine_cities_and_municipalities_by_population" class="mw-redirect" title="List of Philippine cities and municipalities by population"> Pop.</a> </th> 
         <th><a href="/wiki/List_of_Philippine_cities_and_municipalities_by_population" class="mw-redirect" title="List of Philippine cities and municipalities by population">Rank</a> </th> 
         <th><a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_in_the_Philippines" title="List of cities in the Philippines">Name</a> </th> 
         <th><a href="/wiki/Regions_of_the_Philippines" title="Regions of the Philippines">Region</a> </th> 
         <th><a href="/wiki/List_of_Philippine_cities_and_municipalities_by_population" class="mw-redirect" title="List of Philippine cities and municipalities by population"> Pop.</a></th> 
         <th> </th>
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td rowspan="11" style="text-align: center"><a href="/wiki/File:Eastwood_City,_Libis,_Quezon_City.jpg" class="image" title="Quezon City"><img alt="Quezon City" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Eastwood_City%2C_Libis%2C_Quezon_City.jpg/120px-Eastwood_City%2C_Libis%2C_Quezon_City.jpg" decoding="async" width="120" height="90" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Eastwood_City%2C_Libis%2C_Quezon_City.jpg/180px-Eastwood_City%2C_Libis%2C_Quezon_City.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Eastwood_City%2C_Libis%2C_Quezon_City.jpg/240px-Eastwood_City%2C_Libis%2C_Quezon_City.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4160" data-file-height="3120"></a><br><a href="/wiki/Quezon_City" title="Quezon City">Quezon City</a><br><a href="/wiki/File:Manila_as_seen_from_Intramuros.jpg" class="image" title="Manila"><img alt="Manila" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/Manila_as_seen_from_Intramuros.jpg/120px-Manila_as_seen_from_Intramuros.jpg" decoding="async" width="120" height="80" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/Manila_as_seen_from_Intramuros.jpg/180px-Manila_as_seen_from_Intramuros.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/Manila_as_seen_from_Intramuros.jpg/240px-Manila_as_seen_from_Intramuros.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5170" data-file-height="3447"></a><br><a href="/wiki/Manila" title="Manila">Manila</a> </td> 
         <td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">1</td> 
         <td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Quezon_City" title="Quezon City">Quezon City</a></td> 
         <td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Metro_Manila" title="Metro Manila">National Capital Region</a></td> 
         <td style="text-align:right;">2,936,116</td> 
         <td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">11</td> 
         <td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Para%C3%B1aque" title="Parañaque">Parañaque</a></td> 
         <td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Metro_Manila" title="Metro Manila">National Capital Region</a></td> 
         <td style="text-align:right;">665,822 </td> 
         <td rowspan="11" style="text-align: center"><a href="/wiki/File:Davao_Skyline.jpg" class="image" title="Davao City"><img alt="Davao City" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Davao_Skyline.jpg/120px-Davao_Skyline.jpg" decoding="async" width="120" height="52" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Davao_Skyline.jpg/180px-Davao_Skyline.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Davao_Skyline.jpg/240px-Davao_Skyline.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2048" data-file-height="894"></a><br><a href="/wiki/Davao_City" title="Davao City">Davao City</a><br><a href="/wiki/File:Edsa-caloocan-2010-01.JPG" class="image" title="Caloocan"><img alt="Caloocan" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Edsa-caloocan-2010-01.JPG/120px-Edsa-caloocan-2010-01.JPG" decoding="async" width="120" height="90" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Edsa-caloocan-2010-01.JPG/180px-Edsa-caloocan-2010-01.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Edsa-caloocan-2010-01.JPG/240px-Edsa-caloocan-2010-01.JPG 2x" data-file-width="3264" data-file-height="2448"></a><br><a href="/wiki/Caloocan" title="Caloocan">Caloocan</a> </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr>

      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Ethnic_groups">Ethnic groups</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_groups_in_the_Philippines" title="Ethnic groups in the Philippines">Ethnic groups in the Philippines</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Filipinos" title="Filipinos">Filipinos</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Peoples_of_the_Philippines_en.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Peoples_of_the_Philippines_en.svg/220px-Peoples_of_the_Philippines_en.svg.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="341" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Peoples_of_the_Philippines_en.svg/330px-Peoples_of_the_Philippines_en.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Peoples_of_the_Philippines_en.svg/440px-Peoples_of_the_Philippines_en.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1846" data-file-height="2863"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Peoples_of_the_Philippines_en.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Dominant ethnic groups by province
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>There is substantial ethnic diversity with the Philippines, a product of the seas and mountain ranges dividing the archipelago along with significant foreign influences.<sup id="cite_ref-Banlaoi_263-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Banlaoi-263">[262]</a></sup> According to the 2010 census, 24.4% of Filipinos are Tagalog, 11.4% Visayans/Bisaya <span style="font-size:85%;">(excluding Cebuano, Hiligaynon and Waray)</span>, 9.9% Cebuano, 8.8% Ilocano, 8.4% Hiligaynon, 6.8% Bikol, 4% Waray, and 26.2% are "others",<sup id="cite_ref-CIAfactbook_6-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIAfactbook-6">[6]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-264" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-264">[263]</a></sup> which can be broken down further to yield more distinct non-tribal groups like the <a href="/wiki/Moro_people" title="Moro people">Moro</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Kapampangan_people" title="Kapampangan people">Kapampangan</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Pangasinan_people" title="Pangasinan people">Pangasinense</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Ibanag_people" title="Ibanag people">Ibanag</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Ivatan_people" title="Ivatan people">Ivatan</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-265" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-265">[264]</a></sup> There are also <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_of_the_Philippines" title="Indigenous peoples of the Philippines">indigenous peoples</a> like the <a href="/wiki/Igorot" class="mw-redirect" title="Igorot">Igorot</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Lumad" title="Lumad">Lumad</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Mangyan" title="Mangyan">Mangyan</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Bajau" class="mw-redirect" title="Bajau">Bajau</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Peoples_of_Palawan" title="Peoples of Palawan">tribes of Palawan</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Ethnol_266-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ethnol-266">[265]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Negrito" title="Negrito">Negritos</a> are considered among the earliest inhabitants of the islands.<sup id="cite_ref-Negritos_267-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Negritos-267">[266]</a></sup> These minority aboriginal settlers are an <a href="/wiki/Australoid" class="mw-redirect" title="Australoid">Australoid</a> group and are a left-over from the first human migration out of Africa to Australia, and were likely displaced by later waves of migration.<sup id="cite_ref-268" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-268">[267]</a></sup> At least some Negritos in the Philippines have <a href="/wiki/Denisovan" title="Denisovan">Denisovan</a> admixture in their genomes.<sup id="cite_ref-269" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-269">[268]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-270" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-270">[269]</a></sup> Ethnic Filipinos generally belong to several <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Asians" class="mw-redirect" title="Southeast Asians">Southeast Asian</a> ethnic groups classified linguistically as part of the <a href="/wiki/Austronesian_peoples" title="Austronesian peoples">Austronesian</a> or <a href="/wiki/Malayo-Polynesian_languages" title="Malayo-Polynesian languages">Malayo-Polynesian</a> speaking people.<sup id="cite_ref-Ethnol_266-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ethnol-266">[265]</a></sup> There is some uncertainty over the origin of this Austronesian speaking population, with it being likely that ancestors related to <a href="/wiki/Taiwanese_aborigines" class="mw-redirect" title="Taiwanese aborigines">Taiwanese aborigines</a> brought their language and mixed with existing populations in the area.<sup id="cite_ref-AJHG_271-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AJHG-271">[270]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-272" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-272">[271]</a></sup> European DNA is present in many Filipinos today.<sup id="cite_ref-273" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-273">[272]</a></sup> A <a href="/wiki/Craniometry" title="Craniometry">craniometric</a> study reveals that samples taken from graveyards across the Philippines show a mean ratio of European descent of circa 6%.<sup id="cite_ref-274" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-274">[273]</a></sup> Under Spanish rule there was also immigration from elsewhere in the empire, especially <a href="/wiki/Latin_American_Asian" title="Latin American Asian">from Latin America</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-275" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-275">[274]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Chinese_Filipino" title="Chinese Filipino">Chinese Filipinos</a> are mostly the descendants of immigrants from <a href="/wiki/Fujian" title="Fujian">Fujian</a> in China after 1898,<sup id="cite_ref-276" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-276">[275]</a></sup> numbering around 2&nbsp;million, although there are an estimated 20 percent of Filipinos who have partial Chinese ancestry, stemming from precolonial and colonial Chinese migrants.<sup id="cite_ref-277" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-277">[276]</a></sup> While a distinct minority, Chinese Filipinos are well-integrated into Filipino society.<sup id="cite_ref-Banlaoi_263-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Banlaoi-263">[262]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-278" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-278">[277]</a></sup> As of 2015, there were 220,000 to 600,000 American citizens living in the country.<sup id="cite_ref-279" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-279">[278]</a></sup> There are also up to 250,000 <a href="/wiki/Amerasian" title="Amerasian">Amerasians</a> scattered across the cities of <a href="/wiki/Angeles,_Philippines" title="Angeles, Philippines">Angeles</a>, Manila, <a href="/wiki/New_Clark_City" title="New Clark City">Clark</a> and <a href="/wiki/Olongapo" title="Olongapo">Olongapo</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-280" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-280">[279]</a></sup> Other important non-indigenous minorities include <a href="/wiki/Indian_Filipino" title="Indian Filipino">Indians</a><sup id="cite_ref-281" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-281">[280]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Arab_Filipino" class="mw-redirect" title="Arab Filipino">Arabs</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-282" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-282">[281]</a></sup> There are also <a href="/wiki/Japanese_people" title="Japanese people">Japanese people</a>, which include escaped Christians (<a href="/wiki/Kirishitan" title="Kirishitan">Kirishitan</a>) who <a href="/wiki/Martyrs_of_Japan" title="Martyrs of Japan">fled the persecutions of Shogun Tokugawa Ieyasu</a> which the Spanish empire in the Philippines had offered asylum from.<sup id="cite_ref-283" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-283">[282]</a></sup> The descendants of mixed-race couples are known as <i><a href="/wiki/Filipino_mestizo" title="Filipino mestizo">Tisoy</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-284" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-284">[283]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Languages">Languages</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_the_Philippines" title="Languages of the Philippines">Languages of the Philippines</a>
      </div>
