        <tr class="sortbottom" style="border-top:double gray;"> 
         <th scope="col" style="text-align:left;letter-spacing:0.02em;" colspan="3">TOTAL </th> 
         <th scope="col" style="text-align:right;">92,097,978 </th>
        </tr> 
        <tr class="sortbottom"> 
         <td style="font-style:italic;" colspan="4">Source: <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Statistics_Authority" title="Philippine Statistics Authority">Philippine Statistics Authority</a><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPhilippine_Statistics_Authority201429–34_285-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPhilippine_Statistics_Authority201429–34-285">[284]</a></sup> </td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <p><i><a href="/wiki/Ethnologue" title="Ethnologue">Ethnologue</a></i> lists 186 individual languages in the Philippines, 182 of which are living languages, while 4 no longer have any known speakers. Most native languages are part of the <a href="/wiki/Philippine_languages" title="Philippine languages">Philippine</a> branch of the <a href="/wiki/Malayo-Polynesian_languages" title="Malayo-Polynesian languages">Malayo-Polynesian languages</a>, which is itself a branch of the <a href="/wiki/Austronesian_languages" title="Austronesian languages">Austronesian language family</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Ethnol_266-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ethnol-266">[265]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Dyen1965_286-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dyen1965-286">[285]</a></sup> In addition, various Spanish-based creole varieties collectively called <a href="/wiki/Chavacano" title="Chavacano">Chavacano</a> exist.<sup id="cite_ref-287" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-287">[286]</a></sup> There are also many <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Negrito_languages#Unique_vocabulary" title="Philippine Negrito languages">Philippine Negrito languages</a> that have unique vocabularies that survived Austronesian acculturation.<sup id="cite_ref-288" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-288">[287]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Filipino_language" title="Filipino language">Filipino</a> and <a href="/wiki/Philippine_English" title="Philippine English">English</a> are the official languages of the country.<sup id="cite_ref-OfficialLang_289-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-OfficialLang-289">[288]</a></sup> Filipino is a standardized version of <a href="/wiki/Tagalog_language" title="Tagalog language">Tagalog</a>, spoken mainly in Metro Manila.<sup id="cite_ref-290" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-290">[289]</a></sup> Both Filipino and English are used in government, education, print, broadcast media, and business, with third local languages often being used at the same time.<sup id="cite_ref-BrownGanguly2003_291-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BrownGanguly2003-291">[290]</a></sup> The Philippine constitution provides for the promotion of <a href="/wiki/Spanish_language_in_the_Philippines" title="Spanish language in the Philippines">Spanish</a> and <a href="/wiki/Arabic" title="Arabic">Arabic</a> on a voluntary and optional basis.<sup id="cite_ref-OfficialLang_289-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-OfficialLang-289">[288]</a></sup> Spanish, which was widely used as a lingua franca in the late nineteenth century, has since declined greatly in use,<sup id="cite_ref-Stewart2012_292-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Stewart2012-292">[291]</a></sup> although Spanish loanwords are still present today in Philippine languages,<sup id="cite_ref-293" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-293">[292]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-294" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-294">[293]</a></sup> while Arabic is mainly taught in Islamic schools in Mindanao.<sup id="cite_ref-295" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-295">[294]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Nineteen regional languages act as auxiliary official languages used as media of instruction: <a href="/wiki/Aklan_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Aklan language">Aklanon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bikol_languages" title="Bikol languages">Bikol</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cebuano_language" title="Cebuano language">Cebuano</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chavacano" title="Chavacano">Chavacano</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hiligaynon_language" title="Hiligaynon language">Hiligaynon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ibanag_language" title="Ibanag language">Ibanag</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ilocano_language" title="Ilocano language">Ilocano</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ivatan_language" title="Ivatan language">Ivatan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kapampangan_language" title="Kapampangan language">Kapampangan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kinaray-a_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Kinaray-a language">Kinaray-a</a>, <a href="/wiki/Maguindanao_language" title="Maguindanao language">Maguindanao</a>, <a href="/wiki/Maranao_language" title="Maranao language">Maranao</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pangasinan_language" title="Pangasinan language">Pangasinan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sambal_language" title="Sambal language">Sambal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Surigaonon_language" title="Surigaonon language">Surigaonon</a>, Tagalog, <a href="/wiki/Tausug_language" title="Tausug language">Tausug</a>, <a href="/wiki/Waray_language" title="Waray language">Waray</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Yakan_language" title="Yakan language">Yakan</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-7_mother_languages_2-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7_mother_languages-2">[2]</a></sup> Other indigenous languages such as, <a href="/wiki/Cuyonon_language" title="Cuyonon language">Cuyonon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ifugao_language" title="Ifugao language">Ifugao</a>, <a href="/wiki/Itbayat_language" title="Itbayat language">Itbayat</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kalinga_language" title="Kalinga language">Kalinga</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kamayo_language" title="Kamayo language">Kamayo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kankanaey_language" title="Kankanaey language">Kankanaey</a>, <a href="/wiki/Masbate%C3%B1o_language" title="Masbateño language">Masbateño</a>, <a href="/wiki/Romblomanon_language" title="Romblomanon language">Romblomanon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Manobo_languages" title="Manobo languages">Manobo</a>, and several <a href="/wiki/Visayan_languages" class="mw-redirect" title="Visayan languages">Visayan languages</a> are prevalent in their respective provinces.<sup id="cite_ref-ethn_296-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ethn-296">[295]</a></sup> Article 3 of Republic Act No. 11106 declared the <a href="/wiki/Filipino_Sign_Language" title="Filipino Sign Language">Filipino Sign Language</a> as the national sign language of the Philippines, specifying that it shall be recognized, supported and promoted as the medium of official communication in all transactions involving the deaf, and as the language of instruction of deaf education.<sup id="cite_ref-297" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-297">[296]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-298" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-298">[297]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">Religion</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_the_Philippines" title="Religion in the Philippines">Religion in the Philippines</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:St._Agustine_Paoay_Church_02.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/St._Agustine_Paoay_Church_02.jpg/220px-St._Agustine_Paoay_Church_02.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/St._Agustine_Paoay_Church_02.jpg/330px-St._Agustine_Paoay_Church_02.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/St._Agustine_Paoay_Church_02.jpg/440px-St._Agustine_Paoay_Church_02.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2592" data-file-height="1944"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:St._Agustine_Paoay_Church_02.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The historical <a href="/wiki/Paoay_Church" title="Paoay Church">Paoay Church</a> in Ilocos Norte. Declared as a National Cultural Treasure by the Philippine government in 1973 and a <a href="/wiki/UNESCO_World_Heritage_Site" class="mw-redirect" title="UNESCO World Heritage Site">UNESCO World Heritage Site</a> under the collective group of <a href="/wiki/Baroque_Churches_of_the_Philippines" title="Baroque Churches of the Philippines">Baroque Churches of the Philippines</a> in 1993.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The Philippines is a <a href="/wiki/Secular_state" title="Secular state">secular state</a> which protects <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_religion_in_the_Philippines" title="Freedom of religion in the Philippines">freedom of religion</a>. <a href="/wiki/Christianity_in_the_Philippines" title="Christianity in the Philippines">Christianity</a> is the dominant faith,<sup id="cite_ref-2013ReportonInternationalReligiousFreedom_299-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2013ReportonInternationalReligiousFreedom-299">[298]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ReligiousFreedomon2014_300-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ReligiousFreedomon2014-300">[299]</a></sup> shared by over 92% of the population.<sup id="cite_ref-pew_301-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pew-301">[300]</a></sup> As of 2013<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Philippines&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, the country had the <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_by_country" title="Catholic Church by country">world's third largest Roman Catholic population</a>, and was the <a href="/wiki/Christianity_in_Asia" title="Christianity in Asia">largest Christian nation in Asia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-302" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-302">[301]</a></sup> Census data from 2015 found that about 79.53% of the population professed <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_in_the_Philippines" title="Catholic Church in the Philippines">Catholicism</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-2015census_303-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2015census-303">[302]</a></sup> Around 37% of the population regularly attend <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Mass" class="mw-redirect" title="Catholic Mass">Mass</a>. 29% of self-identified Catholics consider themselves very religious.<sup id="cite_ref-newsinfo.inquirer.net_304-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-newsinfo.inquirer.net-304">[303]</a></sup> An <a href="/wiki/Independent_Catholic_churches" class="mw-redirect" title="Independent Catholic churches">independent Catholic</a> church, the <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Independent_Church" title="Philippine Independent Church">Philippine Independent Church</a>, has around 66,959 adherents.<sup id="cite_ref-2015census_303-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2015census-303">[302]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Protestantism_in_the_Philippines" title="Protestantism in the Philippines">Protestants</a> were 10.8% of the population in 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-305" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-305">[304]</a></sup> 2.64% of the population are members of <a href="/wiki/Iglesia_ni_Cristo" title="Iglesia ni Cristo">Iglesia ni Cristo</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-2015census_303-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2015census-303">[302]</a></sup> The combined following of the <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Council_of_Evangelical_Churches" title="Philippine Council of Evangelical Churches">Philippine Council of Evangelical Churches</a> comes to 2.42% of the total population.<sup id="cite_ref-2015census_303-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2015census-303">[302]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-306" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-306">[305]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Islam_in_the_Philippines" title="Islam in the Philippines">Islam</a> is the second largest religion. The <a href="/wiki/Muslim" class="mw-redirect" title="Muslim">Muslim</a> population of the Philippines was reported as 6.01% of the total population according to census returns in 2015.<sup id="cite_ref-2015census_303-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2015census-303">[302]</a></sup> Conversely, a 2012 report by the National Commission of Muslim Filipinos (NCMF) stated that about 10,700,000 or 11% of Filipinos are Muslims.<sup id="cite_ref-2013ReportonInternationalReligiousFreedom_299-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2013ReportonInternationalReligiousFreedom-299">[298]</a></sup> The majority of Muslims live in Mindanao and nearby islands.<sup id="cite_ref-ReligiousFreedomon2014_300-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ReligiousFreedomon2014-300">[299]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-307" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-307">[306]</a></sup> Most practice <a href="/wiki/Sunni_Islam" title="Sunni Islam">Sunni Islam</a> under the <a href="/wiki/Shafi%27i_school" class="mw-redirect" title="Shafi'i school">Shafi'i school</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-308" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-308">[307]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-309" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-309">[308]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The percentage of combined <a href="/wiki/Positive_atheism" class="mw-redirect" title="Positive atheism">positive atheist</a> and <a href="/wiki/Agnostic" class="mw-redirect" title="Agnostic">agnostic</a> people in the Philippines was measured to be about 3% of the population as of 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-310" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-310">[309]</a></sup> The 2015 Philippine Census reported the religion of about 0.02% of the population as "none".<sup id="cite_ref-2015census_303-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2015census-303">[302]</a></sup> A 2014 survey by <a href="/wiki/Gallup_International_Association" title="Gallup International Association">Gallup International Association</a> reported that 21% of its respondents identify as "not a religious person".<sup id="cite_ref-311" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-311">[310]</a></sup> Around 0.24% of the population practice <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_Philippine_folk_religions" title="Indigenous Philippine folk religions">indigenous Philippine folk religions</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-2015census_303-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2015census-303">[302]</a></sup> whose practices and folk beliefs are often syncretized with Christianity and Islam.<sup id="cite_ref-312" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-312">[311]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-313" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-313">[312]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_the_Philippines" title="Buddhism in the Philippines">Buddhism</a> is practiced by around 0.03% of the population,<sup id="cite_ref-2015census_303-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2015census-303">[302]</a></sup> concentrated among Filipinos of Chinese descent.<sup id="cite_ref-314" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-314">[313]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Health">Health</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Health_in_the_Philippines" title="Health in the Philippines">Health in the Philippines</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Saint_Luke%27s_Global_City_(BGC,_Taguig)(2018-06-04).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/Saint_Luke%27s_Global_City_%28BGC%2C_Taguig%29%282018-06-04%29.jpg/220px-Saint_Luke%27s_Global_City_%28BGC%2C_Taguig%29%282018-06-04%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="124" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/Saint_Luke%27s_Global_City_%28BGC%2C_Taguig%29%282018-06-04%29.jpg/330px-Saint_Luke%27s_Global_City_%28BGC%2C_Taguig%29%282018-06-04%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/Saint_Luke%27s_Global_City_%28BGC%2C_Taguig%29%282018-06-04%29.jpg/440px-Saint_Luke%27s_Global_City_%28BGC%2C_Taguig%29%282018-06-04%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4608" data-file-height="2592"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Saint_Luke%27s_Global_City_(BGC,_Taguig)(2018-06-04).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/St._Luke%27s_Medical_Center_%E2%80%93_Global_City" title="St. Luke's Medical Center – Global City">St. Luke's Medical Center – Global City</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In 2016, 63.1% of healthcare came from private expenditures while 36.9% was from the government (12.4% from the national government, 7.1% from the local government, and 17.4% from social health insurance).<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDepartment_of_Health2018Chapter_2_(pages_25-27)_315-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDepartment_of_Health2018Chapter_2_(pages_25-27)-315">[314]</a></sup> Total health expenditure share in GDP for the year 2016 was 4.5%. Per capita health expenditure rate in 2015 was <span style="white-space: nowrap"><a href="/wiki/United_States_dollar" title="United States dollar">US$</a>323</span>, which was one of the lowest in Southeast Asia.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDepartment_of_Health2018Chapter_2_(page_23)_316-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDepartment_of_Health2018Chapter_2_(page_23)-316">[315]</a></sup> The budget allocation for Healthcare in 2019 was ₱98.6&nbsp;billion<sup id="cite_ref-317" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-317">[316]</a></sup> and had an increase in budget in 2014 with a record high in the collection of taxes from the House Bill 5727 (commonly known as <a href="/wiki/Sin_tax" title="Sin tax">Sin tax</a> Bill).<sup id="cite_ref-318" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-318">[317]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>There were 101,688 hospital beds in the country in 2016, with government hospital beds accounting for 47% and private hospital beds for 53%.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDepartment_of_Health2018Chapter_3_(page_60)_319-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDepartment_of_Health2018Chapter_3_(page_60)-319">[318]</a></sup> In 2009, there were an estimated 90,370 physicians or 1 per every 833 people, 480,910 nurses and 43,220 dentists.<sup id="cite_ref-WHOStats2009_320-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WHOStats2009-320">[319]</a></sup> Retention of skilled practitioners is a problem. Seventy percent of nursing graduates go overseas to work. As of 2007<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Philippines&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, the Philippines was the largest supplier of nurses for export.<sup id="cite_ref-321" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-321">[320]</a></sup> The Philippines suffers a triple burden of high levels of communicable diseases, high levels of non-communicable diseases, and high exposure to natural disasters.<sup id="cite_ref-322" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-322">[321]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 2018, there were 1,258 <a href="/wiki/Hospital" title="Hospital">hospitals</a> licensed by the <a href="/wiki/Department_of_Health_(Philippines)" title="Department of Health (Philippines)">Department of Health</a>, of which 433&nbsp;(<span data-sort-value="7001344197138314785♠" style="display:none"></span>34%) were government-run and 825&nbsp;(<span data-sort-value="7001655802861685214♠" style="display:none"></span>66%) private.<sup id="cite_ref-323" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-323">[322]</a></sup> A total of 20,065 barangay health stations (BHS) and 2,590 rural health units (RHUs) provide primary care services throughout the country as of 2016.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDepartment_of_Health2018Chapter_3_(page_58)_324-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDepartment_of_Health2018Chapter_3_(page_58)-324">[323]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Cardiovascular_diseases" class="mw-redirect" title="Cardiovascular diseases">Cardiovascular diseases</a> account for more than 35% of all deaths.<sup id="cite_ref-325" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-325">[324]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-326" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-326">[325]</a></sup> 9,264 cases of <a href="/wiki/Human_immunodeficiency_virus" class="mw-redirect" title="Human immunodeficiency virus">human immunodeficiency virus</a> (HIV) were reported for the year 2016, with 8,151 being asymptomatic cases.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDepartment_of_Health2018Table_3.2_(page_47)_327-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDepartment_of_Health2018Table_3.2_(page_47)-327">[326]</a></sup> At the time the country was considered a low-HIV-prevalence country, with less than 0.1% of the adult population estimated to be HIV-positive.<sup id="cite_ref-328" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-328">[327]</a></sup> HIV/AIDS cases increased from 12,000 in 2005<sup id="cite_ref-usaidhealth_329-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-usaidhealth-329">[328]</a></sup> to 39,622 as of 2016, with 35,957 being asymptomatic cases.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDepartment_of_Health2018Table_3.2_(page_47)_327-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDepartment_of_Health2018Table_3.2_(page_47)-327">[326]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>There is improvement in patients access to medicines due to Filipinos' growing acceptance of <a href="/wiki/Generic_drug" title="Generic drug">generic drugs</a>, with 6 out of 10 Filipinos already using generics.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDepartment_of_Health2018Table_3_(page_58)_330-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDepartment_of_Health2018Table_3_(page_58)-330">[329]</a></sup> While the country's <a href="/wiki/Universal_healthcare" class="mw-redirect" title="Universal healthcare">universal healthcare</a> implementation is underway as spearheaded by the state-owned <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Health_Insurance_Corporation" title="Philippine Health Insurance Corporation">Philippine Health Insurance Corporation</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-331" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-331">[330]</a></sup> most healthcare-related expenses are either borne out of pocket<sup id="cite_ref-332" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-332">[331]</a></sup> or through health maintenance organization (HMO)-provided health plans. As of April 2020, there are only about 7&nbsp;million individuals covered by these plans.<sup id="cite_ref-333" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-333">[332]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_the_Philippines" title="Education in the Philippines">Education in the Philippines</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:UST_Main_Building.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/UST_Main_Building.jpg/220px-UST_Main_Building.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="141" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/UST_Main_Building.jpg/330px-UST_Main_Building.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/UST_Main_Building.jpg/440px-UST_Main_Building.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3763" data-file-height="2408"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:UST_Main_Building.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Founded in 1611, the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Santo_Tomas" title="University of Santo Tomas">University of Santo Tomas</a> is the oldest extant university in Asia.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The Philippines had a simple <a href="/wiki/Literacy" title="Literacy">literacy</a> rate of 98.3% as of 2015, and a <a href="/wiki/Functional_illiteracy" title="Functional illiteracy">functional literacy</a> rate of 90.3% as of 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-NQ-June2020_334-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NQ-June2020-334">[333]</a></sup> Education takes up a significant proportion of the national budget. In the 2020 budget, education was allocated PHP17.1&nbsp;billion from the PHP4.1&nbsp;trillion budget.<sup id="cite_ref-335" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-335">[334]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Commission_on_Higher_Education_(Philippines)" title="Commission on Higher Education (Philippines)">Commission on Higher Education</a> (CHED) lists 2,180 higher education institutions, among which 607 are public and 1,573 are private.<sup id="cite_ref-CHED_336-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CHED-336">[335]</a></sup> Classes start in June and end in March. The majority of colleges and universities follow a semester calendar from June to October and November to March, while some have adopted an increasingly common semester calendar from August to December and January to May.<sup id="cite_ref-About_192-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-About-192">[191]</a></sup> Primary and secondary schooling is divided between a 6-year elementary period, a 4-year junior high school period, and a 2-year senior high school period.<sup id="cite_ref-337" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-337">[336]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-338" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-338">[337]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-339" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-339">[338]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Department_of_Education_(Philippines)" title="Department of Education (Philippines)">Department of Education</a> (DepEd) covers elementary, secondary, and non-formal education.<sup id="cite_ref-340" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-340">[339]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Technical_Education_and_Skills_Development_Authority" title="Technical Education and Skills Development Authority">Technical Education and Skills Development Authority</a> (TESDA) administers middle-level education training and development.<sup id="cite_ref-341" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-341">[340]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-342" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-342">[341]</a></sup> The Commission on Higher Education (CHED) was created in 1994 to, among other functions, formulate and recommend development plans, policies, priorities, and programs on <a href="/wiki/Higher_education_in_the_Philippines" title="Higher education in the Philippines">higher education</a> and research.<sup id="cite_ref-343" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-343">[342]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 2004, <a href="/wiki/Madrasa" title="Madrasa">madaris</a> were mainstreamed in 16 regions nationwide, mainly in Muslim areas in Mindanao under the auspices and program of the Department of Education.<sup id="cite_ref-madrasa_344-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-madrasa-344">[343]</a></sup> Public universities are all non-sectarian entities, and are further classified as State Universities and Colleges (SUC) or Local Colleges and Universities (LCU).<sup id="cite_ref-CHED_336-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CHED-336">[335]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/University_of_the_Philippines" title="University of the Philippines">University of the Philippines</a>, a system of eight (8) constituent universities, is the <a href="/wiki/National_university" title="National university">national university</a> system of the Philippines.<sup id="cite_ref-Charter_345-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Charter-345">[344]</a></sup> The country's top ranked universities are as follows: University of the Philippines, <a href="/wiki/Ateneo_de_Manila_University" title="Ateneo de Manila University">Ateneo de Manila University</a>, <a href="/wiki/De_La_Salle_University" title="De La Salle University">De La Salle University</a>, and <a href="/wiki/University_of_Santo_Tomas" title="University of Santo Tomas">University of Santo Tomas</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-346" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-346">[345]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-347" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-347">[346]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-348" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-348">[347]</a></sup> The University of Santo Tomas, established in 1611, has the oldest <a href="/wiki/Extant_literature" title="Extant literature">extant</a> university charter in the Philippines and Asia.<sup id="cite_ref-349" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-349">[348]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-350" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-350">[349]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Government_and_politics">Government and politics</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_the_Philippines" title="Politics of the Philippines">Politics of the Philippines</a> and <a href="/wiki/Government_of_the_Philippines" title="Government of the Philippines">Government of the Philippines</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Malaca%C3%B1ang_Palace_(Cropped).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/Malaca%C3%B1ang_Palace_%28Cropped%29.jpg/220px-Malaca%C3%B1ang_Palace_%28Cropped%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="124" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/Malaca%C3%B1ang_Palace_%28Cropped%29.jpg/330px-Malaca%C3%B1ang_Palace_%28Cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/Malaca%C3%B1ang_Palace_%28Cropped%29.jpg/440px-Malaca%C3%B1ang_Palace_%28Cropped%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1650" data-file-height="928"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Malaca%C3%B1ang_Palace_(Cropped).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Malaca%C3%B1ang_Palace" title="Malacañang Palace">Malacañang Palace</a> is the official residence of the <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_Philippines" title="President of the Philippines">President of the Philippines</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The Philippines has a <a href="/wiki/Democracy" title="Democracy">democratic</a> government in the form of a <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_republic" class="mw-redirect" title="Constitutional republic">constitutional republic</a> with a <a href="/wiki/Presidential_system" title="Presidential system">presidential system</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Rose-Ackerman_351-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rose-Ackerman-351">[350]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_Philippines" title="President of the Philippines">President</a> functions as both <a href="/wiki/Head_of_state" title="Head of state">head of state</a> and <a href="/wiki/Head_of_government" title="Head of government">head of government</a><sup id="cite_ref-Banlaoi_263-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Banlaoi-263">[262]</a></sup> and is the <a href="/wiki/Commander-in-chief" title="Commander-in-chief">commander-in-chief</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Armed_Forces_of_the_Philippines" title="Armed Forces of the Philippines">armed forces</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Rose-Ackerman_351-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rose-Ackerman-351">[350]</a></sup> The president is elected by popular vote for a single six-year term,<sup id="cite_ref-TeehankeeThompson_352-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TeehankeeThompson-352">[351]</a></sup> during which he or she appoints and presides over the <a href="/wiki/Cabinet_(government)" title="Cabinet (government)">cabinet</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Lazo_353-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lazo-353">[352]</a></sup><sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">:<span>213–214</span></sup> <a href="/wiki/Rodrigo_Duterte" title="Rodrigo Duterte">Rodrigo Duterte</a> was elected to a six-year term as president in 2016.<sup id="cite_ref-2016_election_170-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2016_election-170">[169]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Bicameral" class="mw-redirect" title="Bicameral">bicameral</a> <a href="/wiki/Congress_of_the_Philippines" title="Congress of the Philippines">Congress</a> is composed of the <a href="/wiki/Senate_of_the_Philippines" title="Senate of the Philippines">Senate</a>, serving as the <a href="/wiki/Upper_house" title="Upper house">upper house</a>, with members elected to a six-year term, and the <a href="/wiki/House_of_Representatives_of_the_Philippines" title="House of Representatives of the Philippines">House of Representatives</a>, serving as the <a href="/wiki/Lower_house" title="Lower house">lower house</a>, with members elected to a three-year term.<sup id="cite_ref-Carter2010_354-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Carter2010-354">[353]</a></sup> Philippine politics tends to be dominated by those with well-known names, such as members of <a href="/wiki/List_of_political_families_in_the_Philippines" title="List of political families in the Philippines">political dynasties</a> or celebrities.<sup id="cite_ref-Celebrity_355-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Celebrity-355">[354]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-David_356-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-David-356">[355]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Senators are elected at large<sup id="cite_ref-Carter2010_354-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Carter2010-354">[353]</a></sup> while the representatives are elected from both <a href="/wiki/Legislative_districts_of_the_Philippines" title="Legislative districts of the Philippines">legislative districts</a> and through sectoral representation.<sup id="cite_ref-Lazo_353-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lazo-353">[352]</a></sup><sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">:<span>162–163</span></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Judiciary" title="Judiciary">judicial</a> power is vested in the <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_the_Philippines" title="Supreme Court of the Philippines">Supreme Court</a>, composed of a <a href="/wiki/Chief_Justice_of_the_Supreme_Court_of_the_Philippines" class="mw-redirect" title="Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of the Philippines">Chief Justice</a> as its presiding officer and fourteen <a href="/wiki/Associate_Justice_of_the_Supreme_Court_of_the_Philippines" class="mw-redirect" title="Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the Philippines">associate justices</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Pangalangan_357-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pangalangan-357">[356]</a></sup> all of whom are appointed by the President from nominations submitted by the <a href="/wiki/Judicial_and_Bar_Council" title="Judicial and Bar Council">Judicial and Bar Council</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Rose-Ackerman_351-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rose-Ackerman-351">[350]</a></sup> The capital city of the Philippines is <a href="/wiki/Manila" title="Manila">Manila</a> and the most populous city is <a href="/wiki/Quezon_City" title="Quezon City">Quezon City</a>, both within the single urban area of <a href="/wiki/Metro_Manila" title="Metro Manila">Metro Manila</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-358" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-358">[357]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>There have been <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_reform_in_the_Philippines" title="Constitutional reform in the Philippines">attempts to change</a> the government to a <a href="/wiki/Federal_government" class="mw-redirect" title="Federal government">federal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Unicameral" class="mw-redirect" title="Unicameral">unicameral</a>, or <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_government" class="mw-redirect" title="Parliamentary government">parliamentary government</a> since the Ramos administration.<sup id="cite_ref-359" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-359">[358]</a></sup> There is a significant amount of <a href="/wiki/Corruption_in_the_Philippines" title="Corruption in the Philippines">corruption in the Philippines</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-360" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-360">[359]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-361" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-361">[360]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-362" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-362">[361]</a></sup> which some historians attribute to the system of governance put in place during the Spanish colonial period.<sup id="cite_ref-363" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-363">[362]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_relations">Foreign relations</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_the_Philippines" title="Foreign relations of the Philippines">Foreign relations of the Philippines</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Donald_Trump_and_Rodrigo_Duterte_in_Manila_(6).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Donald_Trump_and_Rodrigo_Duterte_in_Manila_%286%29.jpg/220px-Donald_Trump_and_Rodrigo_Duterte_in_Manila_%286%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Donald_Trump_and_Rodrigo_Duterte_in_Manila_%286%29.jpg/330px-Donald_Trump_and_Rodrigo_Duterte_in_Manila_%286%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Donald_Trump_and_Rodrigo_Duterte_in_Manila_%286%29.jpg/440px-Donald_Trump_and_Rodrigo_Duterte_in_Manila_%286%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1350" data-file-height="900"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Donald_Trump_and_Rodrigo_Duterte_in_Manila_(6).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Rodrigo_Duterte" title="Rodrigo Duterte">President Rodrigo Duterte</a> and U.S. President <a href="/wiki/Donald_Trump" title="Donald Trump">Donald Trump</a> discuss matters during a bilateral meeting in November 2017.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>As a <a href="/wiki/Philippines_and_the_United_Nations" title="Philippines and the United Nations">founding and active member</a> of the United Nations,<sup id="cite_ref-364" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-364">[363]</a></sup> the country <a href="/wiki/List_of_members_of_the_United_Nations_Security_Council" title="List of members of the United Nations Security Council">has been elected</a> to the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council" title="United Nations Security Council">Security Council</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-365" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-365">[364]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Carlos_P._Romulo" title="Carlos P. Romulo">Carlos P. Romulo</a> was a former President of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_General_Assembly" title="United Nations General Assembly">United Nations General Assembly</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-366" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-366">[365]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-367" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-367">[366]</a></sup> The country is an active participant in <a href="/wiki/Peacekeeping" title="Peacekeeping">peacekeeping</a> missions, particularly in <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Transitional_Administration_in_East_Timor" title="United Nations Transitional Administration in East Timor">East Timor</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-368" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-368">[367]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-369" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-369">[368]</a></sup> Over 10&nbsp;million Filipinos live and work overseas.<sup id="cite_ref-poea_370-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-poea-370">[369]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-CFO2013_371-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CFO2013-371">[370]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The Philippines is a founding and active member of <a href="/wiki/ASEAN" title="ASEAN">ASEAN</a> (Association of Southeast Asian Nations).<sup id="cite_ref-summit_372-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-summit-372">[371]</a></sup> It has hosted several <a href="/wiki/ASEAN_summit" class="mw-redirect" title="ASEAN summit">summits</a> and is an active contributor to the direction and policies of the bloc.<sup id="cite_ref-373" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-373">[372]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-374" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-374">[373]</a></sup> It is also a member of the <a href="/wiki/East_Asia_Summit" title="East Asia Summit">East Asia Summit</a> (EAS),<sup id="cite_ref-375" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-375">[374]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Asia-Pacific_Economic_Cooperation" title="Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation">Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation</a> (APEC), the <a href="/wiki/Group_of_24" title="Group of 24">Group of 24</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Non-Aligned_Movement" title="Non-Aligned Movement">Non-Aligned Movement</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-About_192-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-About-192">[191]</a></sup> The country is also seeking to obtain observer status in the <a href="/wiki/Organisation_of_Islamic_Cooperation" title="Organisation of Islamic Cooperation">Organisation of Islamic Cooperation</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-376" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-376">[375]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-377" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-377">[376]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The Philippines has a long <a href="/wiki/Philippines%E2%80%93United_States_relations" title="Philippines–United States relations">relationship with the United States</a>, covering economics, security, and people-to-people relations.<sup id="cite_ref-PhilState_378-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PhilState-378">[377]</a></sup> A <a href="/wiki/Mutual_Defense_Treaty_(U.S.%E2%80%93Philippines)" class="mw-redirect" title="Mutual Defense Treaty (U.S.–Philippines)">mutual defense treaty between the two countries</a> was signed in 1951, and supplemented later with the <a href="/wiki/Philippines%E2%80%93United_States_Visiting_Forces_Agreement" title="Philippines–United States Visiting Forces Agreement">1999 Visiting Forces Agreement</a> and the 2016 <a href="/wiki/Enhanced_Defense_Cooperation_Agreement" title="Enhanced Defense Cooperation Agreement">Enhanced Defense Cooperation Agreement</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-379" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-379">[378]</a></sup> The Philippines supported American policies during the <a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">Cold War</a> and participated in the <a href="/wiki/Korean_War" title="Korean War">Korean</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_War" title="Vietnam War">Vietnam</a> wars.<sup id="cite_ref-380" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-380">[379]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-381" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-381">[380]</a></sup> In 2003 the Philippines was designated a <a href="/wiki/Major_non-NATO_ally" title="Major non-NATO ally">Major non-NATO ally</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-382" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-382">[381]</a></sup> Under President Duterte ties with the United States have weakened<sup id="cite_ref-383" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-383">[382]</a></sup> with military purchases instead coming from China and Russia,<sup id="cite_ref-384" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-384">[383]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-385" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-385">[384]</a></sup> while Duterte states that the Philippines will no longer participate in any US-led wars.<sup id="cite_ref-386" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-386">[385]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The Philippines attaches great importance in its <a href="/wiki/China%E2%80%93Philippines_relations" title="China–Philippines relations">relations with China</a>, and has established significant cooperation with the country.<sup id="cite_ref-387" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-387">[386]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-388" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-388">[387]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-389" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-389">[388]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-390" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-390">[389]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-391" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-391">[390]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-392" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-392">[391]</a></sup> Japan is the biggest bilateral contributor of <a href="/wiki/Official_development_assistance" title="Official development assistance">official development assistance</a> to the country.<sup id="cite_ref-393" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-393">[392]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-394" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-394">[393]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-395" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-395">[394]</a></sup> Although historical tensions exist due to the events of World War II, much of the animosity has faded.<sup id="cite_ref-neighbors_396-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-neighbors-396">[395]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Historical and cultural ties continue to affect relations with Spain.<sup id="cite_ref-397" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-397">[396]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-398" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-398">[397]</a></sup> Relations with <a href="/wiki/Middle_East" title="Middle East">Middle Eastern</a> countries are shaped by the high number of Filipinos working in these countries,<sup id="cite_ref-399" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-399">[398]</a></sup> and by issues relating the Muslim minority in the Philippines.<sup id="cite_ref-400" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-400">[399]</a></sup> Concerns have been raised regarding issues such as <a href="/wiki/Domestic_abuse" class="mw-redirect" title="Domestic abuse">domestic abuse</a> and war affecting<sup id="cite_ref-401" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-401">[400]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-bulatlat_402-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bulatlat-402">[401]</a></sup> the around 2.5&nbsp;million overseas Filipino workers in the region.<sup id="cite_ref-403" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-403">[402]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The Philippines <a href="/wiki/Spratly_Islands_dispute" title="Spratly Islands dispute">has claims</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Spratly_Islands" title="Spratly Islands">Spratly Islands</a> which overlap with claims by China, Malaysia, Taiwan, and Vietnam. The largest of its controlled islands in <a href="/wiki/Thitu_Island" title="Thitu Island">Thitu Island</a>, which contains the Philippine's smallest village.<sup id="cite_ref-Pitlo_404-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pitlo-404">[403]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-405" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-405">[404]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Scarborough_Shoal" title="Scarborough Shoal">Scarborough Shoal</a> <a href="/wiki/Scarborough_Shoal_standoff" title="Scarborough Shoal standoff">standoff in 2012</a>, where China took control of the shoal from the Philippines, led to an <a href="/wiki/Philippines_v._China" title="Philippines v. China">international arbitration case</a><sup id="cite_ref-406" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-406">[405]</a></sup> and has made the shoal a prominent symbol in the wider dispute.<sup id="cite_ref-407" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-407">[406]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Military">Military</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Armed_Forces_of_the_Philippines" title="Armed Forces of the Philippines">Armed Forces of the Philippines</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:BRP_Jose_Rizal_at_RIMPAC_2020_005.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/BRP_Jose_Rizal_at_RIMPAC_2020_005.jpg/220px-BRP_Jose_Rizal_at_RIMPAC_2020_005.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="157" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/BRP_Jose_Rizal_at_RIMPAC_2020_005.jpg/330px-BRP_Jose_Rizal_at_RIMPAC_2020_005.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/BRP_Jose_Rizal_at_RIMPAC_2020_005.jpg/440px-BRP_Jose_Rizal_at_RIMPAC_2020_005.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5145" data-file-height="3675"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:BRP_Jose_Rizal_at_RIMPAC_2020_005.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/BRP_Jose_Rizal_(FF-150)" title="BRP Jose Rizal (FF-150)">BRP Jose Rizal (FF-150)</a> is the <a href="/wiki/Lead_ship" title="Lead ship">lead ship</a> of <a href="/wiki/Jose_Rizal-class_frigate" title="Jose Rizal-class frigate">her class</a> of <a href="/wiki/Guided_missile_frigate" class="mw-redirect" title="Guided missile frigate">guided missile frigates</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Navy" title="Philippine Navy">Philippine Navy</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The Armed Forces of the Philippines (AFP) consist of three branches: the <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Air_Force" title="Philippine Air Force">Philippine Air Force</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Army" title="Philippine Army">Philippine Army</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Navy" title="Philippine Navy">Philippine Navy</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-afporg_408-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-afporg-408">[407]</a></sup> The Armed Forces of the Philippines are a <a href="/wiki/Volunteer_military" title="Volunteer military">volunteer force</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-409" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-409">[408]</a></sup> Civilian security is handled by the <a href="/wiki/Philippine_National_Police" title="Philippine National Police">Philippine National Police</a> under the <a href="/wiki/Department_of_the_Interior_and_Local_Government" title="Department of the Interior and Local Government">Department of the Interior and Local Government</a> (DILG).<sup id="cite_ref-410" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-410">[409]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-RA6975_411-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RA6975-411">[410]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In Bangsamoro, the largest separatist organizations, the <a href="/wiki/Moro_National_Liberation_Front" title="Moro National Liberation Front">Moro National Liberation Front</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Moro_Islamic_Liberation_Front" title="Moro Islamic Liberation Front">Moro Islamic Liberation Front</a> were engaging the government politically as of 2007<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Philippines&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>.<sup id="cite_ref-412" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-412">[411]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers"><span title="The date of the event predicted near this tag has passed. (November 2020)">needs update</span></a></i>]</sup> Other more militant groups like the <a href="/wiki/Abu_Sayyaf" title="Abu Sayyaf">Abu Sayyaf</a> have kidnapped foreigners for ransom, particularly in the Sulu Archipelago.<sup id="cite_ref-414" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-414">[413]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-415" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-415">[414]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-416" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-416">[415]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-417" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-417">[416]</a></sup> Their presence decreased due to successful security provided by the Philippine government.<sup id="cite_ref-418" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-418">[417]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-419" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-419">[418]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_of_the_Philippines" title="Communist Party of the Philippines">Communist Party of the Philippines</a> and its military wing, the <a href="/wiki/New_People%27s_Army" title="New People's Army">New People's Army</a>, have been waging <a href="/wiki/Communist_rebellion_in_the_Philippines" title="Communist rebellion in the Philippines">guerrilla warfare</a> against the government since the 1970s, reaching its apex in 1986 when Communist guerrillas gained control of a fifth of the country's territory, before significantly dwindling militarily and politically after the return of democracy in 1986.<sup id="cite_ref-420" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-420">[419]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-421" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-421">[420]</a></sup> As of 2018<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Philippines&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, $2.843&nbsp;billion,<sup id="cite_ref-422" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-422">[421]</a></sup> or 1.1 percent of GDP is spent on military forces.<sup id="cite_ref-423" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-423">[422]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Administrative_divisions">Administrative divisions</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Administrative_divisions_of_the_Philippines" title="Administrative divisions of the Philippines">Administrative divisions of the Philippines</a>
      </div> 
      <p>The Philippines is governed as a <a href="/wiki/Unitary_state" title="Unitary state">unitary state</a>, with the exception of the <a href="/wiki/Bangsamoro" title="Bangsamoro">Bangsamoro</a> Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao (BARMM),<sup id="cite_ref-424" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-424">[423]</a></sup> although there has been several steps towards decentralization within the unitary framework.<sup id="cite_ref-425" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-425">[424]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-426" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-426">[425]</a></sup> A 1991 law devolved some powers to <a href="/wiki/Local_government_in_the_Philippines" title="Local government in the Philippines">local governments</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Atienza_427-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Atienza-427">[426]</a></sup> The country is divided into 17 <a href="/wiki/Regions_of_the_Philippines" title="Regions of the Philippines">regions</a>, 81 <a href="/wiki/Provinces_of_the_Philippines" title="Provinces of the Philippines">provinces</a>, 146 <a href="/wiki/Cities_of_the_Philippines" title="Cities of the Philippines">cities</a>, 1,488 <a href="/wiki/Municipalities_of_the_Philippines" title="Municipalities of the Philippines">municipalities</a>, and 42,036 <a href="/wiki/Barangays" class="mw-redirect" title="Barangays">barangays</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-428" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-428">[427]</a></sup> Regions other than Bangsamoro serve primarily to organize the provinces of the country for administrative convenience.<sup id="cite_ref-Tusalem_429-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Tusalem-429">[428]</a></sup> As of 2015<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Philippines&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, <a href="/wiki/Calabarzon" title="Calabarzon">Calabarzon</a> was the most populated region while the <a href="/wiki/Metro_Manila" title="Metro Manila">National Capital Region</a> (NCR) the most densely populated.<sup id="cite_ref-psa.gov.ph_430-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-psa.gov.ph-430">[429]</a></sup> </p> 
      <table class="wikitable sortable mw-datatable collapsible" style="margin:auto; text-align:right; font-size:95%;">

shape="poly" coords="50,989,50,989,49,996,49,996,51,997,51,1000,50,1002,50,1006,49,1006,46,1009,46,1009,41,1001,41,1001,41,1001,42,993,42,993,42,993,45,990,45,990,45,990,50,989,50,989" alt="Palawan" title="Palawan"><area href="/wiki/Palawan" shape="poly" coords="227,749,227,749,230,748,230,748,231,752,231,754,230,758,229,760,227,763,228,765,229,767,233,767,235,766,235,766,235,772,235,772,235,772,231,770,231,770,231,770,231,773,231,773,223,771,226,783,228,785,230,786,231,785,233,785,234,789,233,794,232,798,232,798,237,796,237,796,237,796,238,798,238,798,236,801,238,804,241,806,238,815,235,813,232,819,232,819,224,819,224,819,217,820,211,826,208,832,205,837,207,841,204,843,202,845,198,845,196,846,196,846,189,848,189,848,183,849,185,847,178,850,176,851,173,851,172,854,170,858,174,860,174,867,174,867,170,866,170,866,170,866,171,864,171,864,171,864,167,864,167,864,167,864,170,868,170,868,170,868,169,870,169,870,169,870,172,871,172,871,172,871,170,872,170,872,169,876,167,877,165,881,160,888,157,890,154,898,148,899,147,904,143,906,142,907,128,910,126,910,125,915,122,925,117,929,115,931,113,931,109,934,109,934,99,943,99,943,96,945,87,945,85,947,84,948,84,950,83,953,83,953,81,958,81,958,70,954,64,967,58,970,58,970,60,961,60,961,60,961,61,956,61,956,61,956,63,950,63,950,63,950,70,941,70,941,70,941,75,937,75,937,75,937,81,930,81,930,81,930,89,921,89,921,89,921,92,917,92,917,92,917,99,915,99,915,99,915,103,908,103,908,103,908,111,902,111,902,111,902,116,901,116,901,116,901,119,903,119,903,120,899,123,897,127,895,127,891,128,892,131,889,132,888,132,886,134,884,137,881,141,879,142,874,148,871,145,871,150,868,150,868,154,864,154,864,158,861,165,852,165,847,165,847,171,841,171,841,171,841,174,846,174,846,174,846,177,845,177,845,177,845,178,839,178,839,178,839,176,838,176,838,176,838,176,833,176,833,181,833,186,833,186,827,186,827,191,824,191,824,191,824,192,819,192,819,192,819,189,821,189,821,189,821,190,817,190,817,190,817,195,818,195,818,195,818,198,811,198,811,198,811,199,818,199,818,205,815,213,806,214,799,215,795,217,790,210,790,209,786,206,781,210,778,210,778,210,783,210,783,210,783,219,789,219,789,219,789,218,791,218,791,218,791,224,794,224,794,223,790,222,788,224,785,224,785,220,783,220,783,216,781,215,781,217,777,213,776,213,775,214,771,214,771,216,774,216,774,216,774,214,770,214,770,214,770,215,766,215,766,217,769,221,771,221,766,221,763,220,761,218,759,222,755,221,753,222,747,225,746,225,744,226,742,228,744,227,746,227,749" alt="Palawan" title="Palawan"><area href="/wiki/Oriental_Mindoro" shape="poly" coords="333,586,335,589,338,593,342,593,344,593,349,592,351,593,355,595,360,601,364,604,365,606,367,607,368,608,368,610,368,612,368,614,370,613,375,612,375,615,376,618,374,619,373,621,372,623,372,624,372,626,372,626,371,640,371,640,372,643,375,645,375,648,377,654,372,658,367,660,368,666,365,664,368,671,368,671,364,670,364,670,364,670,365,677,365,677,365,677,362,674,362,674,362,674,354,678,354,678,354,678,354,627,354,627,354,627,353,620,353,620,353,620,343,614,343,614,343,614,322,602,322,602,322,602,327,594,327,594,327,594,328,586,328,586,328,586,333,586,333,586,359,606,359,606,358,614,358,614,365,617,367,608,359,606" alt="Oriental Mindoro" title="Oriental Mindoro"><area href="/wiki/Occidental_Mindoro" shape="poly" coords="292,585,294,584,297,586,300,586,300,586,320,589,320,589,323,588,325,587,327,586,327,597,326,594,320,602,320,602,342,614,342,614,342,614,352,621,352,621,352,621,354,627,354,627,354,627,354,682,354,682,352,681,339,679,346,676,343,671,343,674,339,671,338,671,334,666,333,665,329,659,332,657,331,654,330,652,326,646,325,645,323,644,322,644,321,644,321,637,320,639,320,635,320,635,320,630,320,630,319,624,317,621,314,616,311,611,308,607,302,606,302,606,298,600,298,600,298,599,297,594,296,593,294,591,292,594,291,595,283,594,285,586,292,585" href="/wiki/Occidental_Mindoro" shape="poly" coords="281,566,282,567,282,569,281,570,278,569,272,567,271,564,271,564,269,559,269,559,272,559,280,562,281,566" alt="Occidental Mindoro" title="Occidental Mindoro"><area href="/wiki/Occidental_Mindoro" shape="poly" coords="342,677,342,677,345,686,345,686,341,684,338,682,339,677,339,677,342,677,342,677" alt="Occidental Mindoro" title="Occidental Mindoro"></map>
