      <p><br> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_the_Philippines" title="Economy of the Philippines">Economy of the Philippines</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:282px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Philippines_Exports_Treemap_2017.svg" class="image"><img alt="Philippine Export Treemap in 2012." src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Philippines_Exports_Treemap_2017.svg/280px-Philippines_Exports_Treemap_2017.svg.png" decoding="async" width="280" height="280" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Philippines_Exports_Treemap_2017.svg/420px-Philippines_Exports_Treemap_2017.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Philippines_Exports_Treemap_2017.svg/560px-Philippines_Exports_Treemap_2017.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="900" data-file-height="900"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Philippines_Exports_Treemap_2017.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>A proportional representation of the Philippines' exports, 2017.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The Philippine economy has produced an estimated <a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">gross domestic product</a> (nominal) of $356.8&nbsp;billion.<sup id="cite_ref-dfat_432-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dfat-432">[431]</a></sup> Primary exports include <a href="/wiki/Semiconductors" class="mw-redirect" title="Semiconductors">semiconductors</a> and electronic products, transport equipment, garments, <a href="/wiki/Copper" title="Copper">copper</a> products, <a href="/wiki/Petroleum" title="Petroleum">petroleum</a> products, <a href="/wiki/Coconut_oil" title="Coconut oil">coconut oil</a>, and fruits. Major trading partners include the United States, Japan, China, Singapore, South Korea, the Netherlands, Hong Kong, Germany, Taiwan, and Thailand.<sup id="cite_ref-CIAfactbook_6-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIAfactbook-6">[6]</a></sup> Its unit of <a href="/wiki/Currency" title="Currency">currency</a> is the <a href="/wiki/Philippine_peso" title="Philippine peso">Philippine peso</a> (₱<sup id="cite_ref-433" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-433">[432]</a></sup> or PHP<sup id="cite_ref-434" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-434">[433]</a></sup>).<sup id="cite_ref-435" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-435">[434]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>A <a href="/wiki/Newly_industrialized_country" title="Newly industrialized country">newly industrialized country</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-goldmann11_436-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-goldmann11-436">[435]</a></sup> the Philippine economy has been transitioning from one based upon agriculture to an economy with more emphasis upon services and manufacturing.<sup id="cite_ref-437" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-437">[436]</a></sup> Of the country's 2018 labor force of around 43.46&nbsp;million, the <a href="/wiki/Agriculture_in_the_Philippines" title="Agriculture in the Philippines">agricultural sector</a> employed 24.3%,<sup id="cite_ref-438" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-438">[437]</a></sup> and accounted for 8.1% of 2018 GDP.<sup id="cite_ref-PSAGovPH-GDP2018_439-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PSAGovPH-GDP2018-439">[438]</a></sup> The industrial sector employed around 19% of the workforce and accounted for 34.1% of GDP, while 57% of the workers involved in the services sector were responsible for 57.8% of GDP.<sup id="cite_ref-PSAGovPH-GDP2018_439-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PSAGovPH-GDP2018-439">[438]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-440" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-440">[439]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Unemployment_rate" class="mw-redirect" title="Unemployment rate">unemployment rate</a> as of October&nbsp;2019<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Philippines&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, stands at 4.5%.<sup id="cite_ref-441" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-441">[440]</a></sup> Meanwhile, due to lower charges in basic necessities, the inflation rate eased to 1.7% in August 2019.<sup id="cite_ref-442" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-442">[441]</a></sup> Gross international reserves as of October 2013 are $83.201&nbsp;billion.<sup id="cite_ref-443" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-443">[442]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Debt-to-GDP_ratio" title="Debt-to-GDP ratio">Debt-to-GDP ratio</a> continues to decline to 37.6% as of the second quarter of 2019<sup id="cite_ref-444" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-444">[443]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-445" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-445">[444]</a></sup> from a record high of 78% in 2004.<sup id="cite_ref-446" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-446">[445]</a></sup> The country is a net importer<sup id="cite_ref-quickstat_447-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-quickstat-447">[446]</a></sup> but it is also a creditor nation.<sup id="cite_ref-448" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-448">[447]</a></sup> Manila hosts the headquarters of the <a href="/wiki/Asian_Development_Bank" title="Asian Development Bank">Asian Development Bank</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-449" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-449">[448]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:0123jfCalipahan_Sicsican_Rice_Fields_San_Pascual_Talavera_Ecijafvf_04.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/0123jfCalipahan_Sicsican_Rice_Fields_San_Pascual_Talavera_Ecijafvf_04.JPG/220px-0123jfCalipahan_Sicsican_Rice_Fields_San_Pascual_Talavera_Ecijafvf_04.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/0123jfCalipahan_Sicsican_Rice_Fields_San_Pascual_Talavera_Ecijafvf_04.JPG/330px-0123jfCalipahan_Sicsican_Rice_Fields_San_Pascual_Talavera_Ecijafvf_04.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/0123jfCalipahan_Sicsican_Rice_Fields_San_Pascual_Talavera_Ecijafvf_04.JPG/440px-0123jfCalipahan_Sicsican_Rice_Fields_San_Pascual_Talavera_Ecijafvf_04.JPG 2x" data-file-width="4608" data-file-height="3456"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:0123jfCalipahan_Sicsican_Rice_Fields_San_Pascual_Talavera_Ecijafvf_04.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Filipinos" title="Filipinos">Filipinos</a> planting rice. <a href="/wiki/Agriculture_in_the_Philippines" title="Agriculture in the Philippines">Agriculture employs 23% of the Filipino workforce</a> as of 2020<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Philippines&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>.<sup id="cite_ref-450" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-450">[449]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/1997_Asian_Financial_Crisis" class="mw-redirect" title="1997 Asian Financial Crisis">1997 Asian Financial Crisis</a> affected the economy, resulting in a lingering decline of the value of the peso and falls in the stock market. The extent it was affected initially was not as severe as that of some of its Asian neighbors. This was largely due to the <a href="/wiki/Fiscal_conservatism" title="Fiscal conservatism">fiscal conservatism</a> of the government, partly as a result of decades of monitoring and fiscal supervision from the <a href="/wiki/International_Monetary_Fund" title="International Monetary Fund">International Monetary Fund</a> (IMF), in comparison to the massive spending of its neighbors on the rapid acceleration of economic growth.<sup id="cite_ref-lastlaugh_156-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lastlaugh-156">[155]</a></sup> There have been signs of progress since. In 2004, the economy experienced 6.4% GDP growth and 7.1% in 2007, its fastest pace of growth in three decades.<sup id="cite_ref-IMF2012_451-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IMF2012-451">[450]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-fastestGDP_452-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fastestGDP-452">[451]</a></sup> Average annual GDP growth per capita for the period 1966–2007 still stands at 1.45% in comparison to an average of 5.96% for the East Asia and the Pacific region as a whole. The daily income for 45% of the population of the Philippines remains less than $2.<sup id="cite_ref-UN_453-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UN-453">[452]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Reddel_454-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Reddel-454">[453]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-455" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-455">[454]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template noprint Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:AGE_MATTERS" class="mw-redirect" title="Wikipedia:AGE MATTERS"><span title="This claim needs references to more current sources. (December 2020)">obsolete&nbsp;source</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Remittance" title="Remittance">Remittances</a> from <a href="/wiki/Overseas_Filipino" class="mw-redirect" title="Overseas Filipino">overseas Filipinos</a> contribute significantly to the Philippine economy.<sup id="cite_ref-InquirerOFW_456-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-InquirerOFW-456">[455]</a></sup> Remittances peaked in 2006 at 10.4% of the national GDP, and were 8.6% and 8.5% in 2012 and in 2014 respectively.<sup id="cite_ref-InquirerOFW_456-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-InquirerOFW-456">[455]</a></sup> In 2014 the total worth of foreign exchange remittances was US$28&nbsp;billion.<sup id="cite_ref-457" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-457">[456]</a></sup> Regional development is uneven, with Luzon – Metro Manila in particular – gaining most of the new economic growth at the expense of the other regions.<sup id="cite_ref-econ-manila_458-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-econ-manila-458">[457]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-459" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-459">[458]</a></sup> Service industries such as <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_the_Philippines" title="Tourism in the Philippines">tourism</a><sup id="cite_ref-460" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-460">[459]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Business_Process_Outsourcing_in_the_Philippines" class="mw-redirect" title="Business Process Outsourcing in the Philippines">business process outsourcing</a> have been identified as areas with some of the best opportunities for growth for the country.<sup id="cite_ref-atimesbpo_461-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-atimesbpo-461">[460]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Outsourcing#Business_process_outsourcing" title="Outsourcing">Business Process Outsourcing</a> (BPO) industry is composed of eight sub-sectors, namely, knowledge process outsourcing and back offices, animation, <a href="/wiki/Call_center_industry_in_the_Philippines" title="Call center industry in the Philippines">call centers</a>, software development, game development, engineering design, and <a href="/wiki/Medical_transcription" title="Medical transcription">medical transcription</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-462" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-462">[461]</a></sup> In 2010<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Philippines&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, the Philippines was reported as having eclipsed India as the main center of BPO services in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-463" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-463">[462]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-464" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-464">[463]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-465" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-465">[464]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Science_and_technology">Science and technology</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Science_and_technology_in_the_Philippines" title="Science and technology in the Philippines">Science and technology in the Philippines</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Head_Quarters_of_the_International_Rice_Research_Institute_in_Los_Ba%C3%B1os_-_panoramio.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/Head_Quarters_of_the_International_Rice_Research_Institute_in_Los_Ba%C3%B1os_-_panoramio.jpg/220px-Head_Quarters_of_the_International_Rice_Research_Institute_in_Los_Ba%C3%B1os_-_panoramio.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/Head_Quarters_of_the_International_Rice_Research_Institute_in_Los_Ba%C3%B1os_-_panoramio.jpg/330px-Head_Quarters_of_the_International_Rice_Research_Institute_in_Los_Ba%C3%B1os_-_panoramio.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/Head_Quarters_of_the_International_Rice_Research_Institute_in_Los_Ba%C3%B1os_-_panoramio.jpg/440px-Head_Quarters_of_the_International_Rice_Research_Institute_in_Los_Ba%C3%B1os_-_panoramio.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3072" data-file-height="2304"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Head_Quarters_of_the_International_Rice_Research_Institute_in_Los_Ba%C3%B1os_-_panoramio.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Headquarters of the <a href="/wiki/International_Rice_Research_Institute" title="International Rice Research Institute">International Rice Research Institute</a> in <a href="/wiki/Los_Ba%C3%B1os,_Laguna" title="Los Baños, Laguna">Los Baños, Laguna</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Department_of_Science_and_Technology_(Philippines)" title="Department of Science and Technology (Philippines)">Department of Science and Technology</a> is the governing agency responsible for the development of coordination of <a href="/wiki/Science_and_technology_in_the_Philippines" title="Science and technology in the Philippines">science and technology-related projects in the Philippines</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-466" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-466">[465]</a></sup> Research organizations in the country include the <a href="/wiki/International_Rice_Research_Institute" title="International Rice Research Institute">International Rice Research Institute</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-467" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-467">[466]</a></sup> which focuses on the development of new rice varieties and rice crop management techniques.<sup id="cite_ref-468" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-468">[467]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The Philippines bought its first satellite in 1996.<sup id="cite_ref-469" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-469">[468]</a></sup> In 2016, <a href="/wiki/Space_program_of_the_Philippines" class="mw-redirect" title="Space program of the Philippines">the Philippines first micro-satellite</a>, <a href="/wiki/Diwata-1" title="Diwata-1">Diwata-1</a> was launched aboard the US <a href="/wiki/Cygnus_(spacecraft)" title="Cygnus (spacecraft)">Cygnus</a> spacecraft.<sup id="cite_ref-Diwata-1_470-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Diwata-1-470">[469]</a></sup> The Philippines has a high concentration of cellular phone users.<sup id="cite_ref-pldt_471-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pldt-471">[470]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Text_messaging" title="Text messaging">Text messaging</a> is a popular form of communication and, in 2007, the nation sent an average of one billion <a href="/wiki/Short_message_service" class="mw-redirect" title="Short message service">SMS</a> messages per day.<sup id="cite_ref-472" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-472">[471]</a></sup> The country has a high level of mobile financial services utilization.<sup id="cite_ref-txt_473-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-txt-473">[472]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Long_Distance_Telephone_Company" class="mw-redirect" title="Philippine Long Distance Telephone Company">Philippine Long Distance Telephone Company</a>, commonly known as PLDT, is a formerly nationalized telecommunications provider.<sup id="cite_ref-pldt_471-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pldt-471">[470]</a></sup> It is also the largest company in the country.<sup id="cite_ref-474" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-474">[473]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/National_Telecommunications_Commission_(Philippines)" title="National Telecommunications Commission (Philippines)">National Telecommunications Commission</a> is the agency responsible for the supervision, adjudication and control over all <a href="/wiki/Telecommunications_in_the_Philippines" title="Telecommunications in the Philippines">telecommunications services throughout the country</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-475" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-475">[474]</a></sup> There are approximately 417 AM and 1079 FM radio stations and 438 television and 1,551 cable television stations.<sup id="cite_ref-476" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-476">[475]</a></sup> On March 29, 1994, the country was <a href="/wiki/Internet_in_the_Philippines" title="Internet in the Philippines">connected to the Internet</a> via a 64 kbit/s connection from a router serviced by PLDT to a Sprint router in California.<sup id="cite_ref-477" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-477">[476]</a></sup> Estimates for Internet penetration in the Philippines vary widely ranging from a low of 2.5&nbsp;million to a high of 24&nbsp;million people.<sup id="cite_ref-ntc2_478-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ntc2-478">[477]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-479" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-479">[478]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Social_networking_in_the_Philippines" title="Social networking in the Philippines">Social networking</a> and watching videos are among the most frequent Internet activities.<sup id="cite_ref-Capital_480-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Capital-480">[479]</a></sup> The Philippine population is the world's top internet user.<sup id="cite_ref-481" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-481">[480]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Tourism">Tourism</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_the_Philippines" title="Tourism in the Philippines">Tourism in the Philippines</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Big_lagoon_entrance,_Miniloc_island_-_panoramio.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Big_lagoon_entrance%2C_Miniloc_island_-_panoramio.jpg/220px-Big_lagoon_entrance%2C_Miniloc_island_-_panoramio.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Big_lagoon_entrance%2C_Miniloc_island_-_panoramio.jpg/330px-Big_lagoon_entrance%2C_Miniloc_island_-_panoramio.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Big_lagoon_entrance%2C_Miniloc_island_-_panoramio.jpg/440px-Big_lagoon_entrance%2C_Miniloc_island_-_panoramio.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1752" data-file-height="1168"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Big_lagoon_entrance,_Miniloc_island_-_panoramio.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Limestone cliffs of <a href="/wiki/El_Nido,_Palawan" title="El Nido, Palawan">El Nido</a>, Palawan.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The travel and tourism sector contributed 10.6% of the country's GDP in 2015<sup id="cite_ref-482" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-482">[481]</a></sup> and providing 1,226,500 jobs in 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-483" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-483">[482]</a></sup> 8,260,913 international visitors arrived from January to December 2019, up by 15.24% for the same period in 2018.<sup id="cite_ref-484" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-484">[483]</a></sup> <span data-sort-value="7001586227454519857♠" style="display:none"></span>58.62%&nbsp;(4,842,774) of these came from East Asia, <span data-sort-value="7001158389756677016♠" style="display:none"></span>15.84%&nbsp;(1,308,444) came from North America, and <span data-sort-value="7000637740646826809♠" style="display:none"></span>6.38%&nbsp;(526,832) came from other ASEAN countries.<sup id="cite_ref-NQ-June2020_334-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NQ-June2020-334">[333]</a></sup> The island of <a href="/wiki/Boracay" title="Boracay">Boracay</a>, popular for its beaches, was named as the best island in the world by <a href="/wiki/Travel_%2B_Leisure" title="Travel + Leisure">Travel + Leisure</a> in 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-mb.com.ph_485-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mb.com.ph-485">[484]</a></sup> The Philippines is also a popular <a href="/wiki/Retirement" title="Retirement">retirement</a> destination for foreigners due to its climate and low cost of living.<sup id="cite_ref-486" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-486">[485]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Infrastructure">Infrastructure</span></h2> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Transportation">Transportation</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Transportation_in_the_Philippines" title="Transportation in the Philippines">Transportation in the Philippines</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:MRT-2_Train_Santolan_1.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/MRT-2_Train_Santolan_1.jpg/220px-MRT-2_Train_Santolan_1.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/MRT-2_Train_Santolan_1.jpg/330px-MRT-2_Train_Santolan_1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/MRT-2_Train_Santolan_1.jpg/440px-MRT-2_Train_Santolan_1.jpg 2x" data-file-width="701" data-file-height="525"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:MRT-2_Train_Santolan_1.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>An <a href="/wiki/LRT_Line_2_(Metro_Manila)" title="LRT Line 2 (Metro Manila)">LRT Line 2</a> train at <a href="/wiki/Santolan_station_(LRT)" title="Santolan station (LRT)">Santolan station</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Skyway_SLEX_PNR.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/Skyway_SLEX_PNR.jpg/220px-Skyway_SLEX_PNR.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/Skyway_SLEX_PNR.jpg/330px-Skyway_SLEX_PNR.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/Skyway_SLEX_PNR.jpg/440px-Skyway_SLEX_PNR.jpg 2x" data-file-width="782" data-file-height="520"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Skyway_SLEX_PNR.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/South_Luzon_Expressway" title="South Luzon Expressway">South Luzon Expressway</a>, <a href="/wiki/Skyway_(Metro_Manila)" title="Skyway (Metro Manila)">Skyway</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Philippine_National_Railways" title="Philippine National Railways">PNR</a> <a href="/wiki/PNR_Metro_Commuter_Line" title="PNR Metro Commuter Line">Metro Commuter Line</a> in <a href="/wiki/Metro_Manila" title="Metro Manila">Metro Manila</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Transportation_in_the_Philippines" title="Transportation in the Philippines">Transportation in the Philippines</a> is facilitated by road, air, rail and waterways. As of December 2018, there are 210,528 kilometers (130,816&nbsp;mi) of roads in the Philippines, with only 65,101 kilometers (40,452&nbsp;mi) of roads paved.<sup id="cite_ref-487" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-487">[486]</a></sup> The 919-kilometer (571&nbsp;mi) <a href="/wiki/Strong_Republic_Nautical_Highway" class="mw-redirect" title="Strong Republic Nautical Highway">Strong Republic Nautical Highway</a> (SRNH), an integrated set of highway segments and ferry routes covering 17 cities was established in 2003.<sup id="cite_ref-488" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-488">[487]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Pan-Philippine_Highway" title="Pan-Philippine Highway">Pan-Philippine Highway</a> connects the islands of Luzon, Samar, Leyte, and Mindanao, forming the backbone of land-based transportation in the country.<sup id="cite_ref-489" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-489">[488]</a></sup> Roads are the dominant form of transport, carrying 98% of people and 58% of cargo. A <a href="/wiki/Philippine_expressway_network" title="Philippine expressway network">network of expressways</a> extends from the capital to other areas of Luzon.<sup id="cite_ref-490" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-490">[489]</a></sup> The 8.25-kilometre (5.13&nbsp;mi) <a href="/wiki/Cebu%E2%80%93Cordova_Link_Expressway" title="Cebu–Cordova Link Expressway">Cebu–Cordova Link Expressway</a> in <a href="/wiki/Cebu" title="Cebu">Cebu</a> will be finished by 2021.<sup id="cite_ref-491" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-491">[490]</a></sup> Traffic is a significant issue facing the country, especially within Manila and on arterial roads connecting to the capital.<sup id="cite_ref-492" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-492">[491]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Public transport in the country include buses, <a href="/wiki/Jeepney" title="Jeepney">jeepneys</a>, <a href="/wiki/UV_Express" title="UV Express">UV Express</a>, TNVS, Filcab, <a href="/wiki/Taxi" class="mw-redirect" title="Taxi">taxis</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Tricycle" title="Tricycle">tricycles</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-493" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-493">[492]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-494" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-494">[493]</a></sup> Jeepneys are a popular and iconic <a href="/wiki/Public_utility_vehicle" class="mw-redirect" title="Public utility vehicle">public utility vehicle</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-reu1_495-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-reu1-495">[494]</a></sup> Jeepneys and other Public Utility Vehicles which are older than 15 years are <a href="/wiki/Public_Utility_Vehicle_Modernization_Program" title="Public Utility Vehicle Modernization Program">being phased out gradually</a> in favor of a more efficient and environmentally friendly <a href="/wiki/Euro_4" class="mw-redirect" title="Euro 4">Euro 4</a> compliant vehicles.<sup id="cite_ref-496" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-496">[495]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-497" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-497">[496]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Despite wider historical use, <a href="/wiki/Rail_transport_in_the_Philippines" class="mw-redirect" title="Rail transport in the Philippines">rail transport in the Philippines</a> is extremely limited, being confined to transporting passengers within Metro Manila and neighboring <a href="/wiki/Laguna_(province)" title="Laguna (province)">Laguna</a>, with a separate short track in the <a href="/wiki/Bicol_Region" title="Bicol Region">Bicol Region</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-498" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-498">[497]</a></sup> There are plans to revive <a href="/wiki/Freight_transport" title="Freight transport">Freight transport</a> to reduce road congestion.<sup id="cite_ref-499" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-499">[498]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-500" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-500">[499]</a></sup> As of 2019<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Philippines&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, the country had a railway footprint of only 79 kilometers, which it had plans to expand up to 244 kilometers.<sup id="cite_ref-501" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-501">[500]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-502" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-502">[501]</a></sup> Metro Manila is served by three rapid transit lines: <a href="/wiki/LRT_Line_1_(Metro_Manila)" title="LRT Line 1 (Metro Manila)">LRT Line 1</a>, <a href="/wiki/LRT_Line_2_(Metro_Manila)" title="LRT Line 2 (Metro Manila)">LRT Line 2</a> and <a href="/wiki/MRT_Line_3_(Metro_Manila)" title="MRT Line 3 (Metro Manila)">MRT Line 3</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-yellow_503-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-yellow-503">[502]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-provision_504-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-provision-504">[503]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-times_505-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-times-505">[504]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/PNR_Metro_Commuter_Line" title="PNR Metro Commuter Line">PNR South Commuter Line</a> transports passengers between Metro Manila and Laguna.<sup id="cite_ref-506" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-506">[505]</a></sup> Railway lines that are under-construction include the 4-kilometre (2.5&nbsp;mi) Line 2 East Extension Project (2020),<sup id="cite_ref-507" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-507">[506]</a></sup> the 22.8-kilometre (14.2&nbsp;mi) <a href="/wiki/MRT_Line_7_(Metro_Manila)" title="MRT Line 7 (Metro Manila)">MRT Line 7</a> (2020),<sup id="cite_ref-508" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-508">[507]</a></sup> the 35-kilometre (22&nbsp;mi) <a href="/wiki/Metro_Manila_Subway" title="Metro Manila Subway">Metro Manila Subway</a> (2025),<sup id="cite_ref-509" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-509">[508]</a></sup> and the 109-kilometre (68&nbsp;mi) PNR North-South Commuter Railway which is divided into several phases, with partial operations to begin in 2022.<sup id="cite_ref-510" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-510">[509]</a></sup> The civil airline industry is regulated by the <a href="/wiki/Civil_Aviation_Authority_of_the_Philippines" title="Civil Aviation Authority of the Philippines">Civil Aviation Authority of the Philippines</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-511" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-511">[510]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Airlines" title="Philippine Airlines">Philippine Airlines</a> is Asia's oldest commercial airline still operating under its original name.<sup id="cite_ref-PAL_512-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PAL-512">[511]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-513" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-513">[512]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Cebu_Pacific" title="Cebu Pacific">Cebu Pacific</a> is the countries leading <a href="/wiki/Low-cost_carrier" title="Low-cost carrier">low-cost carrier</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-OxfordBG_514-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-OxfordBG-514">[513]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>As an archipelago, inter-island travel using watercraft is often necessary.<sup id="cite_ref-515" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-515">[514]</a></sup> Boats have always been important to societies in the Philippines.<sup id="cite_ref-Isorena_516-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Isorena-516">[515]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Unescoboats_517-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Unescoboats-517">[516]</a></sup> Most boats are <a href="/wiki/Outrigger_boat" title="Outrigger boat">double-outrigger</a> vessels, which can reach up to 30 metres (98&nbsp;ft) in length, known as <i>banca</i><sup id="cite_ref-aguilar_518-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-aguilar-518">[517]</a></sup>/<i>bangka</i>,<sup id="cite_ref-Funtecha_519-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Funtecha-519">[518]</a></sup> <i>parao</i>, prahu, or <i>balanghay</i>. A variety of boat types are used throughout the islands, such as <a href="/wiki/Dugout_canoe" title="Dugout canoe">dugouts</a> (<i>baloto</i>) and house-boats like the <i>lepa-lepa</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-Unescoboats_517-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Unescoboats-517">[516]</a></sup> Terms such as <i>bangka</i> and <i>baroto</i> are also used as general names for a variety of boat types.<sup id="cite_ref-Funtecha_519-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Funtecha-519">[518]</a></sup> Modern ships use plywood in place of logs and motor engines in place of sails.<sup id="cite_ref-aguilar_518-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-aguilar-518">[517]</a></sup> These ships are used both for fishing and for inter-island travel.<sup id="cite_ref-Funtecha_519-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Funtecha-519">[518]</a></sup> The principal <a href="/wiki/Seaport" class="mw-redirect" title="Seaport">seaports</a> of <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Manila" title="Port of Manila">Manila</a>, <a href="/wiki/Batangas_International_Port" title="Batangas International Port">Batangas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Subic" class="mw-redirect" title="Port of Subic">Subic Bay</a>, <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Cebu" title="Port of Cebu">Cebu</a>, <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Iloilo" title="Port of Iloilo">Iloilo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Davao" title="Port of Davao">Davao</a>, Cagayan de Oro, General Santos, and <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Zamboanga" title="Port of Zamboanga">Zamboanga</a> form part of the ASEAN Transport Network.<sup id="cite_ref-520" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-520">[519]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-521" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-521">[520]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Pasig_River_Ferry" class="mw-redirect" title="Pasig River Ferry">Pasig River Ferry</a> serves the cities of Manila, Makati, Mandaluyong, Pasig and Marikina in Metro Manila.<sup id="cite_ref-522" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-522">[521]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-523" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-523">[522]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Water_supply_and_sanitation">Water supply and sanitation</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Water_supply_and_sanitation_in_the_Philippines" title="Water supply and sanitation in the Philippines">Water supply and sanitation in the Philippines</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Ambuklao_Dam_captured_by_Mitchell_Yumul.jpeg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Ambuklao_Dam_captured_by_Mitchell_Yumul.jpeg/220px-Ambuklao_Dam_captured_by_Mitchell_Yumul.jpeg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Ambuklao_Dam_captured_by_Mitchell_Yumul.jpeg/330px-Ambuklao_Dam_captured_by_Mitchell_Yumul.jpeg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Ambuklao_Dam_captured_by_Mitchell_Yumul.jpeg/440px-Ambuklao_Dam_captured_by_Mitchell_Yumul.jpeg 2x" data-file-width="960" data-file-height="641"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Ambuklao_Dam_captured_by_Mitchell_Yumul.jpeg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Ambuklao_Dam" title="Ambuklao Dam">Ambuklao Dam</a> in <a href="/wiki/Bokod,_Benguet" title="Bokod, Benguet">Bokod</a>, <a href="/wiki/Benguet" title="Benguet">Benguet</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In 2015, it was reported by the <a href="/wiki/Joint_Monitoring_Programme_for_Water_Supply_and_Sanitation" title="Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply and Sanitation">Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply and Sanitation</a> that 74% of the population had access to <a href="/wiki/Improved_sanitation" title="Improved sanitation">improved sanitation</a>, and that "good progress" had been made between 1990 and 2015.<sup id="cite_ref-Organization2015_524-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Organization2015-524">[523]</a></sup> As of 2016, 96% of Filipino households have an improved source of drinking water, and 92% of households had sanitary toilet facilities, although connections of these toilet facilities to appropriate sewerage systems remain largely insufficient especially in rural and urban poor communities.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDepartment_of_Health2018Chapter_3_(page_46)_525-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDepartment_of_Health2018Chapter_3_(page_46)-525">[524]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_the_Philippines" title="Culture of the Philippines">Culture of the Philippines</a> and <a href="/wiki/Arts_in_the_Philippines" title="Arts in the Philippines">Arts in the Philippines</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Ati-Atihan_Festival_Participant.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Ati-Atihan_Festival_Participant.jpg/220px-Ati-Atihan_Festival_Participant.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Ati-Atihan_Festival_Participant.jpg/330px-Ati-Atihan_Festival_Participant.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Ati-Atihan_Festival_Participant.jpg/440px-Ati-Atihan_Festival_Participant.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3648" data-file-height="2736"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Ati-Atihan_Festival_Participant.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>A participant of the <a href="/wiki/Ati-Atihan_Festival" class="mw-redirect" title="Ati-Atihan Festival">Ati-Atihan Festival</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>One of the most visible <a href="/wiki/Spanish_influence_on_Filipino_culture" title="Spanish influence on Filipino culture">Hispanic legacies</a> is the prevalence of <a href="/wiki/Cat%C3%A1logo_Alfab%C3%A9tico_de_Apellidos" class="mw-redirect" title="Catálogo Alfabético de Apellidos">Spanish names and surnames</a> among Filipinos; a Spanish name and surname, however, does not necessarily denote Spanish ancestry. This peculiarity, unique among the people of Asia, came as a result of a colonial edict by Governor-General <a href="/wiki/Narciso_Claver%C3%ADa_y_Zald%C3%BAa,_1st_Count_of_Manila" class="mw-redirect" title="Narciso Clavería y Zaldúa, 1st Count of Manila">Narciso Clavería y Zaldua</a>, which ordered the systematic distribution of family names and implementation of <a href="/wiki/Spanish_naming_customs" title="Spanish naming customs">Hispanic nomenclature</a> on the population.<sup id="cite_ref-Dumont_526-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dumont-526">[525]</a></sup> The names of many locations are also Spanish, or stem from Spanish roots and origins.<sup id="cite_ref-527" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-527">[526]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>There is a substantial American influence on modern Filipino culture.<sup id="cite_ref-Banlaoi_263-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Banlaoi-263">[262]</a></sup> The common use of the English language is an example of the American impact on Philippine society. It has contributed to the influence of American pop cultural trends.<sup id="cite_ref-528" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-528">[527]</a></sup> This affinity is seen in Filipinos' consumption of <a href="/wiki/Fast_food" title="Fast food">fast food</a> and American film and music.<sup id="cite_ref-529" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-529">[528]</a></sup> American global fast-food chain stalwarts have entered the market, but local fast-food chains like <a href="/wiki/Goldilocks_Bakeshop" title="Goldilocks Bakeshop">Goldilocks</a><sup id="cite_ref-530" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-530">[529]</a></sup> and most notably <a href="/wiki/Jollibee" title="Jollibee">Jollibee</a>, the leading fast-food chain in the country, have emerged and compete successfully against foreign chains.<sup id="cite_ref-Jollibee2_531-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Jollibee2-531">[530]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Ati-Atihan_Festival" class="mw-redirect" title="Ati-Atihan Festival">Ati-Atihan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Moriones_Festival" title="Moriones Festival">Moriones</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sinulog" title="Sinulog">Sinulog</a> <a href="/wiki/List_of_festivals_in_the_Philippines" title="List of festivals in the Philippines">festivals</a> are among the most well-known.<sup id="cite_ref-532" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-532">[531]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-533" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-533">[532]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-534" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-534">[533]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The culture within <a href="/wiki/Mindanao" title="Mindanao">Mindanao</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Sulu_Archipelago" title="Sulu Archipelago">Sulu Archipelago</a> developed separately to that of the rest of the country, due to very limited degree of Spanish influence and greater influence from nearby Islamic regions.<sup id="cite_ref-535" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-535">[534]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Literature">Literature</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Philippine_literature" title="Philippine literature">Philippine literature</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Jose_rizal_01.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Jose_rizal_01.jpg/170px-Jose_rizal_01.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="255" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Jose_rizal_01.jpg/255px-Jose_rizal_01.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Jose_rizal_01.jpg/340px-Jose_rizal_01.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1000" data-file-height="1500"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Jose_rizal_01.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Rizal" title="José Rizal">José Rizal</a> is a pioneer of <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Revolution" title="Philippine Revolution">Philippine Revolution</a> through his literary works.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Philippine_mythology" title="Philippine mythology">Philippine mythology</a> has been handed down primarily through the traditional <a href="/wiki/Philippine_folk_literature" title="Philippine folk literature">oral folk literature</a> of the Filipino people. Some popular figures from Philippine mythologies are <a href="/wiki/Maria_Makiling" title="Maria Makiling">Maria Makiling</a>, <a href="/wiki/Biag_ni_Lam-Ang" class="mw-redirect" title="Biag ni Lam-Ang">Lam-Ang</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Sarimanok" title="Sarimanok">Sarimanok</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Lopez_536-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lopez-536">[535]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Philippine literature comprises works usually written in Filipino, Spanish, or English. Some of the most known were created from the 17th to 19th&nbsp;century.<sup id="cite_ref-537" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-537">[536]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Ibong_Adarna" title="Ibong Adarna">Adarna</a>, for example, is a famous epic about an eponymous magical bird allegedly written by <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_de_la_Cruz" title="José de la Cruz">José de la Cruz</a> or "Huseng Sisiw".<sup id="cite_ref-538" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-538">[537]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Francisco_Balagtas" title="Francisco Balagtas">Francisco Balagtas</a>, the poet and playwright who wrote <i><a href="/wiki/Florante_at_Laura" title="Florante at Laura">Florante at Laura</a></i>, is recognized as a preeminent writer in the Tagalog (Filipino) language.<sup id="cite_ref-539" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-539">[538]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Rizal" title="José Rizal">José Rizal</a> wrote the novels <i><a href="/wiki/Noli_Me_T%C3%A1ngere_(novel)" title="Noli Me Tángere (novel)">Noli Me Tángere</a></i> (<i>Touch Me Not</i>) and <i><a href="/wiki/El_Filibusterismo" class="mw-redirect" title="El Filibusterismo">El Filibusterismo</a></i> (<i>The Filibustering</i>, also known as <i>The Reign of Greed</i>).<sup id="cite_ref-540" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-540">[539]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Architecture">Architecture</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_the_Philippines" title="Architecture of the Philippines">Architecture of the Philippines</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Calle_Crisologo,_Vigan_Ilocos_Sur.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Calle_Crisologo%2C_Vigan_Ilocos_Sur.JPG/220px-Calle_Crisologo%2C_Vigan_Ilocos_Sur.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Calle_Crisologo%2C_Vigan_Ilocos_Sur.JPG/330px-Calle_Crisologo%2C_Vigan_Ilocos_Sur.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Calle_Crisologo%2C_Vigan_Ilocos_Sur.JPG/440px-Calle_Crisologo%2C_Vigan_Ilocos_Sur.JPG 2x" data-file-width="2592" data-file-height="1944"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Calle_Crisologo,_Vigan_Ilocos_Sur.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Colonial houses in <a href="/wiki/Vigan" title="Vigan">Vigan</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Spanish_architecture" title="Spanish architecture">Spanish architecture</a> has left an imprint in the Philippines in the way many towns were designed around a <a href="/wiki/Poblacion" title="Poblacion">central square</a> or <i>plaza mayor</i>, but many of the buildings bearing its influence were demolished during World War II.<sup id="cite_ref-Ring_48-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ring-48">[47]</a></sup> Four Philippine <a href="/wiki/Baroque" title="Baroque">baroque</a> churches are included in the list of <a href="/wiki/UNESCO_World_Heritage_Sites" class="mw-redirect" title="UNESCO World Heritage Sites">UNESCO World Heritage Sites</a>: the <a href="/wiki/San_Agustin_Church,_Manila" class="mw-redirect" title="San Agustin Church, Manila">San Agustín Church</a> in Manila, <a href="/wiki/Paoay_Church" title="Paoay Church">Paoay Church</a> in <a href="/wiki/Ilocos_Norte" title="Ilocos Norte">Ilocos Norte</a>, <a href="/wiki/Santa_Maria_Church" title="Santa Maria Church">Nuestra Señora de la Asunción</a> (Santa María) Church in <a href="/wiki/Ilocos_Sur" title="Ilocos Sur">Ilocos Sur</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Miagao_Church" title="Miagao Church">Santo Tomás de Villanueva Church</a> in <a href="/wiki/Iloilo" title="Iloilo">Iloilo</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Unesco_541-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Unesco-541">[540]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Vigan" title="Vigan">Vigan</a> in Ilocos Sur is also known for the many Hispanic-style houses and buildings preserved there.<sup id="cite_ref-lonelyplanet145_542-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lonelyplanet145-542">[541]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>American rule introduced new architectural styles. This led to the construction of government buildings and <a href="/wiki/Art_Deco" title="Art Deco">Art Deco</a> theaters. During the American period, some semblance of city planning using the architectural designs and master plans by <a href="/wiki/Daniel_Burnham" title="Daniel Burnham">Daniel Burnham</a> was done on the portions of the city of Manila. Part of the Burnham plan was the construction of government buildings that resembled <a href="/wiki/Greek_architecture" class="mw-redirect" title="Greek architecture">Greek</a> or <a href="/wiki/Neoclassical_architecture" title="Neoclassical architecture">Neoclassical architecture</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-543" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-543">[542]</a></sup> In <a href="/wiki/Iloilo_City" title="Iloilo City">Iloilo</a>, structures from both the Spanish and American periods can still be seen, especially in <a href="/wiki/Calle_Real,_Iloilo" title="Calle Real, Iloilo">Calle Real</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-544" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-544">[543]</a></sup> Certain areas of the country like <a href="/wiki/Batanes" title="Batanes">Batanes</a> have slight differences as both Spanish and Filipino ways of architecture assimilated differently due to the climate. Limestones were used as a building material, with houses being built to withstand typhoons.<sup id="cite_ref-nccabatanes_545-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nccabatanes-545">[544]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Music">Music</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Music_of_the_Philippines" title="Music of the Philippines">Music of the Philippines</a>
      </div> 
      <p>During the Spanish era <a href="/wiki/Rondalya" class="mw-redirect" title="Rondalya">Rondalya</a> music, where traditional string orchestra <a href="/wiki/Mandolin" title="Mandolin">mandolin</a> type instruments were used, was widespread.<sup id="cite_ref-FameNYC_546-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FameNYC-546">[545]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Kundiman" title="Kundiman">Kundiman</a> developed in the 1920s and 30's,<sup id="cite_ref-Ellingham-Mark_547-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ellingham-Mark-547">[546]</a></sup> and had a renaissance in the postwar period.<sup id="cite_ref-548" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-548">[547]</a></sup> The American colonial period exposed many Filipinos to US culture and popular forms of music.<sup id="cite_ref-Ellingham-Mark_547-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ellingham-Mark-547">[546]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Rock_music" title="Rock music">Rock music</a> was introduced to Filipinos in the 1960s, and developed into <a href="/wiki/Filipino_rock" class="mw-redirect" title="Filipino rock">Filipino rock</a>, or "Pinoy rock", a term encompassing diverse styles such as <a href="/wiki/Pop_rock" title="Pop rock">pop rock</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alternative_rock" title="Alternative rock">alternative rock</a>, <a href="/wiki/Heavy_metal_music" title="Heavy metal music">heavy metal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Punk_rock" title="Punk rock">punk</a>, <a href="/wiki/New_wave_music" title="New wave music">new wave</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ska" title="Ska">ska</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Reggae" title="Reggae">reggae</a>. Martial law in the 1970s produced several <a href="/wiki/Philippine_folk_music" title="Philippine folk music">Filipino folk rock</a> bands and artists who were at the forefront of political demonstrations.<sup id="cite_ref-549" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-549">[548]</a></sup> The 1970s also saw the birth of <a href="/wiki/Manila_Sound" class="mw-redirect" title="Manila Sound">Manila Sound</a><sup id="cite_ref-550" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-550">[549]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Original_Pilipino_Music" class="mw-redirect" title="Original Pilipino Music">Original Pilipino Music</a> (OPM).<sup id="cite_ref-551" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-551">[550]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Filipino_hip-hop" class="mw-redirect" title="Filipino hip-hop">Filipino hip-hop</a> traces its origins back to 1979, entering the mainstream in 1990.<sup id="cite_ref-552" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-552">[551]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-553" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-553">[552]</a></sup> Recently <a href="/wiki/K-pop" title="K-pop">K-pop</a> has become popular.<sup id="cite_ref-554" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-554">[553]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Karaoke" title="Karaoke">Karaoke</a> is a popular activity in the country.<sup id="cite_ref-555" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-555">[554]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Dance">Dance</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Philippine_dance" title="Philippine dance">Philippine dance</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Folklore_of_the_popular_heritage_of_the_State_of_the_Philippines_05.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/Folklore_of_the_popular_heritage_of_the_State_of_the_Philippines_05.jpg/220px-Folklore_of_the_popular_heritage_of_the_State_of_the_Philippines_05.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/Folklore_of_the_popular_heritage_of_the_State_of_the_Philippines_05.jpg/330px-Folklore_of_the_popular_heritage_of_the_State_of_the_Philippines_05.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/Folklore_of_the_popular_heritage_of_the_State_of_the_Philippines_05.jpg/440px-Folklore_of_the_popular_heritage_of_the_State_of_the_Philippines_05.jpg 2x" data-file-width="6016" data-file-height="4000"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Folklore_of_the_popular_heritage_of_the_State_of_the_Philippines_05.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Cari%C3%B1osa" title="Cariñosa">Cariñosa</a>, a Hispanic era dance for traditional Filipino courtship.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In general, there are two types of Philippine traditional folk dance. The first one reflects the influence under the Spanish occupation and the other, the country's profuseness of tribes that offer their own tribal dances. The music that incorporates the former are mostly <a href="/wiki/Bandurria" title="Bandurria">bandurria</a>-based bands that utilizes 14th string guitars. One example of such type is the <a href="/wiki/Cari%C3%B1osa" title="Cariñosa">Cariñosa</a>. A Hispanic Filipino dance, unofficially considered as the "National Dance of the Philippines".<sup id="cite_ref-556" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-556">[555]</a></sup> Another example is the <a href="/wiki/Tinikling" title="Tinikling">Tinikling</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-557" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-557">[556]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In the Modern and Post-Modern time periods, dances may vary from the delicate <a href="/wiki/Ballet" title="Ballet">ballet</a> up to the more street-oriented styles of <a href="/wiki/Breakdancing" title="Breakdancing">breakdancing</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-nccadance_558-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nccadance-558">[557]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-559" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-559">[558]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Values">Values</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Further information: <a href="/wiki/Filipino_values" title="Filipino values">Filipino values</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Core_Value.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Core_Value.JPG/220px-Core_Value.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Core_Value.JPG/330px-Core_Value.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Core_Value.JPG/440px-Core_Value.JPG 2x" data-file-width="2592" data-file-height="1728"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Core_Value.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>A statue in <a href="/wiki/Iriga_City" class="mw-redirect" title="Iriga City">Iriga City</a> commemorating the <i><a href="/wiki/Mano_(gesture)" title="Mano (gesture)">mano po</a></i> gesture
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>As a general description, the distinct <a href="/wiki/Value_system" class="mw-redirect" title="Value system">value system</a> of Filipinos is rooted primarily in personal alliance systems, especially those based in kinship, obligation, friendship, religion (particularly Christianity), and commercial relationships.<sup id="cite_ref-CAPH_560-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CAPH-560">[559]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Filipino values are, for the most part, centered around maintaining social harmony, motivated primarily by the desire to be accepted within a group. The main sanction against diverging from these values are the concepts of "<i>Hiya</i>", roughly translated as 'a sense of shame',<sup id="cite_ref-561" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-561">[560]</a></sup> and "<i>Amor propio</i>" or 'self-esteem'.<sup id="cite_ref-Phil_562-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Phil-562">[561]</a></sup> Social approval, acceptance by a group, and belonging to a group are major concerns. Caring about what others will think, say or do, are strong influences on social behavior among Filipinos.<sup id="cite_ref-Didache_563-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Didache-563">[562]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Other elements of the Filipino value system are optimism about the future, pessimism about present situations and events, concern and care for other people, the existence of friendship and friendliness, the habit of being hospitable, religious nature, respectfulness to self and others, respect for the female members of society, the fear of God, and abhorrence of acts of cheating and thievery.<sup id="cite_ref-564" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-564">[563]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-CRVP2_565-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CRVP2-565">[564]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">Cuisine</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Filipino_cuisine" title="Filipino cuisine">Filipino cuisine</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Regional variations exist throughout the islands, for example <a href="/wiki/Rice" title="Rice">rice</a> is a standard starch in Luzon while <a href="/wiki/Cassava" title="Cassava">cassava</a> is more common in Mindanao.<sup id="cite_ref-Zibart_566-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Zibart-566">[565]</a></sup> Filipino taste buds tend to favor robust flavors, but the cuisine is not as spicy as those of its neighbors.<sup id="cite_ref-Zialcita_567-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Zialcita-567">[566]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Unlike many Asians, most Filipinos do not eat with <a href="/wiki/Chopsticks" title="Chopsticks">chopsticks</a>; they use Western cutlery. However, possibly due to rice being the primary staple food and the popularity of a large number of stews and main dishes with broth in Filipino cuisine, the main pairing of utensils seen at the Filipino dining table is that of <a href="/wiki/Spoon" title="Spoon">spoon</a> and <a href="/wiki/Fork" title="Fork">fork</a>, not knife and fork.<sup id="cite_ref-lonelyplanet48_568-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lonelyplanet48-568">[567]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The traditional way of eating with the hands known as <i>kamayan</i> (using the hand for bringing food to the mouth)<sup id="cite_ref-569" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-569">[568]</a></sup> was previously more often seen in the less urbanized areas.<sup id="cite_ref-Zibart_566-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Zibart-566">[565]</a></sup> However, due to the various Filipino restaurants that introduced Filipino food to people of other nationalities, as well as to Filipino urbanites, <i>kamayan</i> fast became popular.<sup id="cite_ref-570" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-570">[569]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-571" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-571">[570]</a></sup> This recent trend also sometimes incorporates the "<a href="/wiki/Boodle_fight" title="Boodle fight">Boodle fight</a>" concept (as popularized and coined by the Philippine Army), wherein banana leaves are used as giant plates on top of which rice portions and Filipino viands are placed all together for a filial, friendly or communal <i>kamayan</i> feasting.<sup id="cite_ref-572" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-572">[571]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Mass_media">Mass media</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Media_in_the_Philippines" class="mw-redirect" title="Media in the Philippines">Media in the Philippines</a>, <a href="/wiki/Television_in_the_Philippines" title="Television in the Philippines">Television in the Philippines</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Radio_in_the_Philippines" title="Radio in the Philippines">Radio in the Philippines</a>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Media_in_the_Philippines" class="mw-redirect" title="Media in the Philippines">Philippine media</a> uses mainly Filipino and English, though <a href="/wiki/Broadcasting" title="Broadcasting">broadcasting</a> has shifted to Filipino.<sup id="cite_ref-BrownGanguly2003_291-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BrownGanguly2003-291">[290]</a></sup> There are large numbers of both <a href="/wiki/List_of_radio_stations_in_the_Philippines" title="List of radio stations in the Philippines">radio stations</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_newspapers_in_the_Philippines" title="List of newspapers in the Philippines">newspapers</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-BBC_Pilipinas_573-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBC_Pilipinas-573">[572]</a></sup> The top three newspapers by nationwide readership as well as credibility<sup id="cite_ref-574" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-574">[573]</a></sup> are the <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Daily_Inquirer" title="Philippine Daily Inquirer">Philippine Daily Inquirer</a>, <a href="/wiki/Manila_Bulletin" title="Manila Bulletin">Manila Bulletin</a>, and <a href="/wiki/The_Philippine_Star" title="The Philippine Star">The Philippine Star</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-575" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-575">[574]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-576" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-576">[575]</a></sup> While freedom of the press is protected by the constitution, the country is very dangerous for journalists.<sup id="cite_ref-BBC_Pilipinas_573-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBC_Pilipinas-573">[572]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-577" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-577">[576]</a></sup> The dominant <a href="/wiki/Television_in_the_Philippines" title="Television in the Philippines">television</a> networks were <a href="/wiki/ABS-CBN" title="ABS-CBN">ABS-CBN</a> and <a href="/wiki/GMA_Network" title="GMA Network">GMA</a>, both being free to air.<sup id="cite_ref-BBC_Pilipinas_573-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBC_Pilipinas-573">[572]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/ABS-CBN" title="ABS-CBN">ABS-CBN</a>, at the time the largest network<sup id="cite_ref-Gutierrez_578-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Gutierrez-578">[577]</a></sup> was shut down following a cease and desist order issued by the <a href="/wiki/National_Telecommunications_Commission_(Philippines)" title="National Telecommunications Commission (Philippines)">National Telecommunications Commission</a> on May 5, 2020, a day after the <a href="/wiki/ABS-CBN_franchise_renewal_controversy" title="ABS-CBN franchise renewal controversy">expiration of the network's franchise</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-579" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-579">[578]</a></sup> Prior to this move, Duterte accused ABS-CBN of being biased against his administration and vowed to block the renewal of their franchise. However, critics of the Duterte administration, human rights groups, and media unions said the shutdown of ABS-CBN was an attack on press freedom.<sup id="cite_ref-Gutierrez_578-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Gutierrez-578">[577]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-580" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-580">[579]</a></sup> On July 10, 2020, the House of Representatives declined a renewal of ABS-CBN's TV and radio franchise, voted 70–11.<sup id="cite_ref-Gutierrez_578-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Gutierrez-578">[577]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>TV, the <a href="/wiki/Internet" title="Internet">Internet</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-581" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-581">[580]</a></sup> and social media, particularly <a href="/wiki/Facebook" title="Facebook">Facebook</a>, remain the top source of news and information for majority of Filipinos as newspaper readership continues to decline.<sup id="cite_ref-582" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-582">[581]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-583" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-583">[582]</a></sup> English broadsheets are popular among executives, professionals and students.<sup id="cite_ref-ThompsonRogerM2003_584-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ThompsonRogerM2003-584">[583]</a></sup> Cheaper Tagalog tabloids, which feature crime, sex, gossips and gore, saw a rise in the 1990s, and tend to be popular among the masses, particularly in Manila.<sup id="cite_ref-ThompsonRogerM2003_584-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ThompsonRogerM2003-584">[583]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-585" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-585">[584]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-586" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-586">[585]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cinema">Cinema</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_the_Philippines" title="Cinema of the Philippines">Cinema of the Philippines</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Philippine cinema began at the end of the 19th century,<sup id="cite_ref-587" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-587">[586]</a></sup> and made up around 20% of the domestic market during the second half of the 20th century. During the 21st century however, the industry has struggled to compete with larger budget foreign films.<sup id="cite_ref-588" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-588">[587]</a></sup> Critically acclaimed Philippines films include <i><a href="/wiki/Himala" title="Himala">Himala</a></i> (<i>Miracle</i>).<sup id="cite_ref-589" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-589">[588]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-590" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-590">[589]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-591" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-591">[590]</a></sup> Moving pictures were first shown in the Philippines on January 1, 1897.<sup id="cite_ref-592" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-592">[591]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-593" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-593">[592]</a></sup> All films were all in Spanish since Philippine cinema was first introduced during the final years of the Spanish era of the country. Antonio Ramos was the first known movie producer.<sup id="cite_ref-594" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-594">[593]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-595" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-595">[594]</a></sup> Meanwhile, <a href="/wiki/Jose_Nepomuceno" class="mw-redirect" title="Jose Nepomuceno">Jose Nepomuceno</a> was dubbed as the "Father of Philippine Movies".<sup id="cite_ref-596" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-596">[595]</a></sup> His work marked the start of the local production of movies. Production companies remained small during the era of <a href="/wiki/Silent_film" title="Silent film">silent film</a>, but 1933 saw the emergence of sound films and the arrival of the first significant production company. The postwar 1940s and the 1950s are regarded as a high point for Philippine cinema.<sup id="cite_ref-books.google.com_113-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-books.google.com-113">[112]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The growing dominance of <a href="/wiki/Hollywood" title="Hollywood">Hollywood</a> films and the cost of production has severely reduced local filmmaking.<sup id="cite_ref-bleak_597-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bleak-597">[596]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-dying_598-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dying-598">[597]</a></sup> Nonetheless, some local films continue to find success.<sup id="cite_ref-TadhanaABSCBN20150220_599-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TadhanaABSCBN20150220-599">[598]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-TadhanaABSCBN20150303_600-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TadhanaABSCBN20150303-600">[599]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">Sports</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Sports_in_the_Philippines" title="Sports in the Philippines">Sports in the Philippines</a> and <a href="/wiki/Traditional_games_in_the_Philippines" title="Traditional games in the Philippines">Traditional games in the Philippines</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:New_Clark_City_Sports_Hub_BCDA.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/New_Clark_City_Sports_Hub_BCDA.jpg/220px-New_Clark_City_Sports_Hub_BCDA.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="148" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/New_Clark_City_Sports_Hub_BCDA.jpg/330px-New_Clark_City_Sports_Hub_BCDA.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/New_Clark_City_Sports_Hub_BCDA.jpg/440px-New_Clark_City_Sports_Hub_BCDA.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="807"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:New_Clark_City_Sports_Hub_BCDA.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/New_Clark_City_Sports_Hub" title="New Clark City Sports Hub">Sports Hub</a> in the <a href="/wiki/New_Clark_City" title="New Clark City">New Clark City</a>, <a href="/wiki/Capas" title="Capas">Capas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tarlac" title="Tarlac">Tarlac</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Basketball_in_the_Philippines" title="Basketball in the Philippines">Basketball</a> is played at both amateur and professional levels and is considered to be the most popular sport in the Philippines.<sup id="cite_ref-601" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-601">[600]</a></sup> In 2010, <a href="/wiki/Manny_Pacquiao" title="Manny Pacquiao">Manny Pacquiao</a> was named <a href="/wiki/Edward_J._Neil_Trophy#2000s" class="mw-redirect" title="Edward J. Neil Trophy">"Fighter of the Decade"</a> for the 2000s by the <a href="/wiki/Boxing_Writers_Association_of_America" title="Boxing Writers Association of America">Boxing Writers Association of America</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Pacquiao_named_Fighter_of_the_Decade_602-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pacquiao_named_Fighter_of_the_Decade-602">[601]</a></sup> The national <a href="/wiki/Filipino_martial_arts" title="Filipino martial arts">martial art</a> and sport of the country is <a href="/wiki/Arnis_de_Mano" class="mw-redirect" title="Arnis de Mano">Arnis</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-603" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-603">[602]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-604" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-604">[603]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Sabong" class="mw-redirect" title="Sabong">Sabong</a> or <a href="/wiki/Cockfighting" class="mw-redirect" title="Cockfighting">cockfighting</a> is another popular entertainment especially among Filipino men, and was documented by Magellan's voyage as a pastime in the kingdom of Taytay.<sup id="cite_ref-605" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-605">[604]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Beginning in <a href="/wiki/Philippines_at_the_1924_Summer_Olympics" title="Philippines at the 1924 Summer Olympics">1924</a>, the Philippines has competed in every <a href="/wiki/Summer_Olympic_Games" title="Summer Olympic Games">Summer Olympic Games</a>, except when they participated in the <a href="/wiki/American-led_boycott_of_the_1980_Summer_Olympics" class="mw-redirect" title="American-led boycott of the 1980 Summer Olympics">American-led boycott of the 1980 Summer Olympics</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-606" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-606">[605]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-607" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-607">[606]</a></sup> The Philippines is also the first <a href="/wiki/Tropical_nations_at_the_Winter_Olympics" title="Tropical nations at the Winter Olympics">tropical nation</a> to compete at the <a href="/wiki/Winter_Olympic_Games" title="Winter Olympic Games">Winter Olympic Games</a> <a href="/wiki/Philippines_at_the_1972_Winter_Olympics" title="Philippines at the 1972 Winter Olympics">debuting in the 1972</a> edition.<sup id="cite_ref-608" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-608">[607]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-609" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-609">[608]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div style="clear:both;"></div>

      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h2>

            </ul> 
           </div> <p>In the recognized optional languages of the Philippines: </p> 
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r998391716">
           <div class="div-col" style="column-width: 30em;"> 
            <ul>
             <li><a href="/wiki/Spanish_language" title="Spanish language">Spanish</a>: <i lang="es">República de Filipinas</i></li> 
             <li><a href="/wiki/Arabic_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a>: <span lang="ar" dir="rtl">جمهورية الفلبين</span>‎, <small><a href="/wiki/Romanization_of_Arabic" title="Romanization of Arabic">romanized</a>:&nbsp;</small><i lang="ar-Latn" title="Arabic-language romanization">Jumhūriyyat al-Filibbīn</i></li>
            </ul> 
           </div></span> </li>

      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span></h2>

         <li id="cite_note-ra8491-1"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-ra8491_1-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><style .cs1-kern-left,.mw-parser-output .cs1-kern-wl-left{padding-left:0.2em}.mw-parser-output .cs1-kern-right,.mw-parser-output .cs1-kern-wl-right{padding-right:0.2em}.mw-parser-output .citation .mw-selflink{font-weight:inherit}</style><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.officialgazette.gov.ph/1998/02/12/republic-act-no-8491/">"Republic act no. 8491"</a>. Republic of the Philippines<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">March 8,</span> 2014</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Republic+act+no.+8491&amp;rft.pub=Republic+of+the+Philippines&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.officialgazette.gov.ph%2F1998%2F02%2F12%2Frepublic-act-no-8491%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APhilippines" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-7_mother_languages-2"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-7_mother_languages_2-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-7_mother_languages_2-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/317280/news/nation/deped-adds-7-languages-to-mother-tongue-based-education-for-kinder-to-grade-3">DepEd adds 7 languages to mother tongue-based education for Kinder to Grade 3</a>. <a href="/wiki/GMA_News" class="mw-redirect" title="GMA News">GMA News</a>.          <li id="cite_note-Galang-21"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Galang_21-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFGalang1957" class="citation book cs1"><a href="/wiki/Zoilo_Galang" title="Zoilo Galang">Galang, Zoilo M.</a>, ed. Floro. p.&nbsp;46.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Encyclopedia+of+the+Philippines%2C+Volume+15&amp;rft.pages=46&amp;rft.edition=3rd&amp;rft.pub=E.+Floro&amp;rft.date=1957&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3Dlt5uAAAAMAAJ%26q%3Dislas%2Bdel%2Bponiente%2B&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APhilippines" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li>

           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFTarling1999" class="citation book cs1">Tarling, Nicholas (1999). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=jtsMLNmMzbkC"><i>The Cambridge History of Southeast Asia – Volume One, Part Two – From c. 1500 to c. 1800</i></a>.          <li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEScott198417-33"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEScott198417_33-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFScott1984">Scott 1984</a>, p.&nbsp;17.</span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-34"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-34">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">

Salkin &amp; Sharon La Boda (1996). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=vWLRxJEU49EC&amp;pg=PA565"><i>International Dictionary of Historic Places: Asia and Oceania</i></a>.
