Retrieved <span class="nowrap">January 7,</span> 2010</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=International+Dictionary+of+Historic+Places%3A+Asia+and+Oceania&amp;rft.pages=565-569&amp;rft.pub=Taylor+%26+Francis&amp;rft.date=1996&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-884964-04-6&amp;rft.au=Ring%2C+Trudy&amp;rft.au=Robert+M.+Salkin&amp;rft.au=Sharon+La+Boda&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DvWLRxJEU49EC%26pg%3DPA565&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APhilippines" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-49"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-49">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation book cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/historical-atlas-of-the-republic/page/n65/mode/2up"><i>Historical Atlas of the Republic</i></a>. The Presidential Communications Development and Strategic Planning Office. 2016. p.&nbsp;64. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-971-95551-6-2" title="Special:BookSources/978-971-95551-6-2"><bdi>978-971-95551-6-2</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Historical+Atlas+of+the+Republic&amp;rft.pages=64&amp;rft.pub=The+Presidential+Communications+Development+and+Strategic+Planning+Office&amp;rft.date=2016&amp;rft.isbn=978-971-95551-6-2&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Farchive.org%2Fdetails%2Fhistorical-atlas-of-the-republic%2Fpage%2Fn65%2Fmode%2F2up&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APhilippines" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-Carley2013-50"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Carley2013_50-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFCarley2013" class="citation book cs1">Carley, Michael (November 4, 2013) [2001]. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=ycT9AQAAQBAJ&amp;q=Barangay+city-states&amp;pg=PA108">"7"</a>. <i>Urban Development and Civil Society: The Role of Communities in Sustainable Cities</i>. Routledge. p.&nbsp;108. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9781134200504" title="Special:BookSources/9781134200504"><bdi>9781134200504</bdi></a><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">September 11,</span> 2020</span>. <q>Each boat carried a large family group, and the master of the boat retained power as leader, or datu, of the village established by his family. This form of village social organization can be found as early as the 13th century in Panay, Bohol, Cebu, Samar and Leyte in the Visayas, and in Batangas, Pampanga and Tondo in Luzon. Evidence suggests a considerable degree of independence as small city-states with their heads known as datu, rajah or sultan.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=7&amp;rft.btitle=Urban+Development+and+Civil+Society%3A+The+Role+of+Communities+in+Sustainable+Cities&amp;rft.pages=108&amp;rft.pub=Routledge&amp;rft.date=2013-11-04&amp;rft.isbn=9781134200504&amp;rft.aulast=Carley&amp;rft.aufirst=Michael&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DycT9AQAAQBAJ%26q%3DBarangay%2Bcity-states%26pg%3DPA108&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APhilippines" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-51"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-51">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFTan2008" class="citation book cs1">Tan, Samuel K. (2008). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=pw5FWmdNmj8C&amp;pg=PA37"><i>A History of the Philippines</i></a>. UP Press. p.&nbsp;37. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-971-542-568-1" title="Special:BookSources/978-971-542-568-1"><bdi>978-971-542-568-1</bdi></a><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">August 10,</span> 2020</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=A+History+of+the+Philippines&amp;rft.pages=37&amp;rft.pub=UP+Press&amp;rft.date=2008&amp;rft.isbn=978-971-542-568-1&amp;rft.aulast=Tan&amp;rft.aufirst=Samuel+K.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3Dpw5FWmdNmj8C%26pg%3DPA37&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APhilippines" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-52"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-52">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFMallari2014" class="citation news cs1">Mallari, Perry Gil S. (April 5, 2014). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.manilatimes.net/2014/04/05/sports/columnists-sports/war-and-peace-in-precolonial-philippines/87714/">"War and peace in precolonial Philippines"</a>. <i>Manila Times</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">October 24,</span> 2020</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Manila+Times&amp;rft.atitle=War+and+peace+in+precolonial+Philippines&amp;rft.date=2014-04-05&amp;rft.aulast=Mallari&amp;rft.aufirst=Perry+Gil+S.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.manilatimes.net%2F2014%2F04%2F05%2Fsports%2Fcolumnists-sports%2Fwar-and-peace-in-precolonial-philippines%2F87714%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APhilippines" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-53"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-53">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFNewson2009" class="citation book cs1">Newson, Linda (2009) [2009]. "2". <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.universitypressscholarship.com/view/10.21313/hawaii/9780824832728.001.0001/upso-9780824832728"><i>Conquest and Pestilence in the Early Spanish Philippines</i></a>. University of Hawaii Press. p.&nbsp;18. <a href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.21313%2Fhawaii%2F9780824832728.001.0001">10.21313/hawaii/9780824832728.001.0001</a>. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9780824832728" title="Special:BookSources/9780824832728"><bdi>9780824832728</bdi></a><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">September 11,</span> 2020</span>. <q>Given the significance of the size and distribution of the population to the spread of diseases and their ability to become endemic, it is worth commenting briefly on the physical and human geography of the Philippines. The hot and humid tropical climate would have generally favored the propagation of many diseases, especially water-borne infections, though there might be regional or seasonal variations in climate that might affect the incidence of some diseases. In general, however, the fact that the Philippines comprise some seven thousand islands, some of which are uninhabited even today, would have discouraged the spread of infections, as would the low population density.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=2&amp;rft.btitle=Conquest+and+Pestilence+in+the+Early+Spanish+Philippines&amp;rft.pages=18&amp;rft.pub=University+of+Hawaii+Press&amp;rft.date=2009&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.21313%2Fhawaii%2F9780824832728.001.0001&amp;rft.isbn=9780824832728&amp;rft.aulast=Newson&amp;rft.aufirst=Linda&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.universitypressscholarship.com%2Fview%2F10.21313%2Fhawaii%2F9780824832728.001.0001%2Fupso-9780824832728&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APhilippines" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-etymology-54"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-etymology_54-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFZaide,_Gregorio_F.Sonia_M._Zaide2004" class="citation book cs1">Zaide, Gregorio F.; Sonia M. Zaide (2004). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/philippinehistor0000zaid/page/52/mode/2up"><i>Philippine History and Government</i></a> (6th&nbsp;ed.). All-Nations Publishing Company. pp.&nbsp;52–55. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/971-642-222-9" title="Special:BookSources/971-642-222-9"><bdi>971-642-222-9</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Philippine+History+and+Government&amp;rft.pages=52-55&amp;rft.edition=6th&amp;rft.pub=All-Nations+Publishing+Company&amp;rft.date=2004&amp;rft.isbn=971-642-222-9&amp;rft.au=Zaide%2C+Gregorio+F.&amp;rft.au=Sonia+M.+Zaide&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Farchive.org%2Fdetails%2Fphilippinehistor0000zaid%2Fpage%2F52%2Fmode%2F2up&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APhilippines" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-55"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-55">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFEducation1961" class="citation book cs1">Education, United States.          <li id="cite_note-Basques-56"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Basques_56-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Basques_56-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFde_Borja2005" class="citation book cs1">de Borja, Marciano R.          <li id="cite_note-57"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-57">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFFernando_A._Santiago_Jr.2006" class="citation journal cs1">Fernando A. Santiago Jr. (2006). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://ejournals.ph/article.php?id=7887">"Isang Maikling Kasaysayan ng Pandacan, Maynila 1589–1898"</a>. <i>Malay</i>. <b>19</b> (<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.philjol.info/philjol/index.php/MALAY/article/view/80">2</a>): 70–87<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">July 18,</span> 2008</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Malay&amp;rft.atitle=Isang+Maikling+Kasaysayan+ng+Pandacan%2C+Maynila+1589%E2%80%931898&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=%5Bhttp%3A%2F%2Fwww.philjol.info%2Fphiljol%2Findex.php%2FMALAY%2Farticle%2Fview%2F80+2%5D&amp;rft.pages=70-87&amp;rft.date=2006&amp;rft.au=Fernando+A.+Santiago+Jr.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fejournals.ph%2Farticle.php%3Fid%3D7887&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APhilippines" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-58"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-58">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFManuel_L._Quezon_III2017" class="citation web cs1">Manuel L. Quezon III (June 12, 2017). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.spot.ph/newsfeatures/the-latest-news-features/70433/philippine-map-palau-a1507-20170612-lfrm3">"The Philippines Isn't What It Used to Be"</a>. <i>SPOT.PH</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">October 24,</span> 2020</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=SPOT.PH&amp;rft.atitle=The+Philippines+Isn%27t+What+It+Used+to+Be&amp;rft.date=2017-06-12&amp;rft.au=Manuel+L.+Quezon+III&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.spot.ph%2Fnewsfeatures%2Fthe-latest-news-features%2F70433%2Fphilippine-map-palau-a1507-20170612-lfrm3&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APhilippines" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-Andrade-59"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Andrade_59-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFAndrade2005" class="citation book cs1">Andrade, Tonio (2005). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.gutenberg-e.org/andrade/andrade04.html">"La Isla Hermosa: The Rise of the Spanish Colony in Northern Taiwan"</a>. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.gutenberg-e.org/andrade/"><i>How Taiwan Became Chinese: Dutch, Spanish and Han colonialization in the Seventeenth Century</i></a>. Columbia University Press.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=La+Isla+Hermosa%3A+The+Rise+of+the+Spanish+Colony+in+Northern+Taiwan&amp;rft.btitle=How+Taiwan+Became+Chinese%3A+Dutch%2C+Spanish+and+Han+colonialization+in+the+Seventeenth+Century&amp;rft.pub=Columbia+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2005&amp;rft.aulast=Andrade&amp;rft.aufirst=Tonio&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.gutenberg-e.org%2Fandrade%2Fandrade04.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APhilippines" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-60"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-60">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFHawkley2014" class="citation journal cs1">Hawkley, Ethan (2014). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.researchgate.net/publication/276488434">"Reviving the Reconquista in Southeast Asia: Moros and the Making of the Philippines, 1565–1662"</a>. <i>Journal of World History</i>. University of Hawai'i Press. <b>25</b> (2–3): 288. <a href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1353%2Fjwh.2014.0014">10.1353/jwh.2014.0014</a>. <a href="/wiki/S2CID_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="S2CID (identifier)">S2CID</a>&nbsp;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://api.semanticscholar.org/CorpusID:143692647">143692647</a>. <q>The early modern revival of the Reconquista in the Philippines had a profound effect on the islands, one that is still being felt today. As described above, the Spanish Reconquista served to unify Christians against a common Moro enemy, helping to bring together Castilian, Catalan, Galician, and Basque peoples into a single political unit: Spain. In precolonial times, the Philippine islands were a divided and unspecified part of the Malay archipelago, one inhabited by dozens of ethnolinguistic groups, residing in countless independent villages, strewn across thousands of islands. By the end of the seventeenth century, however, a dramatic change had happened in the archipelago. A multiethnic community had come together to form the colonial beginnings of a someday nation: the Philippines. The powerful influence of Christian-Moro antagonisms on the formation of the early Philippines remains evident more than four hundred years later, as the Philippine national government continues to grapple with Moro separatists groups, even in 2013.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+World+History&amp;rft.atitle=Reviving+the+Reconquista+in+Southeast+Asia%3A+Moros+and+the+Making+of+the+Philippines%2C+1565%E2%80%931662&amp;rft.volume=25&amp;rft.issue=2%E2%80%933&amp;rft.pages=288&amp;rft.date=2014&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1353%2Fjwh.2014.0014&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fapi.semanticscholar.org%2FCorpusID%3A143692647%23id-name%3DS2CID&amp;rft.aulast=Hawkley&amp;rft.aufirst=Ethan&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.researchgate.net%2Fpublication%2F276488434&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APhilippines" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-61"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-61">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFGuillermo2012" class="citation book cs1">Guillermo, Artemio (2012) [2012]. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=wmgX9M_yETIC&amp;q=divide+and+conquer+philippines&amp;pg=PA374"><i>Historical Dictionary of the Philippines</i></a>. The Scarecrow Press Inc. p.&nbsp;374. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9780810875111" title="Special:BookSources/9780810875111"><bdi>9780810875111</bdi></a><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">September 11,</span> 2020</span>. <q>To pursue their mission of conquest, the Spaniards dealt individually with each settlement or village and with each province or island until the entire Philippine archipelago was brought under imperial control. They saw to it that the people remained divided or compartmentalized and with the minimum of contact or communication. The Spaniards adopted the policy of divide et impera (divide and conquer).</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Historical+Dictionary+of+the+Philippines&amp;rft.pages=374&amp;rft.pub=The+Scarecrow+Press+Inc.&amp;rft.date=2012&amp;rft.isbn=9780810875111&amp;rft.aulast=Guillermo&amp;rft.aufirst=Artemio&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DwmgX9M_yETIC%26q%3Ddivide%2Band%2Bconquer%2Bphilippines%26pg%3DPA374&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APhilippines" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-auto5-62"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-auto5_62-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFLlobet2015" class="citation journal cs1">Llobet, Ruth de (June 23, 2015). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/journal-of-southeast-asian-studies/article/philippines-a-mountain-of-difference-the-lumad-in-early-colonial-mindanao-by-oona-paredes-ithaca-southeast-asia-program-publications-cornell-university-2013-pp-195-maps-appendices-notes-bibliography-index/10F3EEAA42554FF4996D35ADA368B7F5">"The Philippines.          <li id="cite_note-Halili-72"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Halili_72-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFHalili2004" class="citation book cs1">Halili, Maria Christine N.          <li id="cite_note-Ooi2004-73"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Ooi2004_73-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Ooi2004_73-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Ooi2004_73-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFOoi2004" class="citation book cs1">Ooi, Keat Gin (2004). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com.ph/books?id=QKgraWbb7yoC&amp;pg=PA1077"><i>Southeast Asia: A Historical Encyclopedia, from Angkor Wat to East Timor</i></a>. ABC-CLIO. p.&nbsp;1077. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-57607-770-2" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-57607-770-2"><bdi>978-1-57607-770-2</bdi></a><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">January 29,</span> 2021</span>. <q>Because local resources did not yield enough money to maintain the colonial administration, the government was constantly running a deficit and had to be supported with an annual subsidy from the Spanish government in Mexico, the situado.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Southeast+Asia%3A+A+Historical+Encyclopedia%2C+from+Angkor+Wat+to+East+Timor&amp;rft.pages=1077&amp;rft.pub=ABC-CLIO&amp;rft.date=2004&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-57607-770-2&amp;rft.aulast=Ooi&amp;rft.aufirst=Keat+Gin&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com.ph%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DQKgraWbb7yoC%26pg%3DPA1077&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APhilippines" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-74"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-74">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFIaccarino2017" class="citation journal cs1">Iaccarino, Ubaldo (October 2017). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://ostasien-verlag.de/zeitschriften/crossroads/cr/pdf/CR_16_2017_099-120_Iaccarino.pdf">"<span class="cs1-kern-left">"</span>The Centre of a Circle": Manila's Trade with East and Southeast Asia at the Turn of the Sixteenth Century"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. <i>Crossroads</i>. OSTASIEN Verlag. <b>16</b>. <a href="/wiki/ISSN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISSN (identifier)">ISSN</a>&nbsp;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//www.worldcat.org/issn/2190-8796">2190-8796</a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Crossroads&amp;rft.atitle=%22The+Centre+of+a+Circle%22%3A+Manila%27s+Trade+with+East+and+Southeast+Asia+at+the+Turn+of+the+Sixteenth+Century&amp;rft.volume=16&amp;rft.date=2017-10&amp;rft.issn=2190-8796&amp;rft.aulast=Iaccarino&amp;rft.aufirst=Ubaldo&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fostasien-verlag.de%2Fzeitschriften%2Fcrossroads%2Fcr%2Fpdf%2FCR_16_2017_099-120_Iaccarino.pdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APhilippines" class="Z3988"></span><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability"><span title="The material near this tag failed verification of its source citation(s).          <li id="cite_note-75"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-75">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFDolan1991">Dolan 1991</a>, <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://countrystudies.us/philippines/4.htm">The Early Spanish Period</a>.</span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-76"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-76">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"> 
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFMehl2016" class="citation book cs1">Mehl, Eva Maria (2016). "Chapter 6 – Unruly Mexicans in Manila". <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.cambridge.org/core/books/forced-migration-in-the-spanish-pacific-world/unruly-mexicans-in-manila/EF2599210A0715A5A91B23BB9D84B96C"><i>Forced Migration in the Spanish Pacific World From Mexico to the Philippines, 1765–1811</i></a>. Cambridge University Press. <a href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1017%2FCBO9781316480120.007">10.1017/CBO9781316480120.007</a>. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9781316480120" title="Special:BookSources/9781316480120"><bdi>9781316480120</bdi></a>. <q>In Governor Anda y Salazar’s opinion, an important part of the problem of vagrancy was the fact that Mexicans and Spanish disbanded after finishing their military or prison terms "all over the islands, even the most distant, looking for subsistence.~CSIC riel 208 leg.14</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Chapter+6+%E2%80%93+Unruly+Mexicans+in+Manila&amp;rft.btitle=Forced+Migration+in+the+Spanish+Pacific+World+From+Mexico+to+the+Philippines%2C+1765%E2%80%931811&amp;rft.pub=Cambridge+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2016&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1017%2FCBO9781316480120.007&amp;rft.isbn=9781316480120&amp;rft.aulast=Mehl&amp;rft.aufirst=Eva+Maria&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.cambridge.org%2Fcore%2Fbooks%2Fforced-migration-in-the-spanish-pacific-world%2Funruly-mexicans-in-manila%2FEF2599210A0715A5A91B23BB9D84B96C&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APhilippines" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-77"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-77">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Garcıa de los Arcos, "Grupos etnicos," ´ 65–66 
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFGarcia_de_los_Arcos1999" class="citation web cs1">Garcia de los Arcos, Maria Fernanda (1999). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.persee.fr/doc/arch_0044-8613_1999_num_57_2_3515">"Grupos éthnicos y Clases sociales en las Filipinas de Finales del Siglo XVIII"</a><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">August 19,</span> 2020</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Grupos+%C3%A9thnicos+y+Clases+sociales+en+las+Filipinas+de+Finales+del+Siglo+XVIII&amp;rft.date=1999&amp;rft.aulast=Garcia+de+los+Arcos&amp;rft.aufirst=Maria+Fernanda&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.persee.fr%2Fdoc%2Farch_0044-8613_1999_num_57_2_3515&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APhilippines" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-78"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-78">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"> 
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFMehl2016" class="citation book cs1">Mehl, Eva Maria (2016). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=h1Y2DAAAQBAJ&amp;q=CSIC+ser.+Consultas+riel+301+leg.8&amp;pg=PA256">"Chapter 1 – Intertwined Histories in the Pacific"</a>. <i>Forced Migration in the Spanish Pacific World From Mexico to the Philippines, 1765–1811</i>. Cambridge University Press. p.&nbsp;246. <a href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1017%2FCBO9781316480120.007">10.1017/CBO9781316480120.007</a>. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9781316480120" title="Special:BookSources/9781316480120"><bdi>9781316480120</bdi></a>. <q>The military organization of Manila might have depended to some degree on non-European groups, but colonial authorities measured a successful imperial policy of defense on the amount of European and American recruits that could be accounted for in the military forces.~CSIC ser. Consultas riel 301 leg.8 (1794)</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Chapter+1+%E2%80%93+Intertwined+Histories+in+the+Pacific&amp;rft.btitle=Forced+Migration+in+the+Spanish+Pacific+World+From+Mexico+to+the+Philippines%2C+1765%E2%80%931811&amp;rft.pages=246&amp;rft.pub=Cambridge+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2016&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1017%2FCBO9781316480120.007&amp;rft.isbn=9781316480120&amp;rft.aulast=Mehl&amp;rft.aufirst=Eva+Maria&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3Dh1Y2DAAAQBAJ%26q%3DCSIC%2Bser.%2BConsultas%2Briel%2B301%2Bleg.8%26pg%3DPA256&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APhilippines" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-ReferenceC-79"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-ReferenceC_79-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://filipinokastila.tripod.com/FilMex.html">"Filipino-Mexican-Central-and-South American Connection, Tales of Two Sisters: Manila and Mexico"</a>. June 21, 1997<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">January 1,</span> 2021</span>. <q>Tomás de Comyn, general manager of the Compañia Real de Filipinas, in 1810 estimated that out of a total population of 2,515,406, "the European Spaniards, and Spanish creoles and mestizos do not exceed 4,000 persons of both sexes and all ages, and the distinct castes or modifications known in America under the name of mulatto, quarteroons, etc., although found in the Philippine Islands, are generally confounded in the three classes of pure Indians, Chinese mestizos and Chinese." In other words, the Mexicans who had arrived in the previous century had so intermingled with the local population that distinctions of origin had been forgotten by the 19th century. The Mexicans who came with Legázpi and aboard succeeding vessels had blended with the local residents so well that their country of origin had been erased from memory.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Filipino-Mexican-Central-and-South+American+Connection%2C+Tales+of+Two+Sisters%3A+Manila+and+Mexico&amp;rft.date=1997-06-21&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Ffilipinokastila.tripod.com%2FFilMex.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APhilippines" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-80"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-80">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">(Page 10) 
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFPérez2015" class="citation thesis cs1">Pérez, Marilola (2015). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20210114232555/https://escholarship.org/content/qt6xj6f1jt/qt6xj6f1jt_noSplash_fd187448d1120e8904337fe47b42df2a.pdf"><i>Cavite Chabacano Philippine Creole Spanish: Description and Typology</i></a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span> (PhD). University of California, Berkeley. Archived from <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://escholarship.org/uc/item/6xj6f1jt">the original</a> on January 14, 2021. <q>The galleon activities also attracted a great number of Mexican men that arrived from the Mexican Pacific coast as ships’ crewmembers (Grant 2009: 230). Mexicans were administrators, priests and soldiers (guachinangos or hombres de pueblo) (Bernal 1964: 188) many though, integrated into the peasant society, even becoming tulisanes ‘bandits’ who in the late 18th century “infested” Cavite and led peasant revolts (Medina 2002: 66). Meanwhile, in the Spanish garrisons, Spanish was used among administrators and priests. Nonetheless, there is not enough historical information on the social role of these men. In fact some of the few references point to a quick integration into the local society: “los hombres del pueblo, los soldados y marinos, anónimos, olvidados, absorbidos en su totalidad por la población Filipina.” (Bernal 1964: 188). In addition to the Manila-Acapulco galleon, a complex commercial maritime system circulated European and Asian commodities including slaves. During the 17th century, Portuguese vessels traded with the ports of Manila and Cavite, even after the prohibition of 1644 (Seijas 2008: 21). Crucially, the commercial activities included the smuggling and trade of slaves: “from the Moluccas, and Malacca, and India… with the monsoon winds” carrying “clove spice, cinnamon, and pepper and black slaves, and Kafir [slaves]” (Antonio de Morga cf Seijas 2008: 21).” Though there is no data on the numbers of slaves in Cavite, the numbers in Manila suggest a significant fraction of the population had been brought in as slaves by the Portuguese vessels. By 1621, slaves in Manila numbered 1,970 out of a population of 6,110. This influx of slaves continued until late in the 17th century; according to contemporary cargo records in 1690, 200 slaves departed from Malacca to Manila (Seijas 2008: 21). Different ethnicities were favored for different labor; Africans were brought to work on the agricultural production, and skilled slaves from India served as caulkers and carpenters. </q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Adissertation&amp;rft.title=Cavite+Chabacano+Philippine+Creole+Spanish%3A+Description+and+Typology&amp;rft.inst=University+of+California%2C+Berkeley&amp;rft.date=2015&amp;rft.aulast=P%C3%A9rez&amp;rft.aufirst=Marilola&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fescholarship.org%2Fuc%2Fitem%2F6xj6f1jt&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APhilippines" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-81"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-81">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFTatiana_Seijas2014" class="citation book cs1">Tatiana Seijas (2014). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.google.com/books/edition/Asian_Slaves_in_Colonial_Mexico/YCWjAwAAQBAJ?hl=en&amp;gbpv=1&amp;pg=PA32">"The Diversity and Reach of the Manila Slave Market"</a>. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.google.com/books/edition/Asian_Slaves_in_Colonial_Mexico/YCWjAwAAQBAJ"><i>Asian Slaves in Colonial Mexico</i></a>. p.&nbsp;36. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-107-06312-9" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-107-06312-9"><bdi>978-1-107-06312-9</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=The+Diversity+and+Reach+of+the+Manila+Slave+Market&amp;rft.btitle=Asian+Slaves+in+Colonial+Mexico&amp;rft.pages=36&amp;rft.date=2014&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-107-06312-9&amp;rft.au=Tatiana+Seijas&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.google.com%2Fbooks%2Fedition%2FAsian_Slaves_in_Colonial_Mexico%2FYCWjAwAAQBAJ%3Fhl%3Den%26gbpv%3D1%26pg%3DPA32&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APhilippines" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-82"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-82">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFNewson2009" class="citation book cs1">Newson, Linda A. (April 16, 2009). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com.ph/books?id=A40BEAAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA7"><i>Conquest and Pestilence in the Early Spanish Philippines</i></a>. University of Hawaii Press. pp.&nbsp;7–8. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-8248-6197-1" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-8248-6197-1"><bdi>978-0-8248-6197-1</bdi></a><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">January 29,</span> 2021</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Conquest+and+Pestilence+in+the+Early+Spanish+Philippines&amp;rft.pages=7-8&amp;rft.pub=University+of+Hawaii+Press&amp;rft.date=2009-04-16&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-8248-6197-1&amp;rft.aulast=Newson&amp;rft.aufirst=Linda+A.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com.ph%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DA40BEAAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPA7&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APhilippines" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li>

         <li id="cite_note-84"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-84">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFNewson2009" class="citation book cs1">Newson, Linda A.          <li id="cite_note-85"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-85">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">

         <li id="cite_note-tracy1995p12p55-86"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-tracy1995p12p55_86-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFTracy1995">Tracy 1995</a>, pp.&nbsp;12, 55<span class="error harv-error" style="display: none; font-size:100%"> harvnb error: no target: CITEREFTracy1995 (<a href="/wiki/Category:Harv_and_Sfn_template_errors" title="Category:Harv and Sfn template errors">help</a>)</span><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Template:Harvard_citation_documentation#Wikilink_to_citation_does_not_work" title="Template:Harvard citation documentation"><span title="Template:Harvard citation documentation#Wikilink to citation does not work (January 2019)">citation not found</span></a></i>]</sup></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-87"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-87">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFUnited_States_War_Department1903" class="citation book cs1">United States War Department (1903). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com.ph/books?id=g8FMAAAAYAAJ&amp;pg=PA379"><i>Annual Report of the Secretary of War</i></a>. U.S. Government Printing Office. pp.&nbsp;379–398<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">January 29,</span> 2021</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Annual+Report+of+the+Secretary+of+War&amp;rft.pages=379-398&amp;rft.pub=U.S.+Government+Printing+Office&amp;rft.date=1903&amp;rft.au=United+States+War+Department&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com.ph%2Fbooks%3Fid%3Dg8FMAAAAYAAJ%26pg%3DPA379&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APhilippines" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-88"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-88">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">

         <li id="cite_note-93"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-93">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFSteinberg2018" class="citation book cs1">Steinberg, David Joel (2018). "Chapter – 3 A SINGULAR AND A PLURAL FOLK". <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=6NFMDwAAQBAJ"><i>THE PHILIPPINES A Singular and a Plural Place</i></a>. Routledge. p.&nbsp;47. <a href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.4324%2F9780429494383">10.4324/9780429494383</a>. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-8133-3755-5" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-8133-3755-5"><bdi>978-0-8133-3755-5</bdi></a>. <q>The cultural identity of the mestizos was challenged as they became increasingly aware that they were true members of neither the indio nor the Chinese community. Increasingly powerful but adrift, they linked with the Spanish mestizos, who were also being challenged because after the Latin American revolutions broke the Spanish Empire, many of the settlers from the New World, Caucasian Creoles born in Mexico or Peru, became suspect in the eyes of the Iberian Spanish. The Spanish Empire had lost its universality.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Chapter+%E2%80%93+3+A+SINGULAR+AND+A+PLURAL+FOLK&amp;rft.btitle=THE+PHILIPPINES+A+Singular+and+a+Plural+Place&amp;rft.pages=47&amp;rft.pub=Routledge&amp;rft.date=2018&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.4324%2F9780429494383&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-8133-3755-5&amp;rft.aulast=Steinberg&amp;rft.aufirst=David+Joel&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3D6NFMDwAAQBAJ&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APhilippines" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li>

           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFBorromeo-Buehler1998" class="citation book cs1">Borromeo-Buehler, Soledad (1998). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=RJnMSmXLvr4C"><i>The Cry of Balintawak: A Contrived Controversy</i></a>.          <li id="cite_note-Duka-103"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Duka_103-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Duka_103-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFDuka2008" class="citation book cs1">Duka, Cecilio D.          <li id="cite_note-Manapat,_Carlos_2010-120"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Manapat,_Carlos_2010_120-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Manapat, Carlos, et al.<i> Economics, Taxation, and Agrarian Reform</i>.            <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20120415034823/http://www.sabrizain.org/malaya/library/connections.pdf">"Developing Regional Minorities in Asia"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. <i>Sabri Zain</i>.          <li id="cite_note-152"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-152">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFMydans1986" class="citation news cs1">Mydans, Seth (September 14, 1986). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20150524190820/https://www.nytimes.com/1986/09/14/weekinreview/philippine-communists-are-spread-widely-but-not-thinly.html">"Philippine Communists Are Spread Widely, but Not Thinly"</a>. <i>The New York Times</i>.          <li id="cite_note-214"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-214">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFWikramanayakeDinersteinLoucks2002" class="citation book cs1">Wikramanayake, Eric D.; Dinerstein, Eric; Loucks, Colby J. (2002). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=_VGRBWqIG2gC&amp;pg=PA480"><i>Terrestrial Ecoregions of the Indo-Pacific: A Conservation Assessment</i></a>.          <li id="cite_note-228"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-228">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFBos,_A.R.Smits,_H.M.2013" class="citation journal cs1">Bos, A.R. &amp; Smits, H.M.          <li id="cite_note-229"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-229">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFBos,_Arthur_R.Gumanao,_Girley_S.2013" class="citation journal cs1">Bos, Arthur R. &amp; Gumanao, Girley S.          <li id="cite_note-238"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-238">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFAgoo2007" class="citation journal cs1">Agoo, Esperanza Maribel G. (June 2007). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://asbp.org.ph/wp-content/uploads/2016/09/907-3032-2-PB.pdf">"Status of Orchid Taxonomy Research in the Philippines"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. <i>Philippine Journal of Systematic Biology</i>. <b>1</b><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">July 23,</span> 2020</span>. <q>There are over 137 genera and about 998 species of orchids so far recorded for the archipelago. This represents about 10% of the total flora of the Philippines. The Philippines ranks second to New Guinea in occurrence of endemic species in the Malesian region.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Philippine+Journal+of+Systematic+Biology&amp;rft.atitle=Status+of+Orchid+Taxonomy+Research+in+the+Philippines&amp;rft.volume=1&amp;rft.date=2007-06&amp;rft.aulast=Agoo&amp;rft.aufirst=Esperanza+Maribel+G.&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fasbp.org.ph%2Fwp-content%2Fuploads%2F2016%2F09%2F907-3032-2-PB.pdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APhilippines" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-239"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-239">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Taguinod, Fioro. Retrieved July 5, 2020.</span> </li>

         <li id="cite_note-241"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-241">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Kirby, Alex.          <li id="cite_note-PAGASA-Climate-242"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-PAGASA-Climate_242-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-PAGASA-Climate_242-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20180418140425/http://bagong.pagasa.dost.gov.ph/information/climate-philippines">"Climate of the Philippines"</a>. <i>Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration</i>. Archived from <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://bagong.pagasa.dost.gov.ph/information/climate-philippines">the original</a> on April 18, 2018<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">July 24,</span> 2020</span>. <q>Based on the average of all weather stations in the Philippines, excluding Baguio, the mean annual temperature is 26.6o C. The coolest months fall in January with a mean temperature of 25.5oC while the warmest month occurs in May with a mean temperature of 28.3oC. Latitude is an insignificant factor in the variation of temperature while altitude shows greater contrast in temperature. Thus, the mean annual temperature of Baguio with an elevation of 1,500 meters is 18.3oC.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Philippine+Atmospheric%2C+Geophysical+and+Astronomical+Services+Administration&amp;rft.atitle=Climate+of+the+Philippines&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fbagong.pagasa.dost.gov.ph%2Finformation%2Fclimate-philippines&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APhilippines" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-cp-243"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-cp_243-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-cp_243-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/Library_of_Congress" title="Library of Congress">Library of Congress</a> – <a href="/wiki/Federal_Research_Division" title="Federal Research Division">Federal Research Division</a>. (March 2006). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://lcweb2.loc.gov/frd/cs/profiles/Philippines.pdf"><i>Country Profile: Philippines</i></a>. Retrieved July 30, 2020. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20150214022548/http://lcweb2.loc.gov/frd/cs/profiles/Philippines.pdf">Archived</a> February 14, 2015, at the <a href="/wiki/Wayback_Machine" title="Wayback Machine">Wayback Machine</a></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-244"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-244">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFChong,_Kee-ChaiIan_R._SmithMaura_S._Lizarondo1982" class="citation book cs1">Chong, Kee-Chai; Ian R. Smith &amp; Maura S. Lizarondo (1982). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20110719181709/http://archive.unu.edu/unupress/unupbooks/80346e/80346E00.htm">"III. The transformation sub-system: cultivation to market size in fishponds"</a>. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.unu.edu/unupress/unupbooks/80346e/80346E00.htm"><i>Economics of the Philippine Milkfish Resource System</i></a>. The United Nations University. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-92-808-0346-4" title="Special:BookSources/978-92-808-0346-4"><bdi>978-92-808-0346-4</bdi></a>. Archived from <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/*/http://www.unu.edu/unupress/unupbooks/80346e/80346E06.htmhtm">the original</a> on July 19, 2011<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">July 4,</span> 2020</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=III.+The+transformation+sub-system%3A+cultivation+to+market+size+in+fishponds&amp;rft.btitle=Economics+of+the+Philippine+Milkfish+Resource+System&amp;rft.pub=The+United+Nations+University&amp;rft.date=1982&amp;rft.isbn=978-92-808-0346-4&amp;rft.au=Chong%2C+Kee-Chai&amp;rft.au=Ian+R.+Smith&amp;rft.au=Maura+S.+Lizarondo&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fweb.archive.org%2Fweb%2F%2A%2Fhttp%3A%2F%2Fwww.unu.edu%2Funupress%2Funupbooks%2F80346e%2F80346E06.htmhtm&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APhilippines" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li>

         <li id="cite_note-Banlaoi-263"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Banlaoi_263-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Banlaoi_263-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Banlaoi_263-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Banlaoi_263-3"><sup><i><b>d</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFBanlaoi2009" class="citation book cs1">Banlaoi, Rommel (October 13, 2009). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=hi_NBQAAQBAJ"><i>Philippine Security in the Age of Terror: National, Regional, and Global Challenges in the Post-9/11 World</i></a>.          <li id="cite_note-272"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-272">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFSoaresTrejautRitoCavadas2016" class="citation journal cs1">Soares, PA; Trejaut, JA; Rito, S; Lin, M; Richards, MB (2016). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4757630">"Resolving the ancestry of Austronesian-speaking populations"</a>. <i>Hum Genet</i>. <b>135</b> (3): 309–26. <a href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1007%2Fs00439-015-1620-z">10.1007/s00439-015-1620-z</a>. <a href="/wiki/PMC_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="PMC (identifier)">PMC</a>&nbsp;<span class="cs1-lock-free" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Hum+Genet&amp;rft.atitle=Resolving+the+ancestry+of+Austronesian-speaking+populations&amp;rft.volume=135&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.pages=309-26&amp;rft.date=2016&amp;rft_id=%2F%2Fwww.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov%2Fpmc%2Farticles%2FPMC4757630%23id-name%3DPMC&amp;rft_id=info%3Apmid%2F26781090&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1007%2Fs00439-015-1620-z&amp;rft.aulast=Soares&amp;rft.aufirst=PA&amp;rft.au=Trejaut%2C+JA&amp;rft.au=Rito%2C+T&amp;rft.au=Cavadas%2C+B&amp;rft.au=Hill%2C+C&amp;rft.au=Eng%2C+KK&amp;rft.au=Mormina%2C+M&amp;rft.au=Brand%C3%A3o%2C+A&amp;rft.au=Fraser%2C+RM&amp;rft.au=Wang%2C+TY&amp;rft.au=Loo%2C+JH&amp;rft.au=Snell%2C+C&amp;rft.au=Ko%2C+TM&amp;rft.au=Amorim%2C+A&amp;rft.au=Pala%2C+M&amp;rft.au=Macaulay%2C+V&amp;rft.au=Bulbeck%2C+D&amp;rft.au=Wilson%2C+JF&amp;rft.au=Gusm%C3%A3o%2C+L&amp;rft.au=Pereira%2C+L&amp;rft.au=Oppenheimer%2C+S&amp;rft.au=Lin%2C+M&amp;rft.au=Richards%2C+MB&amp;rft_id=%2F%2Fwww.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov%2Fpmc%2Farticles%2FPMC4757630&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APhilippines" class="Z3988"></span> The final component (dark blue in Fig. 3b) has a high frequency in South China (Fig. 2b) and is also seen in Taiwan at ~25–30&nbsp;%, <b>in the Philippines at ~20–30&nbsp;%</b> (except in one location which is almost zero) and across Indonesia/Malaysia at 1–10&nbsp;%, declining overall from Taiwan within Austronesian-speaking populations.</span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-273"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-273">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation journal cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.genetics.org/content/early/2015/06/18/genetics.115.178616.full.pdf+html">"Self-identified East Asian nationalities correlated with genetic clustering, consistent with extensive endogamy. Institute for Human Genetics, University of California San Francisco: 1. 2015.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Genetics+Online&amp;rft.atitle=Self-identified+East+Asian+nationalities+correlated+with+genetic+clustering%2C+consistent+with+extensive+endogamy.+Individuals+of+mixed+East+Asian-European+genetic+ancestry+were+easily+identified%3B+we+also+observed+a+modest+amount+of+European+genetic+ancestry+in+individuals+self-identified+as+Filipinos&amp;rft.pages=1&amp;rft.date=2015&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.genetics.org%2Fcontent%2Fearly%2F2015%2F06%2F18%2Fgenetics.115.178616.full.pdf%2Bhtml&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APhilippines" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-274"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-274">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFGo2018" class="citation journal cs1">Go, Matthew C. (January 15, 2018). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.researchgate.net/publication/329903258">"An Admixture Approach to Trihybrid Ancestry Variation in the Philippines with Implications for Forensic Anthropology"</a>. <i>Human Biology</i>. <b>232</b> (3): 178. <a href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<span class="cs1-lock-free" title="Freely accessible"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.13110%2Fhumanbiology.90.3.01">10.13110/humanbiology.90.3.01</a></span><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">September 11,</span> 2020</span>. <q>Filipinos appear considerably admixed with respect to the other Asian population samples, carrying on average less Asian ancestry (71%) than our Korean (99%), Japanese (96%), Thai (93%), and Vietnamese (84%) reference samples. We also revealed substructure in our Filipino sample, showing that the patterns of ancestry vary within the Philippines—that is, between the four differently sourced Filipino samples. Mean estimates of Asian (76%) and European (7%) ancestry are greatest for the cemetery sample of forensic signifĳicance from Manila.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Human+Biology&amp;rft.atitle=An+Admixture+Approach+to+Trihybrid+Ancestry+Variation+in+the+Philippines+with+Implications+for+Forensic+Anthropology&amp;rft.volume=232&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.pages=178&amp;rft.date=2018-01-15&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.13110%2Fhumanbiology.90.3.01&amp;rft.aulast=Go&amp;rft.aufirst=Matthew+C.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.researchgate.net%2Fpublication%2F329903258&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APhilippines" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-275"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-275">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFMawson2016" class="citation journal cs1">Mawson, Stephanie J.          <li id="cite_note-276"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-276">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFWong1999" class="citation book cs1">Wong, Kwok-Chu (1999). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=QZQ0aAAAZ4cC&amp;pg=PA15"><i>The Chinese in the Philippine Economy, 1898–1941</i></a>. Ateneo University Press. pp.&nbsp;15–16. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-971-550-323-5" title="Special:BookSources/978-971-550-323-5"><bdi>978-971-550-323-5</bdi></a><span class="reference-accessdate">.          <li id="cite_note-277"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-277">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">"<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20090826194926/http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2009-08/23/content_11930729.htm">Chinese lunar new year might become national holiday in Philippines too</a>". <i>Xinhua News</i> (August 23, 2009).          <li id="cite_note-278"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-278">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://summit.sfu.ca/system/files/iritems1/6689/b1744892x.pdf">"The ethnic Chinese variable in domestic and foreign policies in Malaysia and Indonesia"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span><span class="reference-accessdate">.          <li id="cite_note-279"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-279">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFCooper2013" class="citation news cs1">Cooper, Matthew (November 15, 2013). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.nationaljournal.com/magazine/why-the-philippines-is-america-s-forgotten-colony-20131115">"Why the Philippines Is America's Forgotten Colony"</a>. <i>National Journal</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">January 28,</span> 2015</span>. <q>c.          <li id="cite_note-280"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-280">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation pressrelease cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://amerasianresearch.org/releases/amerasianresearch-2012-09.pdf">"200,000–250,000 or More Military Filipino Amerasians Alive Today in Republic of the Philippines according to USA-RP Joint Research Paper Finding"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. <i>Amerasian Research Network, Ltd.</i> (Press release).          <li id="cite_note-281"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-281">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFDelfin2013" class="citation journal cs1">Delfin, Fredercik (June 12, 2013). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3895641">"Complete mtDNA genomes of Filipino ethnolinguistic groups: a melting pot of recent and ancient lineages in the Asia-Pacific regio"</a>. <i>European Journal of Human Genetics</i>. <b>22</b> (2): 228–237. <a href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1038%2Fejhg.2013.122">10.1038/ejhg.2013.122</a>. <a href="/wiki/PMC_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="PMC (identifier)">PMC</a>&nbsp;<span class="cs1-lock-free" title="Freely accessible"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3895641">3895641</a></span>. <a href="/wiki/PMID_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="PMID (identifier)">PMID</a>&nbsp;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/23756438">23756438</a>. <q>Indian influence and possibly haplogroups M52'58 and M52a were brought to the Philippines as early as the fifth century AD. However, Indian influence through these trade empires were indirect and mainly commercial; moreover, other Southeast Asian groups served as filters that diluted or enriched any Indian influence that reached the Philippines</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=European+Journal+of+Human+Genetics&amp;rft.atitle=Complete+mtDNA+genomes+of+Filipino+ethnolinguistic+groups%3A+a+melting+pot+of+recent+and+ancient+lineages+in+the+Asia-Pacific+regio&amp;rft.volume=22&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.pages=228-237&amp;rft.date=2013-06-12&amp;rft_id=%2F%2Fwww.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov%2Fpmc%2Farticles%2FPMC3895641%23id-name%3DPMC&amp;rft_id=info%3Apmid%2F23756438&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1038%2Fejhg.2013.122&amp;rft.aulast=Delfin&amp;rft.aufirst=Fredercik&amp;rft_id=%2F%2Fwww.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov%2Fpmc%2Farticles%2FPMC3895641&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APhilippines" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-282"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-282">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFRawashdeh2016" class="citation news cs1">Rawashdeh, Saeb (October 11, 2016). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.jordantimes.com/news/local/arab-world%E2%80%99s-ancient-links-philippines-forged-through-trade-migration-and-islam-%E2%80%94">"Arab world's ancient links to Philippines forged through trade, migration and Islam — ambassador"</a>. <i>The Jordan Times</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">September 11,</span> 2020</span>. <q>In the case of the Philippines, the ancient Hadrami migration found its way from Islamised areas in the south towards Sulu, the southwestern archipelagic region of the Philippines,” she said, adding that the Hadramis settled in Cotabato, Maguindao, Zamboanga, Davao and Bukidnon. An estimated 2 per cent of Filipinos can claim Arab ancestry, the ambassador noted.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Jordan+Times&amp;rft.atitle=Arab+world%27s+ancient+links+to+Philippines+forged+through+trade%2C+migration+and+Islam+%E2%80%94+ambassador&amp;rft.date=2016-10-11&amp;rft.aulast=Rawashdeh&amp;rft.aufirst=Saeb&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.jordantimes.com%2Fnews%2Flocal%2Farab-world%25E2%2580%2599s-ancient-links-philippines-forged-through-trade-migration-and-islam-%25E2%2580%2594&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APhilippines" class="Z3988"></span>.</span> </li>

         <li id="cite_note-308"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-308">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">

         <li id="cite_note-325"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-325">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20200726142745/https://www.who.int/nmh/countries/phl_en.pdf?ua=1">"Philippines"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. <i>World Health Organization – Noncommunicable Diseases (NCD) Country Profiles</i>. 2018.          <li id="cite_note-madrasa-344"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-madrasa_344-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFJerry_E._Esplanada2009" class="citation news cs1">Jerry E.          <li id="cite_note-361"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-361">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.ganintegrity.com/portal/country-profiles/the-philippines/">"The Philippines Corruption Report"</a>. <i>ganintegrity.com</i>.          <li id="cite_note-397"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-397">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">

         <li id="cite_note-413"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-413">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation news cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.abc.net.au/7.30/content/2012/s3402880.htm">"Government urged to help kidnapped Australian"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/Australian_Broadcasting_Corporation" title="Australian Broadcasting Corporation">Australian Broadcasting Corporation</a></i>.          <li id="cite_note-414"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-414">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Hayden Cooper, 2012, Australian Broadcasting Corporation, <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.abc.net.au/7.30/content/2012/s3402880.htm">Government urged to help kidnapped Australian</a>, Retrieved September 3, 2014, "...Warren Richard Rodwell from Australia being held captive by this group since December 5, 2011...please do whatever to raise the 2 million US dollars they are asking for my release ..."<sup id="cite_ref-413" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-413">[412]</a></sup></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-415"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-415">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Florante S. Solmerin, December 7, 2013, Manila Standard, <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://manilastandardtoday.com/2013/12/07/abu-sayyaf-keeping-17-foreigners-hostage/">Abu Sayyaf keeping 17 foreigners hostage</a>, Retrieved July 6, 2020. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20141006085118/http://manilastandardtoday.com/2013/12/07/abu-sayyaf-keeping-17-foreigners-hostage/">Archived</a> October 6, 2014, at the <a href="/wiki/Wayback_Machine" title="Wayback Machine">Wayback Machine</a>, Retrieved September 3, 2014, "...17 foreigners, mostly birdwatchers, were being held hostage by the Abu Sayyaf Group..."</span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-416"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-416">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Roel Pareño, The Philippine Star, March 24, 2013, <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.philstar.com/headlines/2013/03/24/923345/sayyaf-releases-aussie-hostage">Sayyaf releases Aussie hostage</a>, Retrieved July 6, 2020, "...Australian Warren Rodwell emerged early yesterday withered after being held for 15 months by Abu Sayyaf bandits in southern Mindanao..."</span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-417"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-417">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Sun Star, April 25, 2014, <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://archive.today/20140903121828/http://www.sunstar.com.ph/breaking-news/2014/04/25/abducted-tourist-hotel-staff-now-sulu-339790">Abducted tourist, hotel staff now in Sulu</a>, Retrieved September 3, 2014, "...Abu Sayyaf bandits have brought a Chinese tourist and a Filipino hotel receptionist to their jungle stronghold in southern Philippines after kidnapping the women from a dive resort in eastern Malaysia ..."</span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-418"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-418">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">World Bank. Conflict Prevention &amp; Reconstruction Unit. (February 2005). <i><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20091007105619/http://siteresources.worldbank.org/INTCPR/214578-1111996036679/20482477/WP24_Web.pdf">The Mindanao Conflict in the Philippines: Roots, Costs, and Potential Peace Dividend</a></i> by Salvatore Schiavo-Campo and Mary Judd. Washington, DC: World Bank. (Social Development Paper No. 24). Retrieved December 16, 2009.</span> </li>

           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20130522101423/http://www.dost.gov.ph/index.php?option=com_content&amp;view=article&amp;catid=58%3Aabout-dost&amp;id=1124&amp;Itemid=82">"About DOST; The DOST in Brief"</a>. <i>Department of Science and Technology</i>.          <li id="cite_note-Unescoboats-517"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Unescoboats_517-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Unescoboats_517-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFRoxas-Lim" class="citation book cs1">Roxas-Lim, Aurora. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.ichcap.org/eng/ek/sub3/pdf_file/domain5/091_Traditional_Boatbuilding_and_Philippine_Maritime_Culture.pdf"><i>Traditional Boatbuilding and Philippine Maritime Culture</i></a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>.          <li id="cite_note-aguilar-518"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-aguilar_518-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-aguilar_518-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFAguilar2004" class="citation book cs1">Aguilar, Glenn D. In Silvestre, Geronimo; Green, Stuart J.; White, Alan T.; Armada, Nygiel; Luna, Cesar; Cruz-Trinidad, Annabelle; Carreon, Marciano F., III (eds.). <i>In Turbulent Seas: The Status of Philippine Marine Fisheries</i>.          <li id="cite_note-Funtecha-519"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Funtecha_519-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Funtecha_519-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Funtecha_519-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">

         <li id="cite_note-532"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-532">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFAguirre2018" class="citation news cs1">Aguirre, Jun (March 4, 2018). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20200903154448/https://businessmirror.com.ph/2018/03/04/legend-of-the-ati-atihan-fest-in-aklan/">"Legend of the Ati-atihan Fest in Aklan"</a>. <i>BusinessMirror</i>.          <li id="cite_note-533"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-533">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFCinco2018" class="citation news cs1">Cinco, Maricar (March 26, 2018). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20180326035724/https://newsinfo.inquirer.net/978072/moriones-festival-returns-to-religious-roots">"Moriones: solemn tradition, not festive occasion"</a>. <i>Philippine Daily Inquirer</i>. Archived from <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://newsinfo.inquirer.net/978072/moriones-festival-returns-to-religious-roots">the original</a> on March 26, 2018<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">September 3,</span> 2020</span>. <q>The sleepy island province of Marinduque comes to life during Holy Week, with thousands of local visitors and foreign tourists coming down to see one of the Philippines’ oldest religious traditions.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Philippine+Daily+Inquirer&amp;rft.atitle=Moriones%3A+solemn+tradition%2C+not+festive+occasion&amp;rft.date=2018-03-26&amp;rft.aulast=Cinco&amp;rft.aufirst=Maricar&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fnewsinfo.inquirer.net%2F978072%2Fmoriones-festival-returns-to-religious-roots&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APhilippines" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-534"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-534">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">

         <li id="cite_note-549"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-549">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFMurrayNadeau2016" class="citation book cs1">Murray, Jeremy A.; Nadeau, Kathleen M.          <li id="cite_note-CRVP2-565"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-CRVP2_565-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFTalisayon1994" class="citation web cs1">Talisayon, Serafin (1994). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20160417164213/http://www.crvp.org/book/Series03/III-7/chapter_xiii.htm">"Filipino Values, Chapter XIII, Teaching Values in the Natural and Physical Sciences in the Philippines"</a>. <i>crvp.org</i>. In 
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFManuel_B._Dy_Jr.1994" class="citation book cs1">Manuel B. Dy Jr., ed.         <li style="min-height:31px"><span style="display:inline-block;width:31px;line-height:31px;vertical-align:middle;text-align:center"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Wikinews-logo.svg/27px-Wikinews-logo.svg.png" decoding="async" width="27" height="15" style="vertical-align: middle" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Wikinews-logo.svg/41px-Wikinews-logo.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Wikinews-logo.svg/54px-Wikinews-logo.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="759" data-file-height="415"></span><span style="display:inline-block;margin-left:4px;width:182px;vertical-align:middle"><a href="https://en.wikinews.org/wiki/Category:Philippines" class="extiw" title="n:Category:Philippines">News</a> from Wikinews</span></li>

      <ul>
       <li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.gov.ph/">Official website of the National Government of the Republic of the Philippines</a></li>

      <ul>

       <li>
        <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFWeedon2019" class="citation news cs1">Weedon, Alan (August 10, 2019). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.abc.net.au/news/2019-08-10/inside-the-push-to-bring-back-spanish-into-the-philippines/11356590">"The Philippines is fronting up to its Spanish heritage, and for some it's paying off"</a>. <i>ABC News</i>. Australian Broadcasting Corporation.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=ABC+News&amp;rft.atitle=The+Philippines+is+fronting+up+to+its+Spanish+heritage%2C+and+for+some+it%27s+paying+off&amp;rft.date=2019-08-10&amp;rft.aulast=Weedon&amp;rft.aufirst=Alan&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.abc.net.au%2Fnews%2F2019-08-10%2Finside-the-push-to-bring-back-spanish-into-the-philippines%2F11356590&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APhilippines" class="Z3988"></span> About the influence of the Spanish people and language</li> 
       <li>
        <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFCrow1914" class="citation book cs1">Crow, Carl (1914). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/americaandphili03crowgoog"><i>America and the Philippines</i></a>.         <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFWorcester1898" class="citation book cs1">Worcester, Dean C.              <li><a href="/wiki/File:Flag_of_the_Philippines.svg" class="image"><img alt="Flag of the Philippines.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Flag_of_the_Philippines.svg/16px-Flag_of_the_Philippines.svg.png" decoding="async" width="16" height="8" class="noviewer" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Flag_of_the_Philippines.svg/24px-Flag_of_the_Philippines.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Flag_of_the_Philippines.svg/32px-Flag_of_the_Philippines.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="600"></a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Portal:Philippines" title="Portal:Philippines">Philippines portal</a></li>

           </div></td>
         </tr>
        </tbody>
       </table>
      </div>
